ARTICLE IV. - CODE OF ENFORCEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; garbage and refuse disposal, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; license and business regulations, Ch. 11; nuisances, Ch. 12; signs and advertising, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; subdivision and platting regulations, Ch. 17.5; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 21; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Code enforcement, F.S. Ch. 162. 

Sec. 2-46. - Declaration of legislative intent. 
    It is the intent of this article to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Lantana, Florida, by providing an equitable, expeditious, effective and inexpensive method of enforcing the hereinafter described codes of the town. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.02. 
(Code 1962, § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-47. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Town council shall mean the Legislative Body of the Town of Lantana, Florida. 
    Town attorney shall mean the Legal Counselor(s) for the Town of Lantana, Florida. 
    Clerk of the board shall mean the town clerk or any employee of the town so designated by the town administrator. 
    Code inspector shall mean those authorized agents or employees of the municipality whose duty it is to insure code compliance. 
    Enforcement board shall mean the Lantana Code Enforcement Board. 
(Code 1962, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-48. - Enforcement board; organization. 
    The town council shall appoint a seven-member code enforcement board and legal counsel for the board. Alternatively, the town council may appoint a special magistrate to hear code enforcement board cases. References in this article to an enforcement board, except as related to the appointment, qualifications or composition of the actual enforcement board, shall include a special magistrate if the context permits. The members of the board shall have the following qualifications and terms of office: 
(1)  Members of the enforcement board shall be residents of the town. Appointments shall be made by the town council on the basis of experience or interest in the subject matter jurisdiction of the code enforcement board. The membership of the enforcement board shall, whenever possible, include an architect, a businessman, an engineer, a general contractor, a subcontractor and a realtor. The town council may appoint two (2) alternates, if desired. 
(2)  In addition to the qualifications set forth in (1) above, each member of the enforcement board shall have the following minimum qualifications, where appropriate: 
a.  The architects and the engineers shall be registered under the state laws regulating the practice of architecture or engineering, or shall possess similar qualifications under the laws of other states, or shall have actual experience deemed by the town council to be equivalent to such registration; 
b.  The general contractors and the subcontractors shall possess a valid certificate of competency and occupational license, recognized and accepted under the state laws and the ordinances of the city regulating the business of contracting, and where required, state registration as a contractor or shall possess similar qualifications under the laws of other states, or shall have actual experience deemed by the town council to be equivalent to such certification; 
c.  The real estate persons shall be licensed under the state laws licensing real estate persons as either broker or salesman or shall possess similar qualifications under the laws of other states or shall have actual experience deemed by the town council to be equivalent to such licensing, and shall hold a current and valid occupational license issued by the town; 
d.  The business persons shall be actively engaged in any lawful business within the town and shall hold a current and valid occupational license issued by the town, or shall be an officer or employee of a business entity holding a current and valid occupational license issued by the town. 
(3)  All appointments shall be made for a term of three (3) years. Any members may be reappointed for one successive three (3) year term upon approval of the town council. Appointments to fill any vacancy on the enforcement board shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of office. Any member who fails to attend two (2) of three (3) successive meetings without cause and without prior approval of the chairman shall automatically forfeit his appointment and the town council shall promptly fill such vacancy. The members shall serve in accordance with the ordinances of the town and may be suspended and removed for cause as provided in F.S. § 112.501. 
(4)  The members of the enforcement board shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman. The presence of four (4) or more members shall constitute a quorum of the enforcement board. Members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for such travel expenses, mileage expenses and per them expenses as may be authorized by the town manager and approved by the town council. 
(5)  The town attorney shall either act as counsel to the enforcement board or shall represent the town by presenting cases before the board, but in no case shall the town attorney serve in both capacities. Should the town council appoint a special magistrate to hear code enforcement board cases, the town attorney shall act as prosecutor for the town. 
(Code 1962, § 2-34; Ord. No. O-12-89, § 1, 11-27-89; Ord. No. O-19-2012, § 1, 9-24-12; Ord. No. O-01-2019, § 1, 1-28-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.05. 
Sec. 2-49. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the code inspectors to initiate enforcement proceedings of the various codes. No member of the board shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. 
(b)  If a violation of the Code is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator and give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation unless (c) or (d) of this section applies. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction, the code inspector shall notify the enforcement board and request a hearing pursuant to the procedures set forth in sections 2-50 and 2-51 herein or shall, alternatively, proceed to handle the case pursuant to section 2-59 herein. Notice shall be served upon the violator as provided herein section 2-57. 
(c)  If the code inspector has reason to believe a violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the enforcement board and request a hearing. 
(d)  If a repeat violation is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation. The code inspector, upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation, shall notify the enforcement board and request a hearing. The code enforcement board, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing and shall provide notice as set forth herein. The case may be presented to the enforcement board even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the board hearing, and the notice shall so state. 
(Code 1962, § 2-35; Ord. No. O-17-86; § 2, 9-8-86; Ord. No. O-19-87, § 1, 11-23-87; Ord. No. O-12-89, § 2, 11-27-89) 
Sec. 2-50. - Hearings. 
(a)  The chairman of the enforcement board may call hearings of the enforcement board and hearings may also be called by written notice signed by at least three (3) members of the enforcement board. The enforcement board at any hearing may set a future hearing date. The enforcement board should attempt to convene no less frequently than once every two (2) months, but may meet more or less often as the demand necessitates. 
(b)  Minutes shall be kept of all hearings by the enforcement board and all hearings shall be open to the public. The town clerk's office shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the enforcement board for the proper performance of its duties. 
(c)  Each case before the enforcement board shall be presented by the local governing body attorney, or by a member of the staff of the local governing body. 
(d)  The enforcement board shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The enforcement board shall take testimony from the code inspector and alleged violator. 
(e)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the enforcement board shall issue findings of fact and conclusions of law and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with powers granted herein. The finding shall be by motion approved by a majority of those present and voting, except that at least four (4) members of the enforcement board must vote in order for the action to be official. 
(Code 1962, § 2-36; Ord. No. O-19-87, § 2, 11-23-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.07. 
Sec. 2-51. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  No board member shall act in any case in which that member has a conflict of interest, as discussed in F.S. Chapter 112, Part III. 
(b)  Hearings shall be informal and need not be conducted according to technical rules relating to evidence and witnesses. They shall, however, be conducted in accordance with accepted parliamentary procedures relative to motions, votes and decisions. Fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern all hearings. 
(c)  All relevant evidence shall be admitted if, in the opinion of the board, it is the type of evidence upon which reasonable and responsible persons would normally rely in the conduct of business affairs, regardless of the existence of any common law or statutory rule which might make such evidence inadmissible over objections in civil actions. The chairman of the board may exclude irrelevant or unduly repetitious evidence. 
(d)  Hearsay evidence may be accepted for the purpose of supplementing or explaining any direct evidence, but such hearsay evidence shall not in and of itself be considered sufficient to support a finding or decision unless the evidence would be admissible over objections in a civil action. 
(e)  Each party to the hearing shall have the right to: 
(1)  Call and examine witnesses; 
(2)  Introduce exhibits; 
(3)  Cross-examine opposing witnesses; 
(4)  Impeach witnesses; 
(5)  Rebut evidence. 
(f)  The alleged violator has the right to be represented by an attorney at the violation hearing. 
(Code 1962, § 2-37(a)-(f)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.08. 
Sec. 2-52. - Power of board. 
    The board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings not otherwise in conflict with this article or the local government code enforcement boards act, F.S. Ch. 162, as such now exist or may hereafter be amended; 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings; 
(3)  Subpoena evidence to its hearings. 
(4)  Take testimony under oath; 
(5)  Issue orders having the force of law commanding whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(6)  Reduce fines after compliance upon application to the board. 
(Code 1962, § 2-37(g); Ord. No. O-12-89, § 3, 11-27-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.08. 
Sec. 2-53. - Waiver of hearing. 
    The alleged violators may, however, if he so elects, waive his right to a hearing and consent to the imposition of a fine after a stated period of time in which to comply. The waiver shall be in writing on a form provided by the town, signed by all violators named in the notice of violation and witnessed. 
(Code 1962, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-54. - Subpoena powers and procedures. 
    The code inspectors, the board, or the alleged violator may request that witnesses, records, including surveys, plats, and other materials, and other evidence, be subpoenaed to any violation hearing. Subpoenas shall be served by the sheriff of the county, or the police department of the town. These subpoenas shall be available through the clerk of the enforcement board. A nominal administrative fee shall be charged for the preparation and service of the subpoenas, the amount of which administrative fee shall be established by resolution of the town council. 
(Code 1962, § 2-39; Ord. No. O-17-86, § 2, 9-8-86; Ord. No. O-19-87, § 3, 11-23-87) 
Sec. 2-55. - Fines. 
    The enforcement board, upon notification by the code inspector that a previous order of the enforcement board has not been complied with by the set time, may order the violator to pay a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day that the violation continues past the date set for compliance for a first violation and may order the violator to pay a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day the violation continues past the date set forth for compliance for a repeat violation. A certified copy of an order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public records and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists. If the violator does not own the land, the lien shall be upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator. It may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgement, including levy against the personal property. After three (3) months from the date of filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the enforcement board may authorize the town attorney to foreclose on the lien. No lien created pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under section 4, article X, of the state Constitution. 
(Code 1962, § 2-40; Ord. No. O-12-89, § 4, 11-27-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.09. 
Sec. 2-56. - Appeal. 
    An aggrieved party, including the local governing body, may appeal a final administrative order of an enforcement board to the circuit court. Such an appeal shall not be a hearing de novo, but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the enforcement board. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the order to be appealed. 
(Code 1962, § 2-42; Ord. No. O-19-87, § 4, 11-23-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.12. 
Sec. 2-57. - Notices. 
    All notices must be provided to the alleged violator as follows: 
(1)  By certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address listed in the tax collector's office for tax notices or the address listed in the Palm Beach County property appraiser's database. Additional notice may also be provided to any other address the town may find for the property owner; 
(2)  For property owned by a corporation, notices may be provided by certified mail to the registered agent of the corporation; 
(3)  By hand delivery by the sheriff or other law enforcement officer, code inspector, or other person designated by the town; 
(4)  By leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with any person residing therein who is above the age of fifteen (15) years and informing such person of the contents of the notice; or 
(5)  In the case of commercial premises, leaving the notice with the manager or other person in charge. 
(6)  If any notice sent by certified mail is not signed as received within thirty (30) days after the postmarked date of mailing, notice may be provided by posting as described hereinbelow. 
(7)  In addition to providing notices as set forth above, at the option of the code enforcement board or special magistrate, notice may also be served by publication or posting as follows: 
(a)  If publication is the method of notice to be utilized, such notice shall be published once during each week of four (4) consecutive weeks, (four (4) publications being sufficient) in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the code enforcement board is located. The newspaper shall meet the requirements as are prescribed under F.S. Ch. 50, as amended, by legal and official advertisements. 
(b)  Proof of publication shall be made as provided in F.S. §§ 50.041 and 50.051. 
(c)  In lieu of publication as described in paragraph (a), such notice may be posted for at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing or prior to the expiration of any deadline contained in the notice, in at least two locations, one (1) of which shall be the property upon which the violation is alleged to exist and the other of which shall be at Lantana Town Hall. 
(d)  Proof of posting shall be by affidavit of the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted, and the date and places of its posting. 
(8)  Notice of publication or posting may run concurrently with, or may follow, an attempt or attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required above. 
(9)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided above, together with proof of publication or posting as provided herein, shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirements of this section as set forth in conformance with F.S. Ch. 162, have been met, without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
(Code 1962, § 2-43; Ord. No. O-17-86, § 2, 9-8-86; Ord. No. O-19-87, § 5, 11-23-87; Ord. No. O-12-89, § 5, 11-27-89; Ord. No. O-19-2012, § 2, 9-24-12; Ord. No. O-09-2013, § 1, 7-8-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 162.12. 
Sec. 2-58. - Ex parte communications. 
    No ex parte communication relative to the merits, threat or offer of reward shall be made to the board by any employee of the town, or any party to the proceeding, or any person who directly or indirectly would have a material interest in an action pending before the board, or the authorized representative or counsel of any such party. 
(Code 1962, § 2-44) 
Sec. 2-59. - Alternate code enforcement procedures. 
(a)  Issuance of citations. A code enforcement officer is authorized to issue a citation to a person when, based on personal investigation, the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a civil infraction in violation of a duly enacted code or ordinance and this citation will be heard by the county court. 
(b)  Notice. Prior to issuing a citation, a code enforcement officer shall provide notice to the person that has committed a violation of a code or ordinance and shall establish a reasonable time period within which the person must correct the violation. Such time period shall be no more than thirty (30) days. If, upon personal investigation, a code enforcement officer finds that the person has not corrected the violation within the time period allowed, the code enforcement officer may issue a citation to the person who has committed the violation. If the code enforcement officer has reason to believe that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible, the code enforcement officer is not obligated to provide the person with a reasonable time period within which to correct the violation prior to the issuance of the citation. 
(c)  Form of citation. The citation issued by the code enforcement officer shall be in a form prescribed by the town and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The date and time of issuance. 
(2)  The name and address of the person to whom this citation is issued. 
(3)  The date and time the civil infraction was committed for the facts constituting reasonable cause. 
(4)  The number or section of the code or ordinance violated. 
(5)  The name and authority of the code enforcement officer. 
(6)  The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil penalty or contest the citation. 
(7)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects to contest the citation. 
(8)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects not to contest the citation. 
(9)  A conspicuous statement if the person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, he shall be deemed to have waived his right to contest the citation and that, in such case, judgement may be entered against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. 
(d)  Disposition by county court. After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, a code enforcement officer shall deposit the original citation and one (1) copy of the citation with the county court for further disposition. 
(e)  Certain ordinances lend themselves to be enforced by means of a citation method and as such, the town has deemed the following sections of the code those to be enforced through the citation method and has provided a schedule of violations and penalties to be assessed as follows:

Section 23-136-Junk yards, salvage yards, and scrap metal yards prohibited; limited open storage allowed as accessory uses in the Industrial zoning district 
Section 23-147-Occupancy regulation 
Upon receipt of a citation, the person alleged to have violated the Town Code may request a court appearance. The county court judge may assess a maximum civil penalty not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) if contested. If the citation is not contested, the amount of fine is the face value of the citation plus costs. 
(f)  Code violations; civil infraction. All violations of the Code of Ordinances shall be considered as civil infractions with a maximum civil penalty not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(g)  Citation contested; county court. Should any person receiving a citation desire to contest same, such person shall have the right to appear in county court in order to present his case and have the determined position made by the court. 
(h)  Failure to accept citation; misdemeanor. Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a code enforcement officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided in section 755.082 or 775.083, Florida Statutes. 
(i)  Citations not applicable to certain portions of building codes: The provisions of this section shall not apply to the enforcement pursuant to section 553.79 and 553.80 of the building codes adopted pursuant to section 553.73 as they apply to construction, provided that a building permit is either not required or has been issued by the municipality. For the purpose of this subsection, building codes means only those codes adopted pursuant to section 553.73. 
(j)  Provisions additional and supplemental. The provisions of the section are additional and supplemental means of enforcing municipal codes and ordinances and may be used for the enforcement of any code or ordinance or for the enforcement of all codes and ordinances except as set forth herein above. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the town from enforcing its codes or ordinances by any other means. 
(Ord. No. O-12-89, § 6, 11-27-89; Ord. No. O-14-90, § 1, 8-13-90; Ord. No. O-10-91, § 1, 1-13-92; Ord. No. O-4-93, § 1, 1O-25-93) 
Secs. 2-60-2-100. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - GREATER LANTANA SCHOOL COMMUNITY EDUCATION COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-110. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a municipal advisory board to be known as the "Greater Lantana School Community Education Council", also informally known as the "education council", which shall consist of a maximum of eight (8) voting members and three (3) non-voting "ex-officio" members. 
    Four (4) voting members shall constitute a quorum in order to conduct and vote upon any and all council business. 
(Ord. No. O-05-01, § 1, 3-26-01; Ord. No. O-01-02, § 1, 1-28-02; Ord. No. O-05-03, § 1, 6-9-03; Ord. No. O-03-05, § 1, 3-28-05; Ord. No. O-06-2018 § 1, 8-27-18) 
Sec. 2-111. - Eligible members. 
    The eight (8) members of the Greater Lantana School Community Education Council, to be appointed by the town council as follows: 
(a)  Six (6) residents of the Town of Lantana; 
(b)  One (1) member-at-large who is not a resident of the town; 
(c)  One (1) member from the Greater Lantana Chamber of Commerce; 
(d)  The principals from the three (3) schools are non-voting "ex-officio members". 
(e)  Additionally, the town council may appoint one (1) member of the town council as a non-voting liaison to the education council, if desired. 
(Ord. No. O-05-01, § 1, 3-26-01; Ord. No. O-01-02, § 1, 1-28-02; Ord. No. O-05-03, § 1, 6-9-03; Ord. No. O-03-05, § 1, 3-28-05; Ord. No. O-06-2018 § 1, 8-27-18) 
Sec. 2-112. - Residence requirement. 
    All members of the education council shall reside in the town except the member from the Greater Lantana Chamber of Commerce, the member-at-large as set forth in subsection 2-111(a) above, the members appointed by the Towns of Manalapan, South Palm Beach and Hypoluxo as set forth in subsection 2-110(b) above, the members representing the Lantana Public Schools as set forth above at subsection 2-111(c), and the non-voting members set forth in subsections 2-111(d) and (e) above. 
(Ord. No. O-05-03, § 1, 6-9-03; Ord. No. O-03-05, § 1, 3-28-05) 
Sec. 2-113. - Meetings. 
    The Greater Lantana School Community Education Council shall meet on a semi-annual basis, but may meet more frequently if the town manager determines that a special meeting is necessary. Minutes must be recorded at every meeting. All meetings shall conform to the requirements of F.S. Chapter 286, known as Government in the Sunshine Law and all documents generated or received by members of the council shall be subject to F.S. Chapter 119, known as the Public Records Act. 
(Ord. No. O-05-01, § 1, 3-26-01; Ord. No. O-06-2013, § 1, 6-10-13) 
Sec. 2-114. - Term. 
    The members of the education council shall generally be appointed to three-year terms; however, in order that the terms will be staggered the members will be appointed as follows: four (4) of the initial council members shall be appointed for a one-year term; four (4) for a two-year term; four (4) for a three-year term; and the "ex-officio" member(s) and the member-at-large shall each be appointed for a three-year term. Thereafter, all members shall be appointed to three-year terms. Members and the "ex-officio" member(s) may be re-appointed for successive terms. 
(Ord. No. O-05-03, § 1, 6-9-03; Ord. No. O-03-05, § 1, 3-28-05) 
Sec. 2-115. - Powers and duties. 
    The Greater Lantana School Community Education Council shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  Establish and amend by-laws from time to time to govern the council's business and election of officers from those appointed as set forth in section 2-110; 
(b)  Represent the Town of Lantana and other constituents of the Lantana Public Schools who do not reside in the town; 
(c)  Develop and build community partnerships with local business within the Greater Lantana Area to assist with professional skills, materials, financial or education support for education; 
(d)  Monitor school board activities; 
(e)  Serve as a liaison between the school board of Palm Beach County and the town council; 
(f)  Participate in an exchange of information with all public school principals in Lantana through varied media; 
(g)  Develop recommendations to present to the town council for action on issues concerning the school board of Palm Beach County in support of schools in the Greater Lantana School Community; 
(h)  Promote a positive image of the Greater Lantana Area through varied public relations media such as, the Internet and student-produced web pages; 
(i)  Build community and parental involvement in the schools; 
(j)  Develop additional resources such as state and federal funding to support the schools; 
(k)  Provide school programs to benefit all students in partnerships with other community groups such as, the Greater Lantana Chamber of Commerce, real estate groups and other community groups in the Greater Lantana School Community; and 
(l)  Address safety issues for students before, after and during school. 
(Ord. No. O-05-01, § 1, 3-26-01; Ord. No. O-03-05, § 1, 3-28-05) 
Sec. 2-116. - Coordination with town. 
    The Greater Lantana School Community Education Council shall be an advisory board to the town council; the actions, decisions and recommendations of the council shall not be final or binding on the town council but shall constitute recommendations to the town council. The education council shall periodically advise the town council of its recommendations with regard to issues and shall respond to any matter referred to it by the town council within such time as prescribed by the town council. 
(Ord. No. O-05-01, § 1, 3-26-01) 
Secs. 2-117-2-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TOWN OF LANTANA ETHICS ORDINANCE 

Sec. 2-121. - Town ethics article. 
(a)  The intent of this article is to provide for the adoption of the Palm Beach County Code of Ethics, by reference, as the town's own ethics provisions and to authorize the jurisdiction of the Palm Beach County Commission on Ethics within the Town of Lantana so that these referenced County ethics regulations and the jurisdiction of the Commission on Ethics, as such regulations or jurisdiction may be amended in the future by the County, shall apply within the Town of Lantana. 
(b)  . The Town of Lantana adopts by reference, and as its own, the Palm Beach County Code of Ethics, set forth in Palm Beach County Code in Chapter 2, Article XIII, at the following sections: sections 2-441 through 2-443; subsections 2-444(c), (d), and (e); and sections 2-445 through 2-448. 
(c)  The Palm Beach County Commission on Ethics, as referenced in the Palm Beach County Code in Chapter 2, Article V, at Division 8, in sections 2-254 through 2-260.10, as these sections may be amended, shall exercise jurisdiction in the Town of Lantana, subject to the provisions for same as set forth in the Interlocal Agreement between the town and the county concerning the applicability of the county's Code of Ethics and the Commission on Ethics within the Town of Lantana. 
(d)  The Palm Beach County Code of Ethics and Commission on Ethics ordinances provisions, set forth hereinabove, in existence as of the effective date of this Ordinance are hereby incorporated by reference into the Town Code of Ordinances and shall be kept on file in the office of the town clerk for reference purposes. In addition, a copy of the executed interlocal agreement between the town and the county concerning such ethics provisions shall also be kept on file in the office of the town clerk. 
(e)  All references to county government provided for in the Palm Beach County Commission on Ethics and Code of Ethics ordinances, including but not limited to county elected and appointed officials, county employees, county divisions and departments, shall be deemed as reference to the corresponding elected and appointed officers, divisions and departments of the Town of Lantana as appropriate to effectuate the intent of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-10-2010, § 1, 9-27-2010) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-46; beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; building and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage and refuse disposal, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 11; nuisances, Ch. 12; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; signs and advertising, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; subdivision and platting regulations, Ch. 17.5; taxation, Ch. 18; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverage code, F.S. § 561.01 et seq, ; authority to regulate hours of sale, F.S. §§ 562.14(l), 562.45(2); municipal tax prohibited, F.S. § 561.342(3); limitation on number of licenses issued, F.S. § 561.20(4); sale of malt beverages for off-premises consumption not subject to municipal zoning, F.S. § 563.02(l)(a); selling to habitual drunkard, F.S. § 562.50. 

Sec. 3-1. - Hours of sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, purchase, deliver, serve, consume or permit the sale, purchase, delivery, service or consumption of any alcoholic beverages on or off the following premises, except during the hours specifically set forth in this section and stated below: 
(1)  Nightclubs, bars and lounges. Nightclubs, bars and lounges may serve alcoholic beverages during the following hours: 
a.  Mondays through Saturdays: Alcoholic beverages may be sold from 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following morning. 
b.  Sundays: Alcoholic beverages may be sold from 12:00 p.m. (noon) until 2:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(2)  Establishments other than nightclubs bars and lounges. 
a.  Sundays: Alcoholic beverages may be sold from 10:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following morning except packaged goods for consumption off-premises (i.e., at grocery stores, package stores, and similar establishments), which may be sold from 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following morning. 
b.  On days of the week other than Sunday, alcoholic beverages may be sold from 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(Ord. No. O-27-86, § 1, 1-12-87; Ord. No. O-9-88, § 1, 6-27-88; Ord. No. O-17-05, § 1, 10-10-05; Ord. No. O-06-2008, § 1, 6-9-08; Ord. No. O-09-2019, § 1, 2-25-19) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O-27-86, § 1, adopted Jan. 12, 1987, repealed former § 3-1, pertaining to hours of sale of alcoholic beverages, and add new provisions in lieu thereof to read as set out herein. Prior to repeal, former § 3-1 derived from Code 1962, § 3-1. 
Cross reference- License schedule, § 11-28., 
State Law reference- Authorization for town to establish hours of sale, G.S. §§ 562.14(l), 562.45(2). 
Sec. 3-2. - Location of establishments. 
(a)  Nightclubs, bars and lounges. Nightclubs, bars and lounges are permittable by special exception use approval in those zoning districts as set forth in the zoning code. 
(b)  Hotels. Hotels serving alcohol are a permitted use in the MXD, MI, and MW zoning districts and are permittable by special exception use approval in those zoning districts as set forth in the zoning code. 
(c)  Restaurants. Restaurants serving alcohol are permitted in the zoning districts as set forth in the zoning code. 
(d)  Retail establishments. Retail establishments (i.e., grocery stores, package stores, and similar establishments), selling alcohol are permitted in the zoning districts as set forth in the zoning code. 
(Code 1962, § 3-2; Ord. No. O-09-2019, § 2, 2-25-19) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate location, G.S. §§ 562.14(l), 562.45(2). 
Sec. 3-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-2019, § 3, adopted Feb. 28, 2019, repealed § 3-3, which pertained to exceptions to location restrictions and derived from the Code 1962, § 3-2. 
Sec. 3-4. - Alcoholic beverages in public places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any open containers or consume any alcoholic beverages on any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way, park, beach, or upon the premises of a retail establishment while outside the confines of the structure on such premises, when the main use of the establishment is the sale of alcoholic beverages, or upon any parking lot or driveway on any business, industrial, or institutional property where the public has a right to travel; while expressly exempting from the prohibition stated hereinabove any sale and/or consumption of beer and wine only on town-owned or other property during special event functions which occur within the confines of the area designated by the special events permit granted by the town specifically allowing such sale and/or consumption pursuant to section 11-25 or 11-25.1. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any open container of or consume any alcoholic beverages in or on a motor vehicle being operated on or parked on any public street, right-of-way, park, beach, or any parking lot or driveway on any business, industrial, or institutional property or any public area open for vehicular traffic. 
(c)  Possession of an open container of any alcoholic beverage shall not be unlawful in the following instances: 
(1)  When any person is picking up empty containers in an effort to control litter; 
(2)  When any licensed vendor or distributor of alcoholic beverages is transporting beverages solely for commercial purposes; 
(3)  When the open container is not readily accessible to the driver or passengers, as in a trunk or locked glove compartment of a vehicle; 
(4)  When the transportation of any open container or consumption of alcoholic beverage shall take place in or on any motor vehicle duly licensed and operated for hire to transport passengers, such as charter buses, regularly scheduled buses, taxicabs, and the separate passenger compartments of limousines; provided that the operator is not in immediate possession of an open container of any alcoholic beverage, nor engaged in the consumption of any alcoholic beverage. 
(5)  When any person is in attendance and within the confines of the area for which a special events permit has been issued by the town allowing the sale and/or consumption of beer and wine only during such special event. 
(d)  Any person found in violation of the provisions of this section shall be issued a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1962, § 3-3; Ord. No. O-11-86, § 1, 5-12-86; Ord. No. O-06-01, § 1, 4-23-01) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O-11-86, § 1, adopted May 12, 1986, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as § 3-4 was at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 3-5. - Forfeiture of vehicles and apparatus. 
    Any vehicle, vessel, aircraft or any animal used in the transportation or removal of, or for the deposit or concealment of any illicit liquor, still, or stilling apparatus, or any mash or other fermented liquids capable of being distilled or manufactured into alcoholic beverages where seized by a police officer within the town shall be forfeited as provided by general law. All sums received shall be deposited into the general operating fund of the town. (Code 1962, § 3-4) 
Cross reference- Offenses, Ch. 13; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Forfeiture of contraband, F.S. § 562.407. 
Sec. 3-6. - Nudity on premises where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, or operating a commercial establishment located within the town at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to expose to the public view that area of the human breast at or below the areola thereof. 
(2)  To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such portions of the human female breast as described in (1) above. 
(3)  To suffer or permit any person while on the premises of the commercial establishment to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(4)  To suffer or permit any person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, anal cleft or cleavage. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any female person while on the premises of a commercial establishment located within the town at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, to expose to public view that area of the human female breast at or below the areola thereof, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such areas of the female breast as described herein. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment located within the town at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale or consumption on the premises, to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft or cleavage, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(Code 1962, § 3-5) 
Cross reference- Offenses, Ch. 13; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 3-7. - Revocation of occupational license. 
    If the owner, operator, licensee, lessor, lessee, manager, employee or any other person participating in the operation of a commercial establishment located within the town in which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises shall be found to have violated any sections of this chapter, in addition to any other penalties prescribed, the town council may revoke the occupational license for the establishment after giving a reasonable notice thereof to the holder of the license and affording the holder an opportunity to be heard as to why the license should not be revoked. 
(Code 1962, § 3-6) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 11. 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement, § 2-46; beaches, boats and waterways, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; garbage and refuse disposal, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; nuisances, Ch. 12; offenses, Ch. 13; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Animals, F.S. Ch. 828; damage by dogs, F.S. Ch. 767; livestock, F.S. § 588.12 et seq.; cruelty, § 828.02 et seq. 

Sec. 4-1. - Protection of birds. 
(a)  The entire area embraced within the town is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, hunt, kill or attempt to trap, hunt, shoot, kill or molest any bird or wild fowl in any manner or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests within the town. Provided however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregated in such numbers in any particular locality within said town to the extent that complaint is made to the town council that such birds constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property, then in such case a meeting shall be called by the town council of representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club, Humane Society, or as many of the clubs as are found to exist in the town, which are interested in such problems, after having given at least three (3) days actual notice of the time and place of the meeting. Thereupon, if as a result of the meeting, no acceptable alternative is found to abate such nuisance, then such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by the town council under the supervision of the chief of police of the town or such other officer as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1962, § 4-16) 
Sec. 4-2. - Hog pens; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a hog or pig pen within the town without a special permit from the town council. 
(Code 1962, § 4-19) 
Cross reference- Town council, § 2-16; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 4-3. - Town recreation facilities-Prohibitions. 
(a)  All pets and domestic animals are prohibited on the public beach and in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean adjacent thereto which are reserved for swimming. It shall also be unlawful for any person to take into or to have any wild animal or livestock on the public beach and in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean or any town recreation facility. Feeding wild animals on the public beach or in town recreation facilities is prohibited. 
(b)  All pets and domestic animals are prohibited in any town recreation facility except domestic dogs, which are specifically permitted within the designated areas of town dog parks. Dogs are not required to be on a leash when the dog is within the designated secure or "off-leash" areas of town dog parks. However, the person who owns or has escorted the dog to the dog park shall maintain reasonable custody and control over the dog at all times. 
(c)  All dogs within a town dog park are required to have up to date vaccinations and be properly licensed through Palm Beach County Animal Control. The dog license/dog tag must be properly affixed to the dog's collar or harness. Any dog not being properly vaccinated, licensed and tagged is prohibited in town dog parks. 
(d)  Any dog which has been classified as "dangerous" or as "vicious" by the Palm Beach County Animal Care and Control Division is specifically prohibited in town dog parks. (See section 4-4). 
(e)  Service dogs or dogs used by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duty are exempt from subsections (a) and (b) hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2013, § 1, 2-25-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-02-2013, § 1, adopted Feb. 25, 2013, repealed § 4-3, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 4-3 pertained to "Public beach; pets prohibited, etc." See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Cross reference- Beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 4-4. - Dogs running at large; impoundment; redemption; disposition; "dangerous" dogs; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or be in control of or in charge of any dog to permit such dog to run at large within the town. Dogs may be taken to all public places within the town's corporate limits except those places where notice has been posted by the town as off limits for dogs, so long as they remain at all times on a leash, chain, or similar restraining device and under the control of the custodian of the dog. In this section, "at large" shall mean that the animal is away from the premises of the owner or custodian of the dog and not under control of the custodian as set forth herein. 
(b)  If any dog shall run at large within the town, proof of the identity of such dog and the ownership thereof shall be sufficient to find violation of the terms and provisions of this section. The dog shall be subject to being picked up by the Palm Beach County Animal Care and Control Division (the "division") and shall be placed there pursuant to the division's rules and regulations. Owners of such dogs must present proof of ownership/rabies inoculation, proper licensing and pay any charges as set forth by the division in order to obtain the release of their animals. 
(c)  Any dog which has been classified as "dangerous" or as "vicious" by the division pursuant to the division's procedures for such classification, may be off the owner's premises only under limited circumstances as set forth in the division's rules and regulations. 
(d)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject, in addition to the fees and charges set forth in subsection (b) above, to penalties as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges adopted by resolution of the town council and such penalties may then be revised from time to time by resolution of the town council. Additionally, this section may be enforced by any lawful means available to the town, including a hearing before the code enforcement board or the special magistrate. 
(Ord. No. O-03-03, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. O-02-2019, § 1, 1-28-19) 
Sec. 4-5. - Keeping of certain animals or birds prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep, raise, harbor and/or maintain, within the town limits, any chickens, geese, turkeys, horses, mules, sheep, cattle, hogs, pigs (with the exception of a miniature pig, or micro pig or teacup pig which may be kept as long as each miniature pig or micro pig or teacup pig weighs no more than thirty-five (35) pounds and each miniature pig or micro pig or teacup pig is kept in accordance with the provisions of this chapter), goats or other livestock or fowl. 
(Ord. No. O-11-06, § 1, 8-28-06; Ord. No. O-02-2018, § 1, 6-11-18) 
Sec. 4-6. - Animals creating nuisances. 
    The keeping, raising, harboring and/or maintaining of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent and/or loud (as defined in section 12-17 of this Code) continued barking, whining, howling or other objectionable noise or foul odor, interferes with the reasonable use and enjoyment of any other property in the neighborhood, or is otherwise offensive so as to create a nuisance shall be deemed to be committing an act in violation of this section as well as Chapter 12 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-11-06, § 2, 8-28-06) 
Sec. 4-6.1. - Sanitation. 
(a)  No owner or custodian of any dog, cat or other domestic animal shall cause or allow such dog, cat or domestic animal to soil, defile or defecate on any public property or upon any public street, road or right-of-way within the town or upon private property other than that of the owner, unless such owner or custodian immediately removes and disposes of all feces deposited by such dog, cat or domestic animal. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalties as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges adopted by resolution of the town council and such penalties may be revised from time to time by resolution of the town council. Additionally, this section may be enforced by any lawful means available to the town, including a hearing before the code enforcement board or special magistrate. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2008, § 1, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 4-7. - Poisonous or venomous insects, reptiles and animals prohibited. 
    The keeping, raising, harboring and/or maintaining of any insects, reptiles or animals that are capable of delivering any poison, toxin or venom to their victim by any means whatsoever, are strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-11-06, § 3, 8-28-06) 
Sec. 4-8. - Enforcement. 
    This chapter may be enforced by citation to the code enforcement board or special magistrate and/or though any other lawful means available to the town. No one (1) means of enforcement shall be the exclusive remedy. 
(Ord. No. O-11-06, § 4, 8-28-06) 
Chapter 5 - BEACHES, BOATS, WATERWAYS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - BEACHES [2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Police reserve officers, Ch. 15; offenses, Ch. 13; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17. 

Sec. 5-16. - Fishing restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fish from, or to cast with any fly rod, bait rod, or spinning tackle from or upon the Lantana municipal beach property at any time from three (3) hours after sunrise to one (1) hour before sunset. 
(Code 1962, § 5-4) 
Sec. 5-17. - Public beach; rules and regulations. 
    Rules and regulations for the public beach of the town and its adjacent areas known as the Lantana municipal beach are hereby promulgated. The beach rules shall be enforced by the police department and the beach patrol. These rules are supplemental to conduct prohibited elsewhere in the Code. 
(Code 1962, § 4A-1; Ord. No. O-17-86, § 2, 9-8-86) 
Sec. 5-18. - Public beach; unlawful conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey the rules and regulations for the Lantana municipal beach. Violators shall be penalized in accordance with the town Code. Although appropriate signs regarding the rules on the beach shall be conspicuously placed at the public beach, neither the posting of the signs nor viewing of a sign by a violator need be provided for conviction hereof. 
(1)  Littering. No person shall place or throw any trash, garbage, refuse or other litter on the beach except in the receptacles provided. 
(2)  Driving or parking on beach. No private motor vehicles shall be driven or parked on the beach or on any unpaved area thereof. 
(3)  Spearguns, slings, harpoons. Spearguns, slings, harpoons, and similar equipment are prohibited on the beach and in the waters. The extreme north and south boundaries are excepted for the sole purpose of being access routes for those using the instruments in waters other than the Lantana municipal beach. 
(4)  Skimboards. No person shall use a skimboard or its equivalent on the beach or in the waters thereof, unless specifically approved by the beach patrol. 
(5)  Surfboards, belly boards and similar equipment. Surfboards, belly boards and similar equipment are prohibited from being used in the water area where swimmers are present or where determined by the beach patrol. 
(6)  Bathing or swimming in surf area. Persons shall bathe or swim in the surfing area only when no surfboards are being used there. 
(7)  Vessels or airplanes. No person shall bring any boat, or other vessel, or amphibious airplane to less than eight hundred (800) feet of the shoreline of Lantana municipal beach. 
(8)  Use of beach for assemblies. No person shall use the beach for the assembly of over fifty (50) persons without obtaining written permission of the town manager. The request for such use shall be made to the town on forms provided by the town clerk. 
(9)  Swimmers to stay within fifty (50) yards of shore. As a condition of swimming at the Lantana Beach, all swimmers in the waters thereof must remain within fifty (50) yards of shore. Swimmers must obey requests of lifeguards to remain within this area or leave the Lantana municipal beach. Surfers in the surfing area are excepted from the provisions hereof. 
(10)  Personal flotation devices. No person shall use a raft, inner tube, beach ball, or other personal flotation device beyond twenty-five (25) yards of shore. Surfers and those with boogie boards are exempted from the provisions herein. 
(11)  Banning of public from beach area. The beach patrol may, when it is deemed necessary for the sake of public safety, order all persons from the water or beach area. 
(Code 1962, § 4A-2; Ord. No. O-17-86, § 2, 9-8-86) 
Secs. 5-19-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. O-15-87, adopted Oct. 26, 1987, renumbered former §§ 5-33-5-36 as 5-40-5-43. Sections 3-9 of the ordinance enacted new §§ 5-33-5-39 to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Throwing stones at any marine vessels, railroad trains, car or any other vehicle prohibited, § 13-4. 
State Law reference- Boats, F.S. Ch. 327; fishing, F.S. Ch. 370. 

Sec. 5-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Prohibited area shall mean the lake bottom lands within the town not previously reserved by ordinance or the Code for the anchorage or parking of vessels. 
    Vessel shall mean watercraft of every description used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water in addition to the definitions contained in Section 327.02, Florida Statutes, as amended. 
    Mooring shall mean any appliance used to secure a vessel other than to a pier. 
    Anchor shall mean any appliance used to secure a vessel other than to a pier which is carried aboard such vessel as regular equipment when under way. 
    Pier shall mean any fixed or floating structure that is part of or affixed to land such as a wharf, dock, float or other loading facility. 
(Code 1962, § 16-43; Ord. No. O-15-87, § 1, 1O-26-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-32. - Limitation on anchoring, mooring, parking in prohibited area; mooring permit required. 
    It is declared to be unlawful for any person to anchor, moor or park in a stationary position or cause or permit or allow any other person under his control or command to do same, any vessel in the prohibited area for a period of time of more than ninety-six (96) continuous hours in any consecutive thirty-day period. The occupants of such vessel shall obtain a mooring permit from the police department and register the occupants and vessel on forms provided by the chief of police within eighteen (18) hours after such vessel has been secured for anchoring, mooring or parking in the prohibited area. A mooring permit fee shall be required as established by the council, 
(Code 1962, § 16-44) 
Cross reference- Offenses, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 5-33. - Unlawfully parked vessels-Police to impound. 
    The police department of the town is authorized and directed to take into custody and impound any such vessel and any such vessel taken into custody and impounded under the authority of the police department shall not be released therefrom until the charges for towing such vessel and storage charges have been paid. The charge for towing or removal of any such vessel and storage charges shall be reasonable and shall be the customary charges prevailing in the town for such services. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 3, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-34. - Same-Owner to be notified upon impoundment. 
    Whenever any vessel is taken into custody and impounded by the authority of the police department as authorized herein, and the name and address of the owner of such vessel can be ascertained by the police department, it shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reason therefor and the place to which such vessel has been removed. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 4, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-35. - Same-Procedure in event owner cannot be found. 
    Whenever the police department authorizes the removal of such vessel from the prohibited area as authorized herein and the police department does not know and is not able to ascertain the name and address of the owner of such vessel or for any other reason is unable to give the notice to the owner, and in the event the vessel is not returned to the owner within a period of three (3) days after same has been taken into custody and impounded, the police department shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written notice of such impoundment by mail to the Division of Marine Resources of the Department of Natural Resources, and shall file a copy of such notice with the person who has been authorized to have custody of the impounded vessel for the purpose of storage. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vessel, the date, time and place from which it was removed, the reason for such removal, and the name of the storage facility or place where the vessel is stored. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 5, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-36. - Same-Unclaimed vessel to be sold; certification of sale. 
(a)  If the owner fails to claim the vessel within ten (10) days after the police department has sent its notice to the Division of Marine Resources, such vessel shall be sold to the highest bidder at public auction by the police department at some place within the town; but, prior to the sale, a notice shall be published one (1) time in a local newspaper published in the county and circulated in the town. Publication shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the date of sale. Such notice shall give the time and place of sale and describe the vessel to be sold. A copy of such notice shall be mailed to the owner if his name and address be known at least ten (10) days before the date of such sale. The town shall not guarantee title to such vessel or to deliver a title of ownership, but shall furnish the purchaser a certificate in substantially the following form: 
Certificate Number: _____ CERTIFICATE OF SALE TOWN OF LANTANA, POLICE DEPARTMENT, LANTANA, FLORIDA  THIS IS TO CERTIFY that the following described vessel was impounded and placed in the custody of the Police Department, where it was held for twenty (20) days, after which time the Police Department made every reasonable effort to find the owner of the same or if found, such owner failed to repossess same, this vessel was sold to the highest bidder at public auction after legal advertisement.  This Certificate of Sale is therefor issued to: _____ residing at _____ Description of vessel: _____ Dated at Lantana, Florida, this______day of_________________19___. ___________ Name and Title of Police Officer  
(b)  This form shall be in duplicate. The original shall be given to the purchaser and the duplicate bound in a book of record for the purposes intended. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 6, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-37. - Same-Disposal of proceeds. 
    Proceeds of sale of the impounded vessel shall be deposited in the fines and forfeitures account after paying all the costs actually expended for towing, storage, advertising and sale of such vessel. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 7, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-38. - Same-Claiming of vessel by owner; payment of costs. 
    The owner of such impounded vessel may take possession of such vessel at anytime prior to the time of sale provided herein, but such owner shall reimburse the Town for all reasonable expenses for removal, storage, advertising and other expenses incurred as a result of the impoundment of such vessel. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 8, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-39. - Same-Reclamation of owner after sale. 
    The proceeds from the sale of any impounded vessel paid into the fine and forfeitures account shall not be expended or disbursed for ninety (90) days after the date of such sale. At any time during such period, the owner, upon providing proof of such ownership of such vessel, evidenced by documentary written evidence, may recover back from the fines and forfeitures account, the proceeds of the sale, less all the expenses incurred in regard to removal, storage, advertising and a commission of five (5) percent on the gross sales price of such vessel for the cost of making such sale. 
(Ord. No. O-15-87, § 9, 1O-26-87) 
Sec. 5-40. - Discharging excreta from toilet or similar facility, depositing refuse matter into waters of prohibited area. 
    It is declared to be unlawful for any person to discharge or permit, or allow any other person on a vessel under his control or command, to discharge any human or animal excreta from any head, toilet, or similar facility, or in any manner from any vessel, or throw, discharge, deposit or leave, or cause or permit to be thrown, discharged, deposited or left from any vessel any refuse matter of any description into the waters of the prohibited area. 
(Code 1962, § 16-45) 
Cross reference- Garbage and refuse disposal, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; nuisance, Ch. 12; offenses, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; sewers, § 21-36 et seq. 
Sec. 5-41. - Use of vessel for dwelling purposes in prohibited area. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy for dwelling purposes any vessel in the prohibited area except during the period covered by the mooring permit referred to in section 5-32. 
(Code 1962, § 16-46) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; nuisances, Ch. 12; offenses, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 5-42. - Certain net fishing prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take fish from the waters within the town by using any net larger than eight (8) feet in diameter. 
(Code 1962, § 16-47) 
Sec. 5-43. - Obstructing town boat ramp prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Obstruct free access to and from the boat ramp provided by the town on the south side of Ocean Avenue. 
(2)  Store on property of the town adjacent to the boat ramp provided by the town on the south side of Ocean Avenue any boat, trailer, automobile or other material. 
(b)  The word "store" as used in this section shall mean leaving any article mentioned on said premises for any period of time longer than is necessary to the user of said boat ramp for the purpose for which the same is provided, namely, to launch boats, take boats out of the lake, and while such boats are actually in the water, to leave the trailer and/or vehicle pulling the boat temporarily upon such area. 
(Code 1962, § 5-2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17. 
Secs. 5-44-5-50. - Reserved.

Sec. 5-51. - Bulkhead lines, map adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby located and fixed a bulkhead line, or lines, offshore from the existing lands and islands bordering on or being in Lake Worth, a navigable water in Palm Beach County, Florida, within the territorial area of the Town of Lantana and said bulkhead line or lines, shall be, and are hereby located and fixed along the line indicated and shown in the map or plat entitled "Bulkhead Line, Town of Lantana, Florida, October, 1956, Scale 1"-200", revised January 21, 1957, by MLR, redrawn February 12, 1957, by VMN, revised February 13, 1957, by ASW, and revised February 27, 1958, by ASW, and revised February 27, 1958, by ASW, and identified by the inscription "R-56-008" as amended on June 27, 1966 which are on file in the town clerk's office, which said map or plat is marked "Town of Lantana, Florida, Bulkhead Map, " referred to and made a part of this chapter as fully as if copied completely herein." 
(b)  From and after November 10, 1958, no creating or filling of lands or islands outward beyond said bulkhead line and into the waters of Lake Worth may be made or maintained. 
(Code 1962, § 26-1) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 5-52. - Buildings prohibited. 
    No building may be constructed or maintained outside or beyond the bulkhead line. 
(Code 1962, § 26-4) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; zoning, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 5-53. - Violations; removal of fill. 
(a)  Any fill outside the bulkhead line which shall be made or maintained contrary to this article shall be unlawful and the same shall be promptly removed upon order of the town council. 
(b)  Any person who violates this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided by section 1-12, and each day any such unlawful creation or fill of land or islands shall continue to exist shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1962, § 26-5)

Sec. 6-16. - Florida Building Code Incorporated by reference.
