ARTICLE XII. - CONSTRUCTION SITE AND STAGING STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - CONSTRUCTION SITES 

Sec. 6-241. - Screening standards. 
(a)  All construction sites whether residential or commercial shall be enclosed by a chain link fence, which is six (6) feet chain in height. 
(b)  The chain link fence must be covered with screening material that is ninety-five (95) percent opaque. The fence screening material may have small wind flaps. 
(c)  Screening material may either be black or green and must be made of a colorfast weatherproof material. 
(Ord. No. O-10-2019, § 1, 3-11-19) 
Sec. 6-242. - Site standards. 
(a)  In residential and mixed-use districts construction vehicles may not be stored on site overnight unless they are entirely screened from view by the screening fence. 
(b)  In commercial districts construction vehicles may be stored on site overnight on parcels that are one (1) or more acres in size, but are only required to be parked within the screened construction area. Commercial parcels that are less than one (1) acre in size must comply with the construction vehicle screening standards set forth in subsection (a), hereinabove. 
(c)  All construction and building materials must be fully screened from view, from the adjacent right-of-way, if they are to be stored overnight. 
(d)  Fill material may not be piled any higher than the top of the screening fence and must be covered or kept sufficiently moist to prevent dust and/or debris from being blown from the site. 
(e)  Construction debris shall be contained within an on-site dumpster. All construction dumpsters shall be emptied when full. A dumpster shall be deemed to be full once its contents are even with or protrude above the top of the dumpster at any point. 
(Ord. No. O-10-2019, § 1, 3-11-19) 
Secs. 6-243-6-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION STAGING (OFF-SITE) 

Sec. 6-251. - Permits required. 
(a)  Prior to utilizing any parcel as an off-site construction staging site, an application and site plan of the proposed staging site shall be submitted to the development services director for review. 
(b)  Staging sites are subject to the same regulations and requirements as construction sites. 
(c)  The development services director may impose additional conditions if deemed necessary and appropriate to mitigate the impact the proposed staging site may have on adjacent or nearby properties. 
(Ord. No. O-10-2019, § 1, 3-11-19) 
Chapter 7 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 12, 2001 completely repealed the provisions of §§ 7-2-7-7 of this article, replacing them with the similar provisions of §§ 7-2-7-6 as currently set out herein. Former §§ 7-2-7-7 derived from the Code of 1962, §§ 8-6.1, 8-9, 8-13(l), 8-15(a), (b); and Ord. No. O-15-88, §§ 1-3, adopted Sept. 12, 1988. 
Charter reference- Qualification and election, Art. V. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; town council, § 2-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Election Code, F.S. Chs. 97-106; uniform optional election dates for Palm Beach County, Laws of Fla. Ch. 83-498. 

Sec. 7-1. - Qualifications and selection of candidates; candidate vacancies. 
(a)  Any person who is a duly registered elector of the town may become a candidate for any elective office by presenting to the town clerk a petition subscribed by at least one (1) percent of the total registered electors of the town. Upon presenting such petition, the person shall be entitled to have his name placed upon the ballot for such office. Such petition may be filed with the town clerk no earlier than noon on the first Tuesday in January, nor later than noon on the third Tuesday in January of the calendar year in which the election is to be held. 
(b)  If there should be a vacancy in the pool of qualified candidates caused by death, withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period which leaves only one (1) candidate for office, that candidate shall be deemed automatically elected. Should there be a vacancy in candidacy caused by death, withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period which leaves no candidates for that particular office, the qualifying period shall be extended or re-opened for an additional week in order that additional candidates might have an opportunity to file for office. This extension is conditioned on there being sufficient time to extend the qualifying period and still meet the deadline established by the Palm Beach County Supervisor of Elections. If there is not sufficient time to extend the qualifying period, the town council shall cause to be held a special election for the purpose of filling the remaining seat(s) on the council. 
(Ord. No. O-15-88, § 1, 9-12-88; Ord. No. O-04-94, § 1, 1O-24-94; Ord. No. O-12-2008, § 1, 12-8-08; Ord. No. O-06-2015, § 2, 6-22-15; Ord. No. O-05-2017, § 2, 4-24-17) 
Sec. 7-2. - Resign-to-run requirements; designation of group. 
(a)  No councilmember may qualify as a candidate for election to the office of mayor if the councilmember's term or any part thereof runs concurrently with the office of the mayor unless that councilmember submits an irrevocable written resignation to the town clerk at least ten (10) days prior to the first day of qualifying for election to the office sought in accordance with the state statute informally known as the "resign to run" law set forth at F.S. Ch. 99. 
(b)  Each candidate seeking election to the council at the time of the qualifying for election shall designate the group seat for which he or she seeks election. 
(Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 7-3. - Date of annual municipal elections. 
    The annual election to fill the town council seats shall be held on the second Tuesday in March and runoff elections, if necessary, shall be held on the fourth Tuesday in March of the calendar year. If a special election is held as set forth in section 7-1 hereinabove or at article V, section 4 of the town Charter, such election must be coordinated with the supervisor of elections and shall be held on a date acceptable to said supervisor of elections. 
(Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 7-4. - Filing fee; candidate's oath. 
    In addition to submitting the petition required under section 7-1 above, each candidate seeking election to the council at the time of qualifying for election shall pay a filing fee, the amount of which is set by state law and must take and subscribe to a candidate's oath as required by state law. 
(Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 7-5. - Form of ballots; listing of candidates. 
    The town clerk shall list all qualified candidates names in alphabetical order and shall otherwise follow the mandates regarding the form of the ballot as prescribed by state election law. 
(Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 7-6. - Inspectors. 
(a)  The town clerk shall procure as many inspectors, clerks or deputies as are deemed necessary to conduct all general and special elections of the town. Such inspectors, clerks or deputies shall fulfill all requirements as set forth by general law. 
(b)  For each election held within the town, the inspectors, clerks or deputies shall be paid the same amount as their counterparts appointed by Palm Beach County. 
(Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 7-7. - Early voting exemption. 
    All general laws of the state relating to elections and to the registration of persons qualified to vote therein, which are not inconsistent or in conflict with the provisions of this chapter, are hereby adopted as part of this chapter; however, the town shall be exempt from the provisions of F.S. § 101.657, regarding early voting, as that section may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. O-18-04, § 1, 1-10-05) 
Chapter 7.5 - FINANCE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7.5-1. - Annual budget. 
    The town's annual budget shall be prepared in accordance with article IV, section 5, of the town's charter and applicable state law; and may be adopted by either resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-2. - General fund committed fund balance. 
    In accordance with the Governmental Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 54, Fund Balance Reporting and Governmental Fund Type Definitions, the Town's General Fund- Committed Fund Balance shall be maintained at an amount equal to 3.3 million dollars, except that such Committed Fund Balance amount may be modified by an ordinance of the Town Council. 
(Ord. No. O-04-2012, § 1, 3-12-12) 
Secs. 7.5-3-7.5-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURCHASING GUIDELINES 

Sec. 7.5-16. - Purpose; generally. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of these purchasing regulations is to: 
(1)  Provide a uniform means of acquiring goods and services in a manner which protects the interests of taxpayers; 
(2)  Ensure that qualified vendors have access to the municipal market on a fair and equitable basis; 
(3)  Apply the regulations to all purchases of the town irrespective of the source of funding; and 
(4)  Provide guidelines to user departments; 
(b)  Role of department heads. The town has a decentralized purchasing system, which empowers the department heads most familiar with their operations to acquire the goods and services they need, so long as the town council has appropriated adequate funds for the purchase. 
(c)  Finance department. The finance department serves as the purchasing gateway to provide assistance and technical expertise in purchasing procedures, and to ascertain that user departments understand and comply with established budgetary, purchasing and accounting procedures for overall internal control. No town employee shall order goods or services without the required authorization, funding, purchasing/finance documents and/or without complying with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-17. - Purchases of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) or more. 
    Purchases of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) or more require competitive bidding, except for the purchases provided for in section 7.5-30, Exempt Purchases and section 7.5-38 Professional Service Contracts, unless otherwise required by law. Purchase requisition must be approved prior to ordering. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-18. - Bid specifications. 
(a)  Preparation. The preparation of specifications is the responsibility of the user department. Specifications are important and are intended to promote competition among vendors. Specifications should be written in terms which define the performance required or the design of the goods/services, rather than using specific brand names. Specifications should be clear and concise, and they should provide complete and detailed descriptions of the item(s) and/or services(s) being solicited, including quantity of items and/or dates of contractual services. 
(b)  Additional information required. If the goods or services desired are outside the expertise of the department personnel and specifications cannot be prepared by the department, the department head may contact prospective bidders with a written request for information and request recommended solutions to provide town staff with an adequate understanding to prepare the specifications. Prospective bidders and town personnel are not permitted to discuss pricing during this process. 
(c)  Bid package contents. In addition to the specifications, the bid package must contain the specific instructions and information to potential bidders. The bid package must: 
(1)  State the time, date and place where bids will be received. 
(2)  State evaluation criteria and the time line that will be used to determine the best bidder. 
(3)  Provide standard bid language to address Public Entity Crimes Act; drug-free work place; and non-discrimination. 
(d)  Additional bid requirements. The bid package must inform potential bidder of the following requirements. Bid must: 
(1)  Be sealed. 
(2)  Have the bid number plainly marked on the outside of the envelope. 
(3)  Have the response due date and/or the time and date of the bid opening plainly marked on the outside of the envelope. 
(4)  State the date by which goods and services must be delivered. 
(5)  The user department shall assemble the specifications together with the bid instructions and forward the bid package to the town clerk for advertising. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-19. - Bid security. 
(a)  Definition. Bid security is a document, usually in an amount of five (5) percent of the bid, which guarantees that the bidder will enter into a contract with the town if he/she wins the award. Bid security protects the town from erroneous or deliberate low bids which the vendor has no intention of honoring or performing within the time frame specified. 
(b)  Requirement for same. Each bid, where so required in the bid documents, must be accompanied by a bid bond, a cashier's check or a certified bank check in an amount of not less than five (5) percent of the total bid amount. The applicable bid documents will specify the details of individual bid requirements. Unless otherwise stated in the bid documents, the bid security of the successful bidder will be retained by the finance director, until such bidder has executed and furnished to the town, an agreement and required contract security. Upon receipt of the executed agreement and contract security, the bid security will be returned. If the successful bidder fails to execute and deliver the agreement and fails to furnish the contract security within the time required by the bid documents, after the notice of award, the town may cancel the notice of award and the bid security of that bidder shall be forfeited. The bid security of other bidders whom the town believes to have a reasonable chance of receiving the award may be retained by the town until the time specified in the bid documents. Bid security for bids which are not competitive will be returned within seven (7) days after the bid opening. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-20. - Invitation to bid. 
    The affected department director or designee shall contact the finance director/town clerk, in writing, to obtain a bid number and verify that funds have been appropriated and are available. Upon verification, the finance director or designee shall forward the request to the town clerk for advertising. Unless otherwise approved by the town manager, in writing, the advertisement shall be placed in a newspaper of general circulation within the area and on the town's website. All advertisements shall provide a reasonable time for potential bidders to respond. Nothing herein shall prevent the town clerk or affected department head from directly sending an invitation to bid to known potential bidders. However, town officers and employees shall not disclose or use any information not available to the public for personal benefit of themselves or others. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
State Law reference- F.S. § 112.313(8). 
Sec. 7.5-21. - Bid opening. 
    Bid openings shall be conducted in public by the affected department director and the town clerk, or their designee(s), at the time and place stated in the advertisement. No bids will be accepted after the time and date designated. Bids received after the time and date designated shall be returned, unopened. This provision is not waivable. A tabulation of all bids and any accompanying bid materials submitted shall be made available to the public by the town clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-22. - Award of bid. 
(a)  Evaluation of bids. Bids shall be awarded by the town council to the "lowest responsive, responsible and most qualified bidder." In determining the bidder meeting such criteria, the following may be considered in addition to prices: 
(1)  The ability, capacity, and skill of the bidder to perform the contract. 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder. 
(4)  The quality of performance on previous public or private contracts of a similar type. 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to any contract. 
(6)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service. 
(7)  Tie bids. The tie may be broken and the successful vendor selected by the following criteria presented in order of importance and consideration: 
a.  Quality of the items or services if ascertainable. 
b.  Time of delivery if provided in the bid. 
c.  Location of the vendor with the following award preferences: 
1.  A Town of Lantana vendor. 
2.  A Palm Beach County vendor. 
3.  A Florida vendor. 
d.  If the above criteria are impossible to determine with any reasonableness or do not resolve the issue, the award will be given to that vendor whose bid was received first as indicated by the time stamp on the envelope containing the bid. 
(b)  Sole criteria. Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or correction, except as authorized in this chapter. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids, which may include additional criteria to determine suitability for a particular purpose. No criteria may be used in bid evaluation that are not set forth in this chapter or the invitation for bids. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-23. - Addition, correction, cancellation, or withdrawal of bids. 
(a)  Addition to bids. After bid opening, an otherwise low bidder shall not be permitted to delete exceptions to bid conditions or specifications which affect price or substantive obligations. However, such bidder shall be permitted to furnish other information requested by the town so long as it was called for by the invitation for bids and does not affect responsiveness as set forth below. 
(1)  Information required to determine the responsibility of the vendor. 
(2)  Information shall not be considered after the bid opening if such information was specifically requested in the invitation for bids or if it is determined that the omission of such information renders the bid unresponsive. The bid shall be considered responsive only if it substantially conforms to requirements of the invitation for bids as it relates to pricing, surety, insurance, specifications, and any other matter unequivocally stated in the invitation for bids as a determinant of responsiveness. A minor or non-substantive lack of conformity on these matters may be considered a technicality or irregularity which may be waived by the authority empowered to make the award. 
(b)  Correction on bids. 
(1)  Mathematical errors. Errors in extension of unit prices or mathematical calculations may be corrected by the finance director prior to award. The unit prices shall not be changed. 
(2)  Clerical errors. A bidder shall be permitted to correct clerical mistakes of fact in their bid. 
(3)  Voluntary reduction of price. The town may accept a voluntary reduction from a low bidder after bid opening, if such reduction is not conditioned on, nor results in, the modification or deletion of any condition contained in the invitation for bids. A voluntary reduction may not be used to ascertain the lowest responsive, responsible bidder. 
(c)  Cancellation of bids. 
(1)  Any time prior to bid opening date and time, the town may cancel or postpone the bid opening or cancel the invitation for bid in its entirety. 
(2)  After bids are open, any or all bids may be rejected by the town. 
(d)  Withdrawal of bids. 
(1)  Any bidder may voluntarily withdraw or amend his bid at any time prior to the bid opening by providing written notice to the town. Amendments should be forwarded to the town clerk, sealed and identified. 
(2)  After bid opening, vendors shall not be allowed to withdraw a bid in less than ninety (90) days, or such specific time period stated in the invitation to bid with the following exception: the bid is so outrageous as to be a prima facie evidence of a bid mistake, but a mistake that cannot be corrected by correction of mathematical computation. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-24. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
(a)  Bids shall include the following additional provisions: 
(1)  Public Entity Crimes Act. In accordance with the Public Entity Crimes Act contained in F.S. § 287.133, the town requires that vendors supplying goods or services in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more must acknowledge receipt of information about the law, and compliance with the statutory provisions. A public entity crime is a violation of law related to the transaction of business with any public entity involving antitrust, fraud, theft, bribery, collusion, racketeering, conspiracy, or material misrepresentation. 
(2)  Drug-free work place. The town is a drug-free work place and has adopted a substance abuse policy in accordance with and pursuant to F.S. § 440.102. In order to maintain a drug-free work place, the town requires that bidders furnishing services on site at town facilities abide by the policy and provide certification that the bidder and each subcontractor used by the bidder, on site, has implemented a drug-free work place program in compliance with F.S. § 287.087. 
(3)  Non-discrimination. The town is an equal opportunity employer and it is the town's policy to provide equal opportunity to all vendors consistent with the laws of the State of Florida. The town intends to prohibit illegal discrimination against any person or business in pursuit of these opportunities based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, age, or disability. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-25. - Purchases from five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and up to fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00); purchases over fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). 
    Purchases from five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) require the approval of the town manager or the finance director or their designee. Purchases from ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and up to fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) require the approval of the town manager and the finance director or the finance director's designee. Purchases over fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) require the approval of the town council either by inclusion in the adopted fiscal year budget, by resolution and budget transfer/amendment to appropriate the funds, or by specific approval at a regular or special town council meeting, with the exception of those items listed in section 7.5-30(a),(b) and (d)-(h). Items listed at section 7.5-30(c) "piggy-back bids", (i) "sole source" (j) "services involving special skill", (k) "legal services", and (l) "emergency purchases" are exempt from bidding but, must still be approved by the town council if over fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). The requesting department director or designee must have obtained three (3) written price quotations before proceeding with the approval process. After receiving town council approval, if required, the requesting department director or designee shall be responsible to follow the purchase order procedures contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-26. - Purchases from two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
    In addition to the requirements in section 7.5-28, below, purchases of two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) must have three (3) written price quotations and written authorization of the finance director in the form of a purchase order. The quotations must be forwarded to the finance department prior to approval of the purchase order. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-27. - Purchases from one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) and up to two thousand five hundred ($2,500.00). 
    In addition to the requirements in section 7.5-28, below, purchases of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) and up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) must have three (3) quotes, which may be verbal, and written authorization of the finance director in the form of a purchase order. Documentation of the phone number and the name of the person who provided the quote must be provided on the purchase requisition. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-28. - Purchases less than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
    Department directors have authorization to purchase goods and services which are less than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), for a single purchase, subject to a valid, current appropriation for the item(s) to be purchased. Payment for the goods and services shall be made using a purchase order, check request form or purchasing card for purchases less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); between one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), a purchase order will be utilized in order to procure goods and/or services, unless the item is a capital asset. All purchases of capital assets require a purchase order. The procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase. Detailed instructions for completing a check request form are found on Sample Form #1 available at the office of the finance director. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-29. - Capital outlay expenditures. 
    Notwithstanding any other requirements, exceptions, exemptions or limitations on purchases, each item purchased within the capital outlay expenditure category, including, but not limited to, land, buildings, improvements other than buildings, and machinery and equipment, shall require the use of a purchase order. 
    A capital/fixed asset is a durable item, with a long-term nature of use, a normal expected life of one year or more, and a value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more at the time of acquisition. Fixed assets include items of real and tangible personal property, of a non-consumable nature of the town. All fixed asset purchases require three (3) quotes. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-30. - Exempt purchases. 
    The following purchases do not require sealed bidding, or requests for proposals, due to the nature of the goods or service, but may require approval by the town council depending on the amount of the expenditure. These include, but are not limited to the following: 
(a)  Payment of utility bills for normal monthly service such as Florida Power & Light (electric), BellSouth, Inter-Tel, Nextel (phone service/lines), Lake Worth Utilities (wastewater treatment), Solid Waste Authority (solid waste disposal fees), and any other utility service. 
(b)  Payment of payroll related deductions or liabilities, such as FICA/Medicare, federal withholding taxes, pension or Prudential 457 Contributions, Palm Beach County Credit Union, US Savings Bonds, IRS and child support garnishment. 
(c)  Piggy-back bids. If the goods or services to be purchased have been approved by the town manager and the funds necessary to purchase the goods or services are available in the annual budget, the user department may "piggyback" any currently authorized public agency bid of any federal, state or municipal government entity or agency. Piggy-back contracts may also be used when such bid has been obtained by a government agency cooperative, whether national, regional, or local. The purchase order for these goods must refer to the current public agency bid number and the goods must have the same specifications as those in the bid documents. A copy of the contract must be provided to the finance department before the purchase order can be approved. 
(d)  Payment to service providers needed to maintain the town operations such as plumbers, electricians, temporary employment services, computer consultants, or air conditioning service. (This should only pertain to emergencies, not routine maintenance and does not include the replacement of major capital equipment or components). 
(e)  Payment of subscriptions, memberships, dues, and education, travel expenses. 
(f)  Payment of insurance billings, postage, and postage meter permits. 
(g)  Payment of authorized debt service. 
(h)  Payment of authorized donations, or scholarships 
(i)  Sole source. Goods or services when determined in writing by the using agency that there is only one (1) source or one (1) reasonable source for the required supply, service or construction. 
(j)  Services involving special skill, ability, training or expertise which are in their nature unique, original or creative. 
(k)  Legal services including paralegals, expert witnesses, appraisal services, investigative services, court reporters, etc. 
(l)  Repairs to vehicles, heavy equipment and trucks, where the cost of such repairs is less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and where the repair estimate is difficult to obtain due to the complexity of the circumstance. Therefore, by October 31st of each year, the vehicle maintenance division shall provide to the finance director three quotes for labor rates for each of the following categories: 
(1)  Vehicle repairs; 
(2)  Body repairs; 
(3)  Heavy equipment/trucks. 
Appropriate contact information such as name, address, phone number and point of contact, shall accompany each quote. 
(m)  Emergency purchases. It is recognized that not all situations or occurrences can be anticipated. Emergency situations may include, but are not limited to, imminent danger to life, safety, health and/or property or breakdowns of equipment that may cause serious curtailment of services to residents. Examples of these purchases are repairs such as for vehicles, broken water and sewer lines, water treatment plant equipment and hurricane or other disaster purchase during a declared disaster. Note that any department head who authorizes such an emergency purchase must seek oral or written approval from the town manager (only required during normal business hours), and must provide a written explanation of the emergency to the town manager as early as possible but not later than twenty-four (24) hours after the purchase together with a copy to the finance department. Town council approval or confirmation shall be required when the amount of the emergency purchase exceeds fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). 
Emergency purchasing procedures may not be implemented to procure goods and/or services needed to carry on what should be considered normal operations. Failure to anticipate normal operating needs shall not be confused with an emergency situation. Although other factors may result in the need for expedited purchasing, such are not considered bona fide emergencies. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07; Ord. No. O-05-2013, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 7.5-31. - Use of purchase orders. 
    A purchase order (PO) is the town's primary acquisition document, used to authorize vendors to deliver goods or to perform services as specified. The purchase order is prepared to communicate in writing to the vendor the quantity specifications, terms and agreed upon price for the goods or services to be provided and is required for the purchases of all goods or services costing one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more with the exception of those listed in section 7.5-30. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-32. - Purchase order requisitions. 
    A purchase order is obtained by completing a purchase order requisition. The price must be verified with the vendor and checked to see if the price includes shipping and handling. Once completed, it must be approved by the supervisor and department director and submitted to the finance department. The finance director or designee shall review all purchase requisitions on a regular basis as determined by the finance director for accuracy and compliance with the purchasing guidelines. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-33. - Purchase order distribution. 
    Purchase orders of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or less may be approved by the finance director or the town manager or their designees. Purchase orders over ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) require the approval of the finance director or his/her designee and the town manager. After obtaining the necessary authorizations, the purchase order is sent to the requesting department. Upon receipt of the hard copy of the signed purchase order, the requesting department is authorized to place the order for goods or services. Goods or services shall never be ordered prior to receipt of a purchase order authorizing the purchase. Once the purchase order is printed, the funds are encumbered until the purchase order is paid, liquidated or voided. 
A copy of the purchase order may be sent to the vendor as confirmation of the order including the quantity, description and agreed upon price. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2007, § 1, 8-13-07) 
Sec. 7.5-34. - Submission of a purchase order for payment. 
    The payment authorization information must be stamped on the invoice. The information must include the date the goods or services were received, the amount to be paid, the supervisor's signature, and the department head's signature. It is the responsibility of the department head to ensure that goods or services have been received, and the invoice correctly represents the town's obligation. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-35. - Partial payments; blanket purchase orders. 
    Partial payments may be made if approved by the finance director or designee. A blanket purchase order may be issued to vendors for repetitive purchases for a set period of time with a maximum amount that may not be exceeded. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-36. - Canceling purchase orders. 
    A copy of the purchase orders or blanket purchase orders not used must be returned to the finance department with an explanation for the non-use. If same are not returned to the finance department, the amount of the purchase order will remain encumbered (unavailable) until the end of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-37. - Check requests. 
    Check requests including vendor number, description of the goods or services and other relevant information may be used to process payments for goods or services under one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) (except capital assets) and exempt purchases as defined in section 7.5-30. 
    An original invoice(s), a copy of the written contract, travel request form, or petty cash reconciliation form with original receipts must be attached to the check request form. 
    The vendor supplying the goods or services must provide an original invoice with the company's name and business address, description of the goods or services, and the cost. When the work involves repairs, the invoice must be broken down by the cost of materials and labor. A sample check request and instructions are found on Sample Form #1 available at the office of the finance director. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-38. - Professional service contracts. 
    All contracts for professional services, except for engagement of the town attorney, must be reviewed by the town attorney and executed by the town manager, or the mayor following town council approval. The town clerk shall maintain an original copy of all contracts. The department making the acquisition will retain a copy of the contract and the first payment request submitted to the finance department must have a copy of the contract attached. Professional service contracts include, but are not limited to, contracts with engineers, attorneys, certified public accountants, architects, planners, actuaries, and maintenance contracts on equipment. 
    The town council engages the town attorney, town engineers, independent certified public accountants, bond counsel and other outside professionals such as planners or architects. These professionals may be engaged by using a request for proposal (RFP) or may be engaged because of their particular expertise in accordance with subsection 7.5-30(j) or (k). If utilizing the RFP process, it must contain specifications for the scope of services to be performed, the proposed time frame, and the qualifications necessary to perform those services. An RFP is used when pricing is not the primary factor used in making the award. Architects, engineers, landscape architects, survey and mapping services must be engaged in accordance with F.S. ch. 287.055, the "Consultants Competitive Negotiation Act" (CCNA). 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-39. - Travel request forms. 
    Travel request forms are required whenever an employee or department head is requesting overnight travel on business. The completed travel request form is attached to each check request as support, along with a copy of the registration invoice and brochure, documentation for the anticipated cost of hotel, rental car, parking, tolls and transportation, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-40. - Petty cash reimbursements. 
    Petty cash is used for minor out-of-pocket purchases up to an amount set by the town manager when waiting for a town check is not timely or cost effective. Petty cash may be used to reimburse employees for purchases of goods or other expenses for the town. All petty cash reimbursements require an original receipt and must be submitted in a timely manner. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-41. - Vendor request form. 
    Except for petty cash or emergency purchases, and regardless of the amount of the purchase, a vendor request form shall be completed before making a purchase for the town, to ensure that all the necessary information has been obtained. The vendor request form must be completed in full along with a W-9 form before the finance department adds the new vendor to the vendor master file. If a user department is notified that a vendor has changed its company name or remittance address, a vendor request form shall be completed with the new information and the existing vendor number. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-42. - Forms. 
    The sample forms, numbered 1 through 6, and all references to the sample forms are deemed to be administrative in nature, and may be amended, deleted, or new forms may be substituted or added at the direction of the town manager or the finance director. Any such amendments, deletions, substitutions or additions shall be noted on the forms with the date of the implementation. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-43. - Check signing and distribution. 
    All checks of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) or greater will require a second signature by the mayor or a member of the council. All vendor checks will be mailed out by the finance department. Vendors may also pick-up their checks from the finance department during regular operating hours. Checks will not be returned to the requesting department for distribution. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-44. - Unauthorized purchases. 
    An unauthorized purchase occurs when a town employee orders, buys, or attempts to buy any goods or services without abiding by the regulations contained in this chapter. This includes: 
(a)  Separating purchases to avoid the need for town council or town manager approval or to avoid obtaining bids/quotes or a purchase order. 
(b)  Committing the town to a purchase before receiving the authorized purchasing documents, or contracts have received final approval. 
(c)  Purchasing in violation of the state's ethics laws (Chap. 112, F.S.) or the CCNA (Chap 287.F.S.) 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Sec. 7.5-45. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  Generally. The appearance of a conflict can be as damaging as a real conflict of interest. All questions concerning conflicts of interest or gifts should be directed to the town manager or the finance director, as soon as they arise. Any employee actions or contacts with vendors or potential vendors, or the offer or acceptance of otherwise permissible gifts which a reasonable person would perceive as advancing personal interests, regardless of actual intent, can give rise to the appearance of impropriety. 
(b)  Insider information. Providing insider or privileged information to select vendors which may provide them an unfair advantage in the purchasing or bidding process, is prima facie evidence of a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Financial gain. 
(1)  It shall be unethical for any town employee to participate directly or indirectly in a procurement contract when the employee knows that: 
a.  The employee or any member of the employee's immediate family has a financial interest in the procurement contract; or 
b.  Any other person, business, or organization with whom the employee or any member of a employee's immediate is negotiating or has an arrangement concerning prospective employment is involved in the procurement contract; 
(2)  It shall be unethical for any person to offer, give, or agree to give any town employee, or for any town employee to solicit, demand, accept, or agree to accept from another person, a gratuity or an offer of employment in connection with any decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, request for ruling determination, or other particular matter, pertaining to any program requirement or a contract or subcontract, or to any solicitation or proposal. 
(Ord. No. O-05-06, § 1(Exh. A), 9-11-06) 
Secs. 7.5-46-7.5-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADDITIONAL HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION 

Sec. 7.5-55. - Additional homestead exemption for persons sixty-five (65) years and older. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Household means a person or group of persons living together in a room or group of rooms as a housing unit, but the term does not include persons boarding or renting a portion of a dwelling. See definition set forth at F.S. § 196.075(1)(a). 
    Household income means the adjusted gross income, as defined § 62 of the United States Internal Revenue Code, of all members of the household. See definition set forth at F.S. § 196.075(1)(b). 
(b)  General . 
(1)  Lantana taxes only. Pursuant to and in accordance with F.S. § 196.075, the additional homestead exemption as set forth in this section shall apply only to taxes levied by the Town of Lantana, including, if any, dependent special districts and municipal service taxing units. 
(2)  Amount of additional homestead exemption. Any person who meets the requirements set forth in subsection (c) hereinbelow, shall be eligible for an additional twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) homestead exemption. 
(c)  Requirements to obtain additional homestead exemption. Any person who has attained the age of sixty-five (65) years of age will be entitled to an additional homestead exemption if all of the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The person has legal or beneficial title in equity to real estate; and 
(2)  The person maintains thereon and in good faith makes the same his or her permanent residence or the permanent residence of another or others legally or naturally dependent upon such person. See F.S. § 196.031; and 
(3)  The person(s household income does not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) as adjusted hereinbelow; and 
(4)  The taxpayer claiming the exemption submits annually to the Palm Beach County Property Appraiser, not later than March 1, a sworn statement of household income on a form prescribed by the Florida Department of Revenue; and 
(5)  In accordance with rules of the Florida Department of Revenue, a statement is filed which is supported by copies of any federal income tax returns for the prior year, any wage and earnings statements (W-2 forms), and any other documents which the Florida Department of Revenue deems necessary, for each member of the household. Such documentation must be submitted by June 1 and the statement shall attest to the accuracy of such copies; and 
(6)  The property appraiser approves the exemption after being provided with all required documentation. 
(d)  Household income . For purposes of subsection (c)(3) above, the twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) household income limitation shall be adjusted annually, on January 1, by the percentage change in the average cost-of-living index in the period January 1 through December 31 of the immediate prior year compared with the same period for the year prior to that. The index is the average of the monthly consumer-price-index figures for the stated twelve-month period, relative to the United States as a whole, issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(e)  If title is held jointly with the right of survivorship, the person residing on the property and otherwise qualifying may receive the entire amount of the additional homestead exemption. 
(Ord. No. O-17-06, § 1, 11-13-06) 
Secs. 7.5-56-7.5-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INCLUSION OF TOWN'S BOUNDARIES INTO PALM BEACH COUNTY'S FIRE-RESCUE MUNICIPAL SERVICE TAXING UNIT ("MSTU") 

Sec. 7.5-61. - Ordinance No. O-15-2017. 
    Ordinance No. O-15-2017 adopted on November 27, 2017 provides for the inclusion of Town of Lantana's boundaries within the boundaries of the Fire/Rescue MSTU established by Palm Beach County for fire-rescue services pursuant to F.S. § 125.01(1)(q) under the authority of Section 9(b), Article VII of the State Constitution. Ordinance No. O-15-2017 is hereby included and incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth herein and shall be kept on file for review in the office of the town clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-10-2007, § 2, 8-27-07; Ord. No. O-15-2017, § 1, 2, 5, 11-27-17) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. O-15-2017, adopted Nov. 27, 2017, provides that section shall take effect on January 1, 2018 provided that the Board of County Commissioners of Palm Beach County has adopted an ordinance providing for the inclusion of the territorial limits of the Town within the County's Fire/Rescue MSTU. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. O-15-2017, adopted Nov. 27, 2017, provides that it is the intent, purpose and effect of this section to comply with the provisions of F.S. § 125.01(1)(q). All of the territory within the incorporated municipal boundaries of the town, to include any parcels of land annexed into the town in the future during the effective term of this section, shall be included within the county's fire rescue municipal service taxing unit (the "Fire/Rescue MSTU") for the purpose of providing fire-rescue services within the territorial limits of the town. The town expressly consents to have all property currently located within its corporate boundaries (or annexed into its corporate boundaries during the ten (10) year term provided by this section) to be included in the fire/rescue MSTU for a term of ten (10) years unless this section is repealed earlier as set forth below. This section shall expire on December 31, 2027, except that it may be repealed earlier by the town council by providing notice in writing to Palm Beach County, by March 1 of any given year, of the town's intent to repeal the ordinance with such repeal to be effective December 31 of that year. Therefore, the notice of its intent to repeal the section and terminate the inclusion of the town in the county's Fire/Rescue MSTU will occur at least ten (10) months prior to such repeal becoming effective.

ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-51. - Purpose. 
    To provide the town with rules and regulations to improve public safety by promoting the control of fire hazards, regulating the installation, use, and maintenance of equipment, regulating the use of structures, premises, and open areas; providing for the abatement of fire hazards; establishing the responsibilities and procedures for code enforcement and setting forth the standards for compliance and achievement of these objectives. 
(Code 1962, § 11-11) 
Sec. 8-52. - Conflicting ordinances. 
(a)  This article shall supersede all conflicting fire codes or fire rules and regulations which have been adopted by the town to this end; all such conflicting fire codes and rules and regulations are hereby repealed. However, nothing herein shall be construed to alter any time limit which may have been imposed by any existing law, regulation or order of the fire marshal relating to compliance with such limits. 
(b)  This article is intended to be used in conjunction with existing laws and nothing in this article shall be construed as rendering other applicable laws invalid. In any situation where a conflict exists between a provision of this article and any existing law, the more stringent requirement shall prevail. This section does not authorize the continuation of existing fire codes, rules or regulations adopted by the town. 
(Code 1962, § 11-26) 
Secs. 8-53-8-65. - Reserved.

Sec. 8-76. - Florida Fire Prevention Code incorporated by reference; Palm Beach County local amendments adopted; 
(a)  The Florida Fire Prevention Code, including the Life Safety Code, Pamphlet 101, by reference, as adopted by the state fire marshal and the state legislature pursuant to F.S. §§ 633.0215 and 633.025, is hereby incorporated by reference as the Fire Prevention and Life Safety Code for the Town of Lantana. The Palm Beach County local amendments to the Florida Fire Prevention Code, as may be amended from time to time by the county, including the board of appeals and adjustment established therein, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by referenced. The Florida Fire Prevention Code as amended by the Palm Beach County local amendments shall be hereinafter referred to as "this code" or the "fire prevention code." 
(b)  Not less than one (1) copy of the current edition of the Florida Fire Prevention Code specifically referenced above, including the Palm Beach County local amendments, shall be on file at the office of the fire department. The provisions of this code shall be controlling within the town, save and except those portions such as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended by other sections of this chapter. 
(c)  The town may administer and enforce this code by means of its own fire department or by entering into a contract with another entity which is able to provide fire prevention and related services.

The fee schedule for plan review, permits, inspections, etc. shall be set by Palm Beach County with whom the town has entered into an agreement for fire rescue and related services. All town-owned property shall be exempt from all fees including, but not limited to, fire inspection, plan review, and/or permit fees. 
(Code 1962, § 11-13; Ord. No. O-01-99, § 2, 1-25-99; Ord. No. O-02-05, § 2, 3-28-05)

Chapter 8.5 - FRANCHISE REGULATIONS

ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-93, § 1, adopted 11-22-93 amended the Code by adding new provisions as Ch. 8.5, Art. I, § 8.5-1. In order to better conform to the organization of the Code, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. O-09-93 as Ch. 8.5, Art. II, § 8.5-16. 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, § 11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 8.5-16. - Rate regulation. 
(a)  Any rate or charge established for cable television service, equipment, repair and installation shall be reasonable to the public. In determining whether a rate or charge is reasonable, the town shall apply the cable television rate regulation criteria established by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). 
(b)  Should a franchisee desire to change any rate or charge, it shall submit a written proposal for the amounts and effective date of such change to the town manager who shall evaluate the proposal in a manner consistent with FCC cable television rate regulation standards and report this evaluation to the town council at a duly noticed public hearing. The town will provide written notice of the public hearing to the franchisee no later than seventy-two (72) hours prior to the public hearing. The town may require the franchisee to notify each subscriber, in writing and/or via the cable system of the proposed rate change and the date and time of the public hearing. At such hearing, the cable operator and members of the public will be given an opportunity to present their respective views on the proposed rates. Upon conclusion of the public hearing, the town council shall decide the matter by majority vote and adopt a resolution approving, disapproving or modifying the proposed rate changes and providing such further relief as is appropriate and authorized by FCC rate regulation standards. The resolution shall set forth complete findings of fact and conclusions regarding all of the basic elements considered in the town council's determination. 
(Ord. No. O-09-93, § 1, 11-22-93) 
Sec. 8.5-17. - Franchise adoption; renewals. 
    The franchise agreement between the Town of Lantana, Florida and Comcast Cablevision of West Palm Beach, Inc. is hereby adopted and included in this Code by reference. The entire franchise agreement which consists of eighteen (18) pages, is attached to the adopting Ordinance No. O-08-98 as Exhibit "A" and shall be kept on file at the office of the town clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-08-98, § 1, 8-24-98)
