Chapter 9 - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-01-2013, adopted Jan. 28, 2013, repealed Ch. 9, Arts. I, II, §§ 9-1, 9-16-9-25, 9-36-9-42, 9-56-9-62 and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Ch. 9 pertained to "Garbage and Refuse Disposal." See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement, § 2-46; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; discharging of certain matter into the water prohibited, § 5-33; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 11; nuisances, Ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; subdivision and platting regulations, Ch. 17.5; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20, utilities, Ch. 21, zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Resource recovery and management, F.S. Ch. 403, Part IV; public health, F.S. Ch. 381. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Authority means the Solid Waste Authority of Palm Beach County. 
(b)  Biohazardous or biomedical wastes means any waste which may cause disease or reasonably be suspected of harboring pathogenic organisms, including waste resulting from the operation of medical clinics, hospitals, and other facilities processing waste that may consist of, but are not limited to, human and animal parts, contaminated bandages, pathological specimens, hypodermic needles, sharps, contaminated clothing, and surgical gloves. 
(c)  Bulk trash means any non-vegetative item which cannot be containerized, bagged, or bundled; including, but not limited to, inoperative and discarded refrigerators, ranges, toilets, pool heaters, water softeners, pianos, washers, dryers, bath tubs, water heaters, sinks, bicycles, and other similar domestic appliances, household goods and furniture. Bulk trash shall not be commingled with vegetative waste. 
(d)  Collection means the process whereby solid waste (garbage, trash, bulk trash), vegetative waste or recyclable material is removed and transported to a designated facility. 
(e)  Compactor means any compaction mechanism, whether stationary or mobile. 
(f)  Commercial solid waste shall mean any all solid waste that is not defined as residential solid waste. 
(g)  Construction and demolition debris (C&D) means materials generally considered to be not water soluble and non-hazardous in nature, including, but no[t] limited to, steel, glass, brick, concrete, roofing material, pipe, gypsum wallboard, and lumber from the construction or destruction of a structure as part of a construction or demolition project. 
(h)  Container means any container intended for collection. 
(i)  Containerized residential recycling collection service means the collection of recyclable materials by the contractor from dwelling units in the service area that require the use of containers for the collection of recyclable materials, which also receives residential containerized solid waste collection service, and the delivery of those recyclable materials to the materials recycling facility. 
(j)  Containerized residential solid waste collection service means solid waste collection service of all dwelling units whose garbage, trash, or bulk trash waste is collected by means of a central or shared container (with or without compactor) and not by means of a garbage can. Vegetative waste shall not be commingled with garbage, trash or bulk trash. 
(k)  Contract means this agreement. 
(l)  Contractor means that person or entity set out initially above that has entered into this agreement to provide the services described herein. 
(m)  Contract administrator means the person designated by the town who shall act as the town's representative during the term of this agreement. This person shall be the operations director, unless otherwise designated in writing by the town manager. 
(n)  Contractor-generated waste means bulk trash and/or yard trash generated by builders, building contractors, privately employed tree trimmers and tree surgeons, landscape services, law[n] or yard maintenance services, and nurseries. 
(o)  County means Palm Beach County. 
(p)  Curbside residential recycling collection service means the collection of recyclable materials by the contractor from all residential dwelling units in the town's service area who receive curbside residential solid waste collection service. This service also includes the delivery of those recyclable materials to a designated facility. 
(q)  Designated facility means the facility or facilities operated by or licensed by the Solid Waste Authority of Palm Beach County for disposal of solid waste, vegetative waste and recyclable materials. 
(r)  Dwelling unit means any type of structure or building unit intended for or capable of being utilized for residential living other than a licensed hotel or motel unit (as defined by Florida Statute or Florida Administrative Code). 
(s)  Fiscal year means the period between October 1 of a given year and September 30 of the following year during this contract. 
(t)  Garbage means all putrescible waste which generally includes, but is not limited to, kitchen and table food waste, animal, vegetative, food or any organic waste that is attendant with or results from the storage, preparation, cooking or handling of food materials whether attributed to residential or commercial activities. Vegetative waste shall not be commingled with garbage in the same collection vehicle. Garbage shall not include any material that falls within the definition of special waste. 
(u)  Garbage can means any commonly available light gauge steel, plastic, or galvanized receptacle of a non-absorbent material, closed at one end and open at the other, optionally furnished with a closely fitted top or lid and handle(s). A garbage can is also defined as a heavy duty, securely tied, plastic bag designed for use as a garbage receptacle. Such container including waste materials shall not exceed fifty (50) gallons in capacity or fifty (50) pounds in weight. This can or bag is used for curbside pickup. A garbage can is also defined as a rollout cart which may be used in the future within the town for curbside service. This cart may be approximately thirty-three (33), sixty-five (65) or ninety-five (95) gallons. A cardboard box may also be used as a garbage can, provided the contents do not contain a level of moisture so as to saturate the box and weaken its walls. 
(v)  Hazardous waste means solid waste as defined by the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation as a hazardous waste in the State of Florida Administrative Code, or by any future legislative action or by federal, state or local law. 
(w)  Hotel or motel means a structure or building unit(s) capable of being utilized for residential living where such a unit or a group of such units is regularly rented to transients or held out or advertised to the public as a place regularly rented to transients for periods of seven (7) days or less. To meet this definition, the hotel or motel must be licensed to operate as such. "Transient" has the meaning as defined in F.S. Ch. 509, or its successor law. 
(x)  Materials recycling facility (MRF) shall mean any facilities operated or managed by, for or on behalf of the authority for the purpose of receiving, sorting, processing, storing, and/or preparing recyclable materials for sale. 
(y)  Mixed paper shall be mean a mixture of paper products including magazines, catalogues, phone books, cereal boxes, soda and beer can boxes, chipboard, file folders, envelopes, letter paper, junk mail, notebook paper and any other clean paper products. 
(z)  Public awareness program shall mean that program developed by the Town to inform and encourage residential and commercial solid waste collection customers to use all solid waste and recycling collection services offered by the town through the contract. It shall also mean information concerning level of service and changes in scope of service. 
(aa)  Recyclable materials shall mean newspapers (including inserts), aluminum, plastic containers, glass bottles and jars, milk and juice cartons, aseptic containers, corrugated cardboard, brown paper bags, mixed paper, tin and ferrous cans, household dry-cell batteries (no wet-cell batteries), and other solid waste materials added by the authority, when such materials have been either diverted from the remaining solid waste stream or removed prior to their entry into the remaining solid waste stream. 
(bb)  Recycling container shall mean a rigid container made of plastic or other suitable substance that is used for the storage of recyclable materials. 
(cc)  Residential recycling collection service shall mean curbside residential recycling collection services and containerized residential recycling collection service. 
(dd)  Residential solid waste shall mean garbage, trash and bulk trash resulting from the normal housekeeping activities of a dwelling unit, but shall not include vegetative waste. Residential solid waste shall also mean construction and demolition debris (C&D) resulting from minor home repair from the dwelling unit. 
(ee)  Residential solid waste collection service shall mean curbside residential solid waste collection service and/or containerized residential solid waste collection service. 
(ff)  Roll-off collection service shall mean the collection of C&D only roll-off containers, or the collection of C&D by other mechanical means, within temporary locations in the service area, limited to new construction sites and remodeling or refurbishment sites. Roll-off collection service shall also mean the collection of horticultural or agricultural wastes at horticultural or agricultural nurseries, but only when the customer chooses to use roll-off containers for horticultural or agricultural waste, and horticultural and agricultural waste shall not include any other type of waste, including, but not limited to, special waste, garbage or recyclable material. 
(gg)  Service area shall mean that portion of the incorporated area of the town as described in the town map provided, for which the contractor has been granted an exclusive franchise. 
(hh)  Sludge shall mean a solid or semi-solid, or liquid generated from any waste water treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, air pollution control facility, septic tank, grease trap, portable toilets and related operations, or any other such waste having similar characteristics or effects. 
(ii)  Special services shall mean any services requested or required by the customer that are in addition to, or a change in, residential solid waste collection service, residential recycling collection service as set out or similar to those listed in the request for proposal. 
(jj)  Special waste shall include automobiles, boats, internal combustion engines, non-automobile tires, sludge, dead animals, septic tank waste, biohazardous or biomedical waste, liquid waste, and hazardous waste. Special waste may also include items determined by the contract administrator to be reasonably unmanageable. 
(kk)  Trash shall mean all refuse, accumulation of paper, rags, wooden or paper boxes and containers, sweepings, broken toys, tools, utensils, and all other accumulations of a similar nature other than garbage, which are usual to housekeeping and to the operation of stores, offices and other business places, but shall not include vegetative waste. 
(ll)  Uncontrollable forces shall mean any event which results in the prevention or delay of performance by a party of its obligations under this agreement and which is beyond the reasonable control of the non-performing party. It includes, but is not limited to fire, flood, hurricanes, earthquakes, storms, lightning, epidemic, war, riot, civil disturbance, sabotage, and governmental actions. 
(mm)  Vegetative waste shall mean any vegetative matter resulting from yard and landscaping maintenance by any party and shall include materials such as tree and shrub materials, grass clippings, palm fronds, tree branches and similar other matter usually produced as refuse in the care of lawns, landscaping and yards. All grass clippings, leaves, pine needles, and similar small loose items must be bagged or containerized. Vegetative waste, except palm fronds, must be no more than six (6) feet in length and no single item shall weigh more than fifty (50) pounds, and shall be placed neatly at the curb. Natural Christmas trees will be collected as vegetative waste and must not be more than eight (8) feet in length and must be less than fifty (50) pounds. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Secs. 9-2-9-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-10. - Collection and disposal-Generally. 
(a)  Requirements during construction. Prior to the issuance of a building permit by the town building official for the renovation or modification of a structure, or the construction of a new structure, provisions must be made for the on-site storage and handling of all refuse, including C&D. Such arrangement shall provide free access to containers by mechanized equipment at all times. 
(b)  Responsibility for removal of construction and demolition debris. Builders, building contractors and construction tradesman shall be responsible for removing from the site all excavation, C&D wastes as defined in section 9-1 emanating from their work and shall use vehicles designed or outfitted so as to prevent the wastes carried therein from being blown, dropped or spilled from said vehicle. 
(c)  Responsibility for removal of waste by producer. It shall be unlawful for any person upon vacating or moving from any dwelling, storeroom or any other building situated within the corporate limits to fail to remove all waste material, regardless of type, garbage, and trash from such building and premise and grounds appurtenant thereto or to fail to place said waste in an approved sanitary container for disposal in accordance herewith. Failure of a renter, lessee, and/or tenant to comply with this requirement shall obligate the property owner of record or his designee to fulfill the responsibility of compliance with this article. 
(d)  Transportation over town streets. All collectors of all refuse desiring to haul over the streets of the town may do so provided they use vehicles designed or outfitted so as to prevent the refuse carried therein from being blown, dropped or spilled from said vehicle. Garbage shall be transported in watertight containers or in a vehicle provided with a tight-fitting cover and constructed so as to prevent offensive odors from escaping therefrom. 
(e)  Franchise license required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the business of collecting and transporting garbage, refuse or waste through or over the streets or alleys of the town without first having obtained a franchise license from the town, whether such franchise license be exclusive or non-exclusive. 
(f)  License application. An applicant for such franchise license shall provide the information as required on the application form and shall pay a franchise license fee as set forth by resolution of the town council, if such franchise is non-exclusive and shall pay a franchise fee as set forth in the franchise agreement if such franchise is exclusive. 
(g)  Insurance. No franchise license shall be issued to an applicant until a certificate of liability insurance coverage is first filed with the town. All applicants shall provide liability coverage for each vehicle to be used in the collection process by providing a general comprehensive liability policy in an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or the equivalent thereof. Such policy/policies shall remain in effect during the life of the franchise license. 
(h)  Tree trimmers, etc. Privately employed tree trimmers, tree surgeons, landscape contractors and operators of tree and shrubbery maintenance services shall remove all vegetative waste from the premises upon which they are working, including but not limited to limbs, tree trunks, roots, shrubbery clippings and other debris resulting from or incidental to their work. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-11. - Illegal disposal of garbage, etc. 
    No person shall deposit on or bury in, or cause to be deposited on or buried in, any land, public square, street, alley, sidewalk, bridge, easement, or other public passageway, or right-of-way, or any storm sewer, vacant or unoccupied lot, or any lake, canal, creek or watercourse, any noxious, filthy, malodorous or offensive liquid or solid materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish, or place or keep materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish anywhere within the limits of the town in any vessel or receptacle other than in an approved refuse container which is collected regularly. The county public health officer may, however, approve the burial of such garbage, refuse or rubbish, such approval to be in writing and to contain the conditions and restrictions with respect thereto including the place of burial. Nothing in this provision shall prohibit private, backyard, nuisance-free composting practices for home gardening purposes. No person shall burn or cause to be burned any refuse or waste anywhere within the town limits, except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-12. - Special waste prohibitions. 
    Hazardous wastes, biohazardous or biomedical wastes, sludge, and/or special waste, shall not be placed in garbage cans, bags, or dumpsters for collection by the town or its franchisee(s). 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-13. - Ownership of collection refuse and waste. 
(a)  Ownership of refuse and waste material shall be vested in the town or the properly licensed franchisee at the time of collection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized to do so to open, remove, untie, or to interfere with the orderly and legitimate collection of any refuse container or to collect, disturb or scatter refuse stored in containers placed for collection and disposal. 
(c)  Should the town provide for a separate collection time for newspaper, newspaper/grade papers and/or other materials for collection and recycling, such materials shall become and be the property of the town or its franchisee from the time of placement at the curb by any resident and it shall be a violation of this article for any person, firm, corporation, or partnership other than the town, or any of its agents, servants, employees, or duly authorized franchisees/contractors, to tamper with or to take or remove or to convert to its own use in any way such material except as set forth herein below. Each such collection in violation hereof from one (1) or more residences or businesses during such period shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-14. - Container/dumpster requirements. 
    All containers/dumpsters shall be completely enclosed by walls and/or appropriate fencing such that the height of the enclosure exceeds the height of the dumpster by at least twelve (12) inches and such that the container/dumpster shall be completely screened from view on at least three (3) sides with the fourth side of the enclosure composed of material having no less than fifty (50) percent opacity, which must contain the gate for access to the subject container/dumpster. All containers/dumpsters shall be set on a concrete slab, four (4) inches thick or other impervious prepared surface. No dumpster enclosure shall have dimensions less than eight (8) feet by ten (10) feet. All containers/dumpsters shall be kept in a sanitary, odor-free condition, so as not to cause a public health problem or nuisance. Additionally, if a commercial establishment is utilizing containerized service which requires four (4) or more containers, regardless of size, such containers shall be subject to the enclosure requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-15. - Administrative powers and duties. 
(a)  All residential garbage, recycling and trash shall be collected and disposed under the supervision of the town manager or designee. 
(b)  The town manager or designee shall coordinate with the town's exclusive franchise collector in order to periodically update collection schedules for trash, recycling and garbage collection designating collection times. When schedule changes are made, reasonable public notice of said changes shall be given to the occupants of each dwelling unit affected thereby. 
(c)  Where strict application of this article is impossible or would create an undue hardship, the town council may authorize a variance from the strict application of this article. 
(d)  The town manager or designee shall have the authority to enter upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of making reasonable inspections at reasonable times to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-16. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect, or refuse to comply with and abide by each provision of this chapter. The performance on each day of any prohibited act or practice shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Secs. 9-17-9-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION 

Sec. 9-20. - Mandatory service. 
    Every dwelling unit within the town, as defined in this article, shall subscribe for residential solid waste, vegetative waste, and recycling disposal and collection services from the town or its exclusive franchisee. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-21. - Waste removal fees established by town council. 
    The fees for waste removal and recycling service shall be established by the town council. The fees for waste removal and recycling service may be collected by any legal means available to the town and specifically may be included in the month[ly] utility bill or collected as a special non-ad valorem assessment on each parcel's property tax bill. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-22. - Residential collection-Exclusive to town or town's franchise collector. 
(a)  Selection of collector. The collector for all residential solid waste, vegetative waste, and recyclables shall be selected through a competitive bid/proposal process unless the town determines it is in the best interest of the citizens for the town to act as the collector. The terms and length of the franchise agreement must be approved by the town council. 
(b)  Franchise agreement term. The term of the franchise agreement may be extended if it clearly is in the best interest of the residents to do so even if no provisions for term extension have been provided for in the agreement or if those provided have previously been utilized. 
(c)  Exclusive franchise. The collector shall be granted an exclusive franchise to provide residential refuse and recyclable materials collection in the town in accordance with the regulations adopted by the town. 
(d)  Responsibilities of collector. 
(1)  The collector shall be an independent contractor and shall provide, at its own expense, all labor, insurance, supervision, machinery and equipment, plant building, trucks and any other tools, equipment, accessories and other items necessary to maintain a high standard of collection and disposal service, unless the town decides to act as collector itself. 
(2)  It is the responsibility of the collector to become familiar with and to determine itself, the nature and conditions affecting collection of refuse, recyclable materials and bulk waste in the town and the disposal of same. The collector shall comply with the requirements of the Florida Solid Waste Management Act and other applicable federal and state and town laws and/or ordinances, and shall be responsible for determining the impact of such legislation on its operations. 
(e)  Property damage. The collector shall conduct work in such a manner as to avoid damage to adjacent private or public property and shall immediately repair or pay for any damage incurred through its operation. The collector shall take whatever steps necessary to become fully informed as to the location of all existing utilities and shall operate with due care in the vicinity of utilities to avoid damage caused by its operation. 
(f)  Litter or spillage. The collector shall not litter or cause any spillage to occur upon the premises or the right-of-way wherein the collection shall occur. The collector may refuse to collect any residential solid waste or vegetative waste that has not been placed in a receptacle and/or prepared for collection, as provided herein. During hauling, all residential solid waste or vegetative waste shall be contained, tied or enclosed so that leaking, spilling and blowing are prevented. In the event of any spillage caused by the collector, the collector shall promptly clean up all spillage. 
(g)  Disposal of refuse. All residential solid waste and vegetative waste shall be hauled to a landfill or to another permitted site or facility as directed in writing by the town manager or designee and disposed of at those facilities at the expense of the collector. 
(h)  Collector's supervisory personnel. Collector's supervisory personnel must be present on the routes to direct operations in a satisfactory manner. Said supervisor(s) must be available for consultation with the town manager and/or customers within a reasonable, practicable time after notification of a request for such consultation. The supervisor(s) shall operate a vehicle which is radio equipped. 
(i)  Conduct of employees. The collector shall assure that employees serve the public in a courteous and helpful manner. Care shall be taken to prevent damage to property including all enclosures, trees, shrubs, flowers and other plants. 
(j)  Employee uniform regulations. The collector's solid waste collection employees shall wear a uniform or shirt bearing the collector's name. 
(k)  Compliance with state, federal and municipal law. The collector shall comply with all applicable town, state and federal laws relating to wages, hours and all other applicable law relating to employment or protection of employees, now or hereafter in effect. 
(l)  Fair Labor Standards Act. The collector is required and hereby agrees to pay all employees not less than the federal minimum wage and to abide by other requirements as established by the Congress of the United States in the Fair Labor Standards Act as amended and changed from time to time. 
(m)  Dangerous animals. Employees of the collector shall not be required to expose themselves to the danger of being bitten or attacked by vicious dogs or any other vicious animal in order to collect refuse. In any case where the owner(s) or tenant(s) have such animals at large, the collector shall immediately notify town code enforcement of such condition. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-23. - Collection and placement. 
(a)  Garbage. All residential garbage will be collected under the following conditions: 
(1)  Garbage must be placed in the designated containers provided by the town or town's franchisee according to solid waste authority regulations. Garbage will be collected at curbside from residential units unless containers/dumpsters are used. Containers must be within one (1) foot from curbside of the paved road. All containers shall be located at a minimum of five (5) feet from any obstruction that may interfere with routine collection. 
(2)  No garbage can or bag shall be placed in view of any person using a public street anywhere in the town prior to 6:00 p.m. on the day before collection nor later than 7:00 a.m. of the day collection is scheduled. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner or occupant to remove garbage cans from the collection point on the same day collection is made. 
(3)  All residential trash shall be bagged and placed in approved containers and deposited at curbside for collection on the appropriate days according to the town schedule. No recycling, yard or garden waste may be placed out for collection with garbage. 
(b)  Vegetative waste. 
(1)  Vegetative waste shall be collected according to a schedule established by the town manager or designee; however, such waste shall be collected at least twice each month. 
(2)  Vegetative waste shall be placed for collection in the swale or parkway immediately in front of the premises producing such wastes, but not upon the paved street or sidewalk. Vegetative waste shall be separated by at least ten (10) feet from garbage when placed out for collection. No yard or garden waste shall be placed in view of any person using a public street anywhere in the town earlier than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the day collection for that location in the town is scheduled. Persons placing waste for collection in violation of this section shall incur a special pick up fee which shall be charged by the town or its franchisee in accordance with the town's franchise agreement, as applicable. 
(3)  No vegetative waste shall be placed for collection against or within ten (10) feet of any wall, fence, vehicle, electric pole, downguys, utility lines, traffic control or telephone interface junction panel, water valve box, manhole, tree, or any other obstruction so as to impede collection. 
(4)  No residential solid waste, as defined in this chapter, shall be placed for collection with vegetative waste; any garbage container put in the same pile as vegetative waste shall be treated as garbage and disposed of accordingly. 
(5)  Vegetative waste placed for pickup in violation of any section of this chapter, including contaminated vegetative waste piles, shall be tagged with written notice stating that the occupant of the premises must remove same within twenty-four (24) hours; if the occupant fails to timely remove the vegetative waste, the town or the town's franchisee, as applicable, will pick up this accumulation which is in violation of this article and the occupant will be charged for a special pickup. 
(6)  The amount of bagged grass, leaves, and other vegetative waste placed for collection at any individual address shall not exceed the limits, if any, set forth in the town's franchise agreement. Piles of vegetative waste must be separated by ten (10) feet. Any pile exceeding the limits, if any, set forth in the town's franchise agreement will be removed by special pickup in accordance with same. 
(c)  Bulk trash. 
(1)  Bulk trash shall be on the same day as one of the collection days for regular garbage collection. Should the item be too large to collect during normal collection, the town or the town's franchisee, as applicable, shall tag the item and have it removed by special pickup in accordance with the terms [of the] town's franchise agreement as applicable. This service shall be provided at no additional charge to the customer. However, in no case shall the collector be responsible for or be required to remove construction waste that has [been] generated or deposited by construction firms or their activity or by landscape maintenance companies or their activity. 
(2)  No refrigerator or freezer shall be placed for collection without removal of its door. 
(d)  State of emergency. If a state of emergency has been declared by a person authorized to make such declaration, residential solid waste and vegetative waste collection shall be made in accordance with the emergency plans of the town, or as authorized by the town manager or his designee. 
(e)  Recyclables. Recyclables shall be placed in the designated bins provided by the town or town's franchisee according to solid waste authority regulations. 
(1)  Recyclables will be collected at curbside from residential units. All bins must be no further than five (5) feet from the edge of paved road. Maximum total weight per container shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. Any recycle bin exceeding fifty (50) pounds will not be emptied. No recycle bin shall be placed for collection within five (5) feet of any obstruction which may interfere with routine collection. 
(2)  Recycle bins shall not be placed in public view anywhere in the town prior to 6:00 p.m. the day before collection and must be removed from public view no later than 7:00 a.m. the day following collection. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner and/or occupant to remove all recycle bins from public view on the same day collection is made. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13; Ord. No. O-07-2013, § 1, 6-10-13; Ord. No. O-11-2018, § 1, 1-14-19) 
Sec. 9-24. - Storage and accumulation of garbage, trash and other waste. 
(a)  Public places. No residential solid waste, recyclable material and/or vegetative waste shall be stored in any public place at any time. No residential solid waste, recyclable material and/or vegetative waste shall be stored upon any private property other than that owned or occupied by the individual, except with the written consent of the owner or occupant. 
(b)  Location of residential garbage or trash container. No residential garbage, trash, and/or recyclable material container shall be placed or maintained upon or adjacent to any street, sidewalk, parkway, front yard, side yard or other place within the reasonable view of persons using the public streets or sidewalks, except as allowed by this article for the purposes of collection thereof. Underground containers are prohibited and may not be utilized for waste removal. On days other than pick-up days, all garbage, trash, and/or recyclable containers must be placed and/or maintained behind the front building line. All such containers must be stored and maintained in an upright and closed position. All such containers must be closed and may not be filled such that they are incapable of being closed. 
(c)  Container/dumpster/compactor requirements. All containers, dumpsters, and compactors shall be completely enclosed by walls and/or appropriate fencing such that the height of the enclosure exceeds the height of the entire apparatus by at least twelve (12) inches and such that the apparatus shall be completely screened from view on at least three (3) sides with the fourth side of the enclosure composed of material having no less than fifty (50) percent opacity, which must contain the gate for access to the subject apparatus. All containers, dumpsters, and compactors shall be set on a concrete slab, four (4) inches thick or other impervious prepared surface. No container, dumpster or compactor enclosure shall have dimensions less than eight (8) feet by ten (10) feet. All such apparatus and their enclosures shall be kept in a sanitary, odor-free condition, so as not to cause a public health problem or nuisance. 
(d)  Unauthorized accumulation. Any accumulation of residential solid waste, recyclable material and/or vegetative waste on any premises in violation of this article is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to remove any such existing accumulation of residential solid waste, recyclable material and/or vegetative waste within the time set forth in the notice thereof shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13; Ord. No. O-07-2018, § 1, 10-22-18) 
Sec. 9-25. - Responsibility of owners or agents for keeping areas free of residential solid waste and vegetative waste; notice of violation. 
(a)  Generally. The owners or agents, tenants or lessees of all property, whether improved or unimproved, including residential homes and apartment units, shall be responsible for complying with the provisions of this section. The owners, agents, tenants or lessees shall be severally and jointly responsible for keeping the following areas free from residential solid waste and vegetative waste at all times, exclusive of those periods immediately prior to collection as permitted in this article, said areas to include the entire premises as well as the parkway or swale and/or easement adjoining the dwelling; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the owners or agents if such owners or agents shall be able to and will point out to the delegated town authority any person who has caused the unsanitary or illegal condition and provided that such owner or agent or any other witness he may produce executes an affidavit to this effect and the affiant in such cases shall thus become the voluntary witness for the town in its proceedings against such person. 
(b)  Notice of violation. After issuance of a written citation in the form of a door hanger, tag, or other written material, to property owners, their agents, tenants or lessees, wherever violations of this chapter are found, the town shall give the violators a fixed number of hours and/or days within which to correct the violation. The time allowed shall depend on the nature of the violation and the time necessary to comply with the provisions of this chapter. If, at the end of the time allowed, an inspection of the property reveals the violation to be continuing, then the town may, at its option, correct the violation and assess a special pick up fee, direct its franchise collector to correct the violation, and assess the customer a special pick up fee in accordance with the town's franchise agreement or pursue any other legal means of enforcement. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-26. - Collector performance, penalties, complaints. 
(a)  Performance. The collector's performance shall be supervised by the town manager or designee. If at any time during the life of the contract, performance is not to the satisfaction of the town manager or designee, the collector shall increase the staff, tools, and equipment needed to perform in such a manner as to comply with this section of the town Code as well as the terms of the contract. The failure of the town manager or designee to give such notification shall not relieve the collector of the obligation to perform in such a manner as to comply with this section of the town Code as well as the terms of the contract. The town manager may appoint a qualified person(s) to inspect the collector's operation and equipment at any reasonable time, and the collector shall admit authorized representatives of the town to make such inspections at any reasonable time and place. 
(b)  Complaints. 
(1)  Office. The collector shall provide at its expense, a suitable office equipped with sufficient telephones where complaints shall be received, recorded and handled during normal business hours, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, for prompt handling of emergency complaints and all other special emergency complaints or calls. 
(2)  Complaints. The collector shall prepare and maintain a register of all complaints and service disputes and indicate the disposition of each. Such record shall be available for town inspection at all times during business hours. The form shall indicate the day and hour on which the complaint or dispute was received and the day and hour on which it was resolved. When a complaint is received after 12:00 noon on the day preceding a holiday, or on a Saturday, it shall be serviced no later than the next working day. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-27. - Residential franchise collector schedules and routes. 
(a)  Schedules. The collector shall provide the town with schedules for all collection routes and keep such information current at all times. Initial schedules shall be developed in conjunction with the town manager or designee. No changes shall be made in the routes without prior approval of the town manager or designee. The town manager shall approve all permanent changes in routes or schedules that alter the day of pickup. Upon approval of the town manager or designee, the collector shall provide notice of the effective date of such route or schedule changes to each residential customer in the town in accordance with the town's franchise agreement. 
(b)  Collector access to transfer station. The town reserves the right to deny the collector's vehicles access to certain streets, alleys and public ways inside the town en route to the disposal site where it is in the interest of the general public to do so because of the condition of the streets or bridges. The collector shall not interrupt the regular schedule of service because of street closures of less than eight (8) hours in duration. The town shall notify the collector of street closures of longer duration and arrangements for service will be made in a manner satisfactory to the collector and the town. Customers shall receive reasonable notification of the schedules provided by the collector prior to commencement of service. 
(c)  Storm. In case of a storm, the town manager or designee may grant the collector reasonable variance from the regular schedules and routes. As soon as practicable after such storm, the collector shall advise the town manager or designee and the customers of the estimated time required before regular schedules and routes can be resumed. In case of a storm where it is necessary for the collector and the town to acquire additional equipment and to hire extra crews to clean the town of debris and refuse resulting from the storm, the collector shall receive extra compensation above the contract price for additional employees, overtime, and the cost of rental equipment, provided the collector has first secured prior written authorization from the town manager or designee. The total cost for such service shall be based on rates jointly agreed upon by the town manager or designee and the collector, not to exceed FEMA approved rates. In addition, the town may require the collector to provide town-wide emergency vegetative collection prior to and/or after the storm. 
(d)  Holidays. The town and the collector will mutually agree upon a list of holidays when there will be no collection. If the regular collection day falls on a no service holiday, the collector shall collect the refuse on the next regularly scheduled collection day. All other holidays shall be considered regular collection days. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-28. - Collection equipment. 
    The collector shall have on hand at all times, in good working order and sanitary condition, such equipment as shall be necessary to perform its contractual duties. Equipment shall be kept in good repair, appearance, and in a sanitary and clean condition at all times. The collector shall have reserve equipment which can be put into service within two (2) hours of any breakdown. Equipment is to be painted uniformly with the name of the collector, business telephone number, and the number of the vehicle in letters not less than five (5) inches on each side of the vehicle. The rear of the vehicle shall contain signs warning the public of frequent stops. All vehicles shall be numbered and a record kept of the vehicle to which each number is assigned. No advertising shall be permitted on vehicles except that approved by the town. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-29. - Residential franchise collector recycling. 
(a)  Duties of collector. Recyclables shall be placed in the designated bins provided by the town or town's franchisee according to solid waste authority regulations. 
(b)  Frequency of collection. Recyclable materials shall be collected within the town at least one (1) time per week. The day of collection shall be on the same day as one (1) of the collection days for solid waste. No changes in routes or collection days shall be made without the advance approval of the town manager or designee and proper notification of each customer, as set forth hereinabove. 
(c)  Hours of collection. Collection shall begin no earlier and shall cease no later than as set forth in the town's franchise agreement. 
(d)  Point of pickup for recyclable materials. Collection of recyclable materials shall be at the same location at which the residential dwelling unit receives garbage collection (i.e., curbside for those that receive containerized service and adjacent to the dumpster enclosure for those that receive dumpster service or other such locations as will provide ready accessibility to the collector's collection crew and vehicle). 
(e)  Receptacles. The collector shall pick up all recyclable materials which have been properly prepared for collection and placed in recycling containers. The collector shall supply and distribute to each dwelling unit within a residential structure utilizing curbside pickup, two (2) containers for recyclable materials to be collected. However, those residential structures that utilize container/dumpster service, shall utilize ninety-six (96) gallon containers to collect recyclable materials. If these containers are used, they must be properly sight screened (see section 9-15). The cost of these containers will be borne by the collector. Receptacles may be imprinted with a logo and/or recycling theme with the prior approval of the town. The collector is responsible for replacing lost, damaged or stolen bins at no charge to the customer. The collector shall maintain an adequate supply of containers to provide for new dwelling unit and replacement of containers. All recycling containers provided or replaced by the collector shall be identical in type, size and color for each type of recycling container. 
(f)  Method of collection. The collector shall make collections with a minimum of noise and disturbance to the residence. Any recyclable materials spilled by the collector shall be picked up immediately. Recycling containers shall be thoroughly emptied and left inverted at the point of collection, unless they are the ninety-six (96) gallon mechanical containers, which may remain upright when emptied. 
(g)  Schedules and routes. Recyclable materials collection for a dwelling unit shall be made on one (1) of the two (2) solid waste pick-up days for that dwelling unit, unless prior approval is received from the town manager or designee. Therefore, schedules and routes shall match the schedules and routes for solid waste collection, except that the town manager or designee is authorized to modify, extend or suspend schedules in the event of natural disaster, health hazard or any other state of emergency requiring such action. Any other schedule or route change must be approved by the town manager or designee. Upon approval of the town manager or designee, the collector shall provide notice of the effective date of such route or schedule changes to each residential customer in the town in accordance with the town's franchise agreement. 
(h)  Monitoring records. The collector shall be responsible, on a monthly basis, for maintaining information and records adequate to determine participation rates and weekly set out rates by percent, volume of solid waste diverted from landfill by percent, weight by material of items recycled, neighborhoods above or below average participating and other information required by the town, Palm Beach County, or the State of Florida necessary to meet requirements of the Solid Waste Management Act or to obtain grant funds from the Solid Waste Trust Fund. 
(i)  Holidays. The town and the collector will mutually agree upon a list of holidays when there will be no collection. If the regular collection day falls on a no service holiday, the collector shall collect the recyclable materials on the next regularly scheduled collection day. All other holidays shall be considered regular collection days. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Secs. 9-30-9-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL COLLECTION 

Sec. 9-40. - Engaging in commercial solid waste collection services; issuance of non-exclusive franchise to private collector. 
(a)  No person, firm, or corporation shall: 
(1)  Place and/or service dumpsters, roll-off and/or compactor containers for the collection of commercial solid waste within the town; or 
(2)  Provide collection, transport or disposal services for non-recyclable commercial solid waste over the streets or public rights-of-way of the town, without first applying for and receiving a non-exclusive franchise from the town to carry on such a business, issued in the name of a corporation or company licensed to [do] business in the State of Florida. The non-exclusive franchise required by this section shall be in addition to any other license(s) that otherwise may be required by law. 
(b)  The town council may, from time to time, grant one (1) or more nonexclusive franchises granting the right and privilege to operate a commercial dumpster, roll-off and/or compactor container collection and disposal service in, upon, over and across the present and future streets, alleys, easements and other public places of the town for the purpose of collecting commercial solid waste. The town may limit the number of nonexclusive franchises granted where such limitation is deemed to be in the public interest. 
(c)  No franchise granted pursuant to this section shall be deemed the property of the holder thereof. 
(d)  The town reserves the right and power to revoke all franchises granted pursuant to this section, to change or limit the rights granted or to otherwise modify such franchises, in its sole discretion, by ordinance duly enacted by it. Such action shall not be deemed a taking of a property, or an impairment of contract or right of any franchisee. It is the express intention of this section to reserve unto the town the power, in its sole discretion, to alter the methods of commercial solid waste collection services employed in the town, and the manner in which commercial solid waste collection services may be provided within the town. Provided however that entry into a non-exclusive franchise with the town shall not constitute a waiver of the franchisees rights under F.S. § 403.70605. 
(e)  Upon payment of the applicable fee and approval of the application for a franchise (or renewal), the town will enter into a franchise agreement, in a form acceptable to the town, which franchise shall expire at the end of the period for which such franchise is granted. The franchise(s) shall be granted only after the applicant for the franchise has filed an application, and such other documentation as may reasonably be required, with the town manager to establish that the applicant meets all of the requirements delineated in this section. 
(f)  Franchise period. No franchise shall be issued for more than five (5) years and all franchises shall expire on September 30 of the applicable year. Application for renewal is required on or before September 30 in accordance with section 9-40(h). 
(g)  Franchise fees. 
(1)  All franchisees shall pay an annual non-exclusive franchise fee as set forth in the town's fees and charges resolution. It shall be no defense of nonpayment of the franchise fee that a franchisee has not received any bill or notice from the town. 
(2)  For each franchise granted on or between October 1 and March 31 of the subsequent year, the full franchise fee as specified in the town fee schedule, for one (1) year shall be paid. For each franchise granted on or between April 1 and June 30, one-half (1/2) of the full fee for one (1) year shall be paid. For each franchise granted on or between July 1 and September 30, one-fourth (1/4) of the full amount for one (1) year shall be paid. 
(3)  All franchisees shall pay a monthly non-exclusive franchise activity fee as specified by the town fee schedule based on a percentage of the franchisee's total gross revenue for the preceding month for all charges for service within the town, including charges for furnishing containers disposal costs and charges for transport of containers. 
(h)  Applications for a non-exclusive franchise (or renewal) shall be made to the town upon such forms and in such manner as shall be prescribed by the town manager to elicit such information as the town manager has deemed to [be] necessary. 
(i)  Cash or a letter of credit in an amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be required for the first year of the franchise period ending September 30. In subsequent years the amount shall be equal to the applicant's previous twelve (12) month franchise fees paid to the town or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), whichever is lesser as security for any fees due to the town under the franchise agreements conditioned upon the compliance of the terms of this section in such form as acceptable to the town attorney. The cash or a letter of credit described in this section must be submitted to the town prior to the initial franchise being granted, for the initial year ending September 30, and maintained for all subsequent years for the period of October 1 through September 30, prior to the beginning of the renewal period. 
(j)  Application form. Each application for a franchise (or renewal) shall be made on a standard form promulgated by the finance and administrative services department and shall include an affirmation that the applicant shall comply with the requirements of this section and the franchise. 
(k)  Review and issuance. The completed application along with the appropriate fee(s) shall be submitted to the town manager, or designee. Upon receipt of a completed application and fee(s), the town manager or designee shall provide for the review of said application and the town manager, or designee, shall either grant or deny the application (or renewal). 
(l)  Denial of application. The following circumstances shall constitute grounds to deny any application for a non-exclusive franchise (or renewal): 
(1)  Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this section and/or the franchise agreement; 
(2)  Evidence that the applicant previously operated a commercial solid waste collection services in the town without holding a valid franchise after the effective date of this section; or 
(3)  A finding that the applicant lacks sufficient experience, equipment, staff, or disposal plan to safely comply with the requirements of this section and/or the franchise agreement. In the event the town manager, or designee, denies an application for a franchise (or renewal), the applicant shall be provided written notification of the denial and the reasons for the denial via certified mail. 
(m)  Appeal from the town manager's, or designee's, denial of a franchise (or renewal). 
(1)  The denial of a franchise (or renewal) by the town manager or designee may be appealed to the town council. The applicant shall pay the appropriate appeal fee as specified in the town fees and charges schedule and the appeal shall be filed in writing with the town manager no later than fourteen (14) days after the mailing of the written notice advising the applicant of the denial. 
(2)  The town council shall either affirm the decision of the town manager, or designee, or direct the town manager to issue the franchise (or renewal). A decision of the town council to affirm the decision of the town manager, or designee, shall be final. 
(n)  Identification of equipment. All equipment utilized to collect and transport commercial solid waste in the town must be conspicuously marked on both sides of the vehicle with the name of the franchisee, and dumpsters and roll-off containers shall be conspicuously marked with the name of the franchisee. All markings must be in letters and numerals at least two (2) inches in height. In addition, all vehicles utilized in the provision of services within the town must comply with federal and state department of transportation regulations pertaining to the operation of commercial vehicles. All drivers must be appropriately licensed. 
(o)  Placement and maintenance of containers. Dumpsters and roll-off containers may only be placed, or allowed to remain, in locations delineated for such purposes. Dumpsters and roll-off containers shall not be placed in the public right-of-way. Equipment and other franchisee property shall be maintained, and all operations shall be conducted, in compliance with this chapter. The town, in its discretion, may require a change in the location of, or replacement of, a container if it becomes an unsightly nuisance, causes a code violation to occur, poses a threat to the surrounding environment, threatens the health and/or safety of the town's population, or becomes unsanitary and/or inoperable. 
(p)  Information required of franchisees. 
(1)  Monthly filings. Within ten (10) days from the first day of each month, franchisees shall deliver to the town via U.S. Mail, as well as an electronic format approved by the town, a true and correct monthly report of gross receipts generated during the previous month from accounts within the town. This detailed monthly report shall include the customer names, service addresses, account numbers and the actual amount billed to each customer. In the event that there are no reportable receipts generated within the town, the franchisee is required to submit a report indicating such. 
(2)  Annual filings. Franchisees shall, on or before November 1 of every year, deliver to the town a statement reflecting annual gross receipts generated from accounts within the corporate limits of the town, compiled by an independent certified public accountant, for the preceding October 1 through September 30. This report shall include the customer names, service addresses, account numbers and the actual amount billed to each customer. 
(3)  Audit of records. By acceptance of a franchise and in consideration of the receipt thereof, the franchisee shall make available, within three (3) business days after notice, all records of the franchisee which pertain to any commercial solid waste collection services within the town, including but not limited to contracts, trip tickets, invoices, state and federal tax returns, and any documents supporting the information compiled within the supplemental filings required by subsections (1) and (2) above, for inspection and auditing by the town. This information shall include, but not be limited to, copies of the following: billing rates, billing amounts and accounts receivable. Additionally, the town's auditors may communicate directly with customers of the franchisee for the purpose of confirming compliance with this section. In the event any audit reveals that a franchisee has failed to pay the full franchise fee, the franchisee shall pay a franchise fee of three (3) times the original amount due. Additionally, the franchisee shall reimburse the town for all expenses incurred by the town pursuant to this paragraph, including audit costs, court costs, and reasonable attorneys' fees. 
(4)  Change in required information. Each franchisee shall file any change in any information which is required to be submitted to the town with the town manager, or designee. 
(5)  Transfer of non-exclusive franchise. Upon the sale or legal transfer of a franchisee company or corporation, the new owner must apply for a transfer of the franchise, in writing, within thirty (30) days of the transfer, to the finance and administrative services director and shall provide the requisite evidence of required insurance and financial responsibility. A franchise may be transferred to a new operational location. Transfer of a franchise to a successor entity is not final until approved by the municipal services director. Once transferred, the franchise shall remain in effect until the original expiration date. 
(q)  Any and all commercial solid waste collected by a franchisee within the town shall be disposed of only at a designated facility. 
(r)  All franchisees shall comply with the provisions of this section. The town may use the reports required in this section and other information available to determine compliance of franchisees. 
(s)  Manner of collection. The franchisee shall provide all collection services with as little disturbance as possible. Franchisees shall not litter or cause any spillage to occur upon the premises or the rights-of-way. During transportation, all commercial solid waste shall be contained or enclosed so that spillage and litter is prevented. In the event of any spillage or litter caused by the franchisee, the franchisee shall promptly clean-up all spillage or litter at no cost to its customer or the town. 
(t)  Rates for services. 
(1)  Rates and charges for roll-off and container collection services shall be determined by agreement between the franchisee and its customer. The franchisee shall be responsible for billing and collecting all fees and charge[s] for its services, including container rental charges, directly from its customers. 
(2)  The franchisee shall be responsible for all costs of transport and disposal of the commercial solid waste at the designated facility. 
(u)  Revocation and suspension of non-exclusive franchise. The town manager, or designee, may, in his/her discretion, revoke or suspend a non-exclusive franchise pursuant to the following: 
(1)  The town manager, or designee, shall provide the franchisee with written notice reasonably specifying the reasons for the proposed revocation or suspension of the franchise and the franchisee shall be afforded five (5) business days to cure the violation stated in such notice. 
(2)  The violation of any of the provisions of this section and/or the franchise agreement shall be cause for revocation or suspension of a franchise. 
(3)  In the event the franchise fails to cure the violation within five (5) business days, the town manager, or designee, may revoke or suspend a franchise and may immediately declare such franchise null and void, and upon such revocation or suspension, franchisee shall immediately cease all operations, and shall be considered to have forfeited said franchise and any rights acquired thereunder. The franchisee shall remove all dumpsters and roll-off and/or compactor containers within ten (10) business days after the mailing of notice of revocation or suspension. In the event all dumpsters and roll-off and/or compactor containers are not removed within ten (10) business days after the mailing of notice of revocation or suspension: 
a.  The cash or letter of credit funds posted pursuant to section 9-40(h) shall be forfeited; and 
b.  The town shall order the property owner or general contractor to remove same within five (5) business days. 
In the event the property owner or the general contractor fails to remove same within five (5) business days, such failure shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(v)  Appeal from the town manager, or designee, of the revocation or suspension of franchise. 
(1)  The revocation or suspension of a franchise by the town manager, or designee, may be appealed to the town council. The applicant shall pay the appropriate appeal fee as specified in the town fees and charges schedule and the appeal shall be filed in writing with the town manager no later than fourteen (14) days after the mailing of the written notice advising the applicant of the denial. 
(2)  The town council shall either affirm the decision of the town manager, or designee, or direct the town manager to reinstate the franchise. A decision of the town council to affirm the decision of the town manager, or designee, shall be final. 
(w)  Violation. It shall be a violation for any person to permit collection of commercial solid waste by any non-franchised commercial solid waste collection services provider from any parcel of land owned or leased by, or in the control of, such person. 
(x)  The franchisee shall hold the town harmless from any and all liabilities, claims, losses or damages the town may suffer as a result of claims, demands, costs or judgments against the town arising out of the wrongful acts or omission of the franchisee or its employees in the performance of commercial solid waste collection services within the town. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Sec. 9-41. - Commercial collection service. 
(a)  Each commercial establishment may select the collector of its choice. However, each commercial collector, regardless of the number of establishments they serve shall obtain a non-exclusive franchise license from the town prior to performing collection services in the town. 
(b)  Frequency of collection. Collection of commercial waste shall be collected at a predetermined frequency as mutually agreed upon by the commercial establishment and the collector. However, for commercial customers generating garbage, a collection of twice per week is mandatory. In the event a customer's container is consistently overloaded, the town will require the customer to use a larger container or a greater frequency of collection with the additional costs, if any, to be paid by the customer. 
(c)  Point of pickup for commercial refuse. Commercial refuse customers shall accumulate refuse at locations that are mutually agreed upon by the customer and the collector and which are convenient for collection by the collector. However, all commercial customers must comply with the requirements of their site plan and the container screening requirement set forth herein. 
(d)  Receptacles. Commercial establishments may utilize container/dumpster service or containerized service, as mutually agreed upon by the customer and the collector. 
(e)  Method of collection of commercial refuse. The collector shall make collections with as little disturbance as possible. Any refuse spilled by the collector shall be picked up immediatelyby the collector, unless spillage is caused by overloaded containers in which case the customer shall be responsible for picking up the spillage. 
(Ord. No. O-01-2013, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Secs. 9-42-9-49. - Reserved.
