ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1-11-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS TAXES AND REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Additional excise or license taxes, § 11-155 et seq. 

Sec. 11-16. - Levy of business tax; registration. 
(a)  Business tax. A tax is hereby fixed and imposed upon every person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the town for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business, profession or occupation within the town. A business tax receipt is also hereby levied upon any person who does not qualify under the provisions noted hereinabove and who transacts any business or engages in any occupation or profession in interstate commerce, if such business tax is not prohibited by Section 8 of Article I of the United States Constitution. 
(b)  Registration. Any person who does not fall into one (1) of the categories set forth above in subsection (a) but who comes within the corporate limits of the town to carry on, complete, perform or engage in any type of business, is hereby required to register with the town by filling out a registration form. Such person must provide a copy of a valid business tax receipt issued by another municipality and/or the county indicating that he possesses a valid business tax receipt at the location of his branch or permanent office and must provide appropriate forms, as requested by the town according to the type of business. A nominal fee shall be charged to cover the administrative costs in registering these additional businesses, occupations and professions; the amount of which registration fee shall be set by resolution of the town council. The registration requirement set forth in this sub-section shall not apply to any trade or business regulated by the department of business and professional regulation. Additionally, this requirement shall not apply to any pest control operators licensed and regulated by the state of Florida. 
(c)  Voluntary registration . Pursuant to F.S. § 205.065, any person engaging in or managing a business, profession or occupation regulated by the department of business and professional regulation that has paid a business tax for the current year to the county or municipality in that state where the person's permanent business location or branch office is maintained shall not be required to register his business tax receipt with the town. However, such persons may voluntarily register with the town by presenting proof of state licensing, a valid business tax receipt issued by the municipality or county in which the licensee's branch or permanent office is located and by paying an administrative fee as established by resolution of the town council. Persons not desiring to register voluntarily shall not be required to do so. However, such persons shall be required to present all documentation required by this subsection each time application for a town permit is made. 
(Code 1962, § 14-1; Ord. No. O-12-90, § 1, 7-23-90; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 1, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-17. - Term of business tax receipt; half-year business tax receipt. 
    All business tax receipts shall be payable on or before the thirtieth day of September of each year as set forth in more detail at section 11-20. Any person who was not liable for a business tax receipt during the first half of the tax year may be issued a business tax receipt during the second half of the tax year upon the payment of one-half the amount fixed as the price of such business tax receipt for one (1) year. 
(Code 1962, § 14-2; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-18. - Application; inspection; rental information card. 
(a)  Application; fee. Before the town shall be required to issue a business tax receipt for engaging in or carrying on any business, profession, or occupation within the town, it shall be the duty of the applicant to file an application for a business tax receipt with the town. Such application shall be in the form required by the town and shall be accompanied by an administrative fee for said business tax receipt; the amount of which shall be set by resolution of the town council. 
(b)  The building department, fire department, and/or any other applicable department shall conduct an inspection of all commercial premises whenever an application is submitted in order to ensure that said commercial premises are in compliance with all town codes. The town shall charge an administrative fee for said inspection; the amount of which shall be set by resolution of the town council. No business tax receipt will be issued unless and/or until, the proposed business entity is in compliance with all town codes. 
(c)  Rental information card to be filed. In addition to the above application, rental property owners and/or landlords shall also have a duty to file a rental information card with the town prior to the issuance of a business tax receipt by the town. 
(Ord. No. O-16-86, § 1, 6-23-86; Ord. No. O-14-87, § 1, 8-24-87; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-08-2019, § 1, 2-25-19) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. O-16-68, adopted June 23, 1986, amended the Code by repealing provisions codified herein as §§ 11-18, 11-19, 11-21-11-23, and enacting, in lieu thereof, provisions codified as §§ 11-18, 11-19, 11-21-11-23, by the editor. Prior to repeal former §§ 11-18, 11-19, 11-21-11-23 pertained to similar provisions and derived from Code 1962, §§ 14-3, 14-4, 14-6-14-8, respectively. 
Sec. 11-19. - Affidavit as to basis of business tax receipt. 
    Whenever the amount of the business tax to be assessed depends upon the amount of stock in trade carried by the applicant, the number of rooms in a hotel or rooming house, living or rental unit, etc., or any other fact or facts not within the personal knowledge of the town, no business tax receipt shall be issued until the applicant has made and filed with the town an affidavit, duly authenticated, setting forth the amount of his stock in trade, number of rooms in his hotel or rooming house, living or rental unit, etc., or other facts upon which the amount of such business tax depends. 
(Ord. No. O-16-86, § 1, 6-23-86; Ord. No. O-14-87, § 2, 8-24-87; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Note- See editor's note following § 11-18. 
Sec. 11-20. - Due dates; delinquency penalties; non-compliance penalties. 
(a)  All business taxes receipts shall be sold by the town clerk beginning July 1 of each year, are due and payable on or before September 30 of each year, and expire on September 30 of the succeeding year. If September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax is due and payable on or before the first working day following September 30. Business tax receipts that are not renewed when due and payable are delinquent and subject to delinquency penalty of ten (10) percent for the month of October, plus an additional five (5) percent for each subsequent month of delinquency until paid. However, the total delinquency penalty may not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the business tax for the delinquent establishment. 
(b)  Any person who engages in or manages any business, occupation, or profession without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, if required, is subject to penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the tax due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(c)  Any person who engages in any business, occupation, or profession covered by this article, who does not pay the required business tax within one hundred fifty (150) days after the initial notice of tax due, and who does not obtain the required business tax receipt is subject to civil actions and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys fees, additional administrative costs incurred as a result of collection efforts, and a penalty of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) 
(Code 1962, § 14-5; Ord. No. O-25-86, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 2, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-06-2007, § 1, 6-25-07) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053 
Sec. 11-21. - Business tax receipts to be posted or carried. 
    All business tax receipts granted hereunder shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where the business is being conducted, either stationary or mobile, or in case of solicitors and canvassers, such business tax receipt must be carried upon their person. 
(Ord. No. O-16-86, § 1, 6-23-86; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Note- See editor's note following § 11-18. 
Sec. 11-22. - Issuance, suspension or revocation of business tax receipt; appeal procedure. 
(a)  No business tax receipt shall be issued unless it is found that the proposed business and location comply with the town zoning code and other applicable town ordinances. 
(b)  No business tax receipt shall be issued for an occupation where certification is required under state law unless proof of said certification is provided. 
(c)  A business tax receipt may be suspended or revoked upon a finding that the business is operating in violation of the town codes. 
(d)  An initial determination upon issuance or revocation will be made by the appropriate town official. 
(e)  The applicant shall have ten (10) days after receiving notification in writing from the town clerk of the suspension or revocation to appeal the determination of the appropriate town official to the town council. The request for appeal shall be filed with the town clerk in writing. 
(f)  Within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the appeal, the town council shall hold a quasijudicial hearing in the denial of the business tax receipt application or the suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1962, § 14-7; Ord. No. O-16-86, § 1, 6-23-86; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-23. - Effect of issuance of business tax receipt. 
    The issuance of a business tax receipt shall merely indicate that the applicant has paid the appropriate business tax. 
    The mistaken issuance of a business tax receipt shall not be deemed to be a waiver of any provision of the town code, nor shall the issuance of a business tax receipt be construed to be a judgment of the town as to the competence of the applicant to transact the business for which the business tax receipt was issued. 
(Ord. No. O-16-86, § 1, 6-23-86; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Note- See editor's note following § 11-18. 
Sec. 11-23.1. - Transfer of business tax receipt. 
(a)  Transfer to new owner. Business tax receipts issued under the provisions of this chapter may be transferred with the approval and written authorization of the town endorsed thereon, for the same business activity for which they were originally issued when there is a bona fide sale and transfer of the property used and employed in the business; however, such transferred business tax receipt shall not be considered valid for any longer time nor for any place other than that for which it was originally issued, provided that the original business tax receipt shall be surrendered to and filed with the town at the time application for transfer is made. The transferred business tax receipt, after being approved, shall be of the same force and effect as the original business tax receipt. At the time any business tax receipt is transferred, the person applying for such transfer shall pay to the town a transfer fee as well as an inspection administrative service fee, the amount of which shall be set by resolution of the town council and amended from time to time as necessary to cover administrative costs. 
(b)  Transfer to new location. Business tax receipts may also be transferred from location to location with the approval and written authorization of the town endorsed thereon, provided no change of ownership has occurred or is in the process and provided that the business tax receipt classification remains unaffected. Such transferred business tax receipt shall not be valid for any longer time nor for any other type of business than that which was originally issued. In order for a business tax receipt to be legally transferred to a new location, the original business tax receipt shall be surrendered to and filed with the town at the time application for transfer is made, and such transferred business tax receipt, after being approved, shall be of the same force and effect as the original business tax receipt. At the time any business tax receipt is transferred, the person applying for such transfer shall pay to the town a transfer fee as well as an inspection administrative service fee, the amount of which fees shall be set by resolution of the town council and amended from time to time to cover administrative costs. 
(c)  Transfer to new name. Business tax receipts granted or issued under the provisions of this chapter may be transferred to a new business name with the approval and written authorization of the town endorsed thereon, provided that the classification of the business tax receipt does not change, the location of the business and the ownership of the business remains the same. Such transferred business tax receipt shall not be valid for any longer time nor for any other place than that for which it was originally issued. The original business tax receipt shall be surrendered to and filed with the town at the time application for transfer is made and such transferred business tax receipt, after being approved, shall be of the same force and effect as the original business tax receipt. At the time any business tax receipt is transferred, the person applying for such transfer shall pay to the town a transfer fee, the amount of which shall be set by resolution of the town council and amended from time to time to cover administrative costs. 
(Ord. No. O-14-88, § 1, 9-26-88; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. O-14-88, adopted Sept. 26, 1988, repealed former § 11-23.1 and enacted new provisions to read as set out herein. Former § 11.23.1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-25-66, § 2, adopted Dec. 8, 1986. 
Sec. 11-23.2. - Duplicate business tax receipts. 
    The town shall charge one dollar ($1.00) for each duplicate business tax receipt issued to replace any business tax receipt issued under the provisions of this chapter which has been lost, stolen, defaced or destroyed, without any willful conduct on the part of the holder of the business tax receipt, upon the filing by the receipt holder of a statement attesting to such fact. 
(Ord. No. O-25-86, § 2, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-24. - Ultra vires transactions; fraudulent business tax receipts void. 
    No business tax receipt issued under the provisions of this chapter shall protect any person from prosecution for transacting any business, trade or profession not covered by the license. No business tax receipt issued shall protect any merchant doing business with a greater stock in trade than is covered by the business tax receipt, or any hotel keeper or rooming house keeper having a greater number of rooms than is covered by the business tax receipt. Any business tax receipt issued upon any false statement made under oath shall be considered as void ab initio, and shall not protect the holder thereof from prosecution for transacting business without a business tax receipt. 
(Code 1962, § 14-9; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-25. - Special events permits; temporary recreation event permits. 
(a)  Permit required. Any person, corporation, or other entity of any kind whatsoever who desires to conduct any type of special event or temporary recreational event within the town which is not covered under the regular business tax receipt and registration sections set forth herein, must obtain a permit from the town in order that the town may adequately provide for the potential impacts created by the proposed event. The fee for such permit shall be set by resolution of the town council. Additionally, vendors at special events shall pay a special permit fee for that event; which fee shall be set by resolution of the town council. 
(b)  Written application. Written application must be submitted to the town at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date for which the special event is proposed; which application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Type of event. 
(2)  Sponsor or persons responsible for event. 
(3)  Proposed location with owner's written consent. 
(4)  Proposed date, commencement time and duration of event. 
(5)  Approximate number of participants. 
(6)  Proof of insurance. 
(7)  Traffic, fire-rescue, utilities impact, if any, and proposed mitigation plan. 
(8)  Copy of all required state and county permits if event will be held on or utilize state and/or county controlled property. 
(c)  Minimum impact. All special events shall be coordinated with the town in order to lessen adverse impacts and to allow for continuous protection of the health, safety, and welfare of all. 
In order to provide such protection, all applications for special events shall be submitted to the town plan review committee (PRC) for review. The PRC may approve the application as presented, or may approve with conditions placed upon the application which are reasonably calculated to reduce impacts created by the proposed event. 
(Code 1962, § 14-9.1; Ord. No. O-12-90, § 2, 7-23-90; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 3, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-25.1. - Special permits to nonprofit enterprise. 
(a)  The town shall issue permits, without payment of any business tax or other charges, therefore, to any person or organization for the conduct or operation of occasional sales and/or fundraising projects held by nonprofit enterprises, when the applicant signs an affidavit that the applicant operates without private profit for a civic, charitable, youth, service, fraternal or religious purpose. 
(b)  Special permittees must conform. A person operating under a special permit shall operate his nonprofit enterprise in compliance with this section and all other rules and regulations. 
(c)  Any person signing a false affidavit pursuant to this section shall be subject to any and all enforcement proceedings as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-25-86, § 3, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 4, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-25.2. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following persons are exempted from the payment of a business tax: 
(1)  Disabled veterans who served in the United States Armed Services; 
(2)  Disabled persons physically incapable of manual labor; 
(3)  Widows with minor dependents; 
(4)  Churches; 
(5)  Persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older with not more than one (1) employee and who only use their own capital in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); and 
(6)  Any other person(s) or entities exempted by state law. 
(b)  Any person entitled to an exemption provided by this section shall, upon application and furnishing of the necessary proof, execute an affidavit supporting his right to exemption, and be issued a business tax receipt which shall have plainly stamped or written across the face thereon the reason for exemption. 
(Ord. No. O-25-86, § 3, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 5, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-26. - Professional licenses. 
(a)  Tax. The tax provided in section 11-28 for architects, auditors, auctioneers, accountants, dentists, draftsmen, engineers, lawyers, osteopaths, chiropractors, chiropodists, phrenologists, physicians, surgeons, real estate agents or brokers, or other similar businesses, professions or occupations shall be construed to mean that each individual shall pay the business tax therein provided, whether engaging in business himself or in partnership with another. 
(b)  Credentials. Any person applying for or renewing a local business tax receipt to practice any profession regulated by the department of business and professional regulation, or any board or commission thereof, must exhibit an active state license, registration or certificate, or proof of copy of same before such local business tax receipt may be issued. 
(Code 1962, § 14-10; Ord. No. O-25-86, § 4, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-26.1. - Various types of rental property defined; business tax receipt required. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply to the rental of all units utilized for residential purposes. 
    Long term rentals: The rental, lease, sublease or assignment of property for a period of time in excess of thirty (30) days. 
    Residential rental property. Residential rental property shall include, but is not limited to, dwelling units such as rooming houses, single-family residences, duplexes and multifamily units, when these properties are rented, leased, subleased or assigned to dwellers as opposed to being owner occupied. These various types of units are further defined in Appendix A of the subdivision regulation code or in the zoning code which may be found at Chapter 17.5 and Chapter 23, respectively, of this Code. 
    Short term rentals: The rental, lease, sublease or assignment of property for thirty (30) days or less. 
(b)  Business tax receipt required for all residential rental properties. All residential rental property as defined above located in the town must pay business tax and must acquire a business tax receipt. Short term rentals as defined above are prohibited for single-family houses located in the R-1 and R-1A Zoning Districts; see section 23-135 of the town's zoning code. Additional regulations regarding residential rental properties are found at Article II of Chapter 13 of this Code relating to sexual offenders and/or predators. In order to apply for a local business tax receipt to rent, lease, sublease or assign to others residential property within the town, the following requirements must be observed: 
(1)  All owners of residential rental property as defined hereinabove shall file a completed rental information card with the town clerk's office after they have received and read the town's rental guidelines for landlords and tenants brochure; this information card must be filed prior to the issuance of a business tax receipt for the rental of residential real property. 
(2)  After the submission of an information card and application for a business tax receipt, an inspection of the premises shall be made by the Town in order to insure that the premises is in compliance with the town's code. See also section 11-18 herein. 
(c)  Business tax receipt required for all commercial rental properties. All commercial uses are required to have business tax receipts in accordance with section 11-16 hereinabove. 
(d)  Enforcement. This section may be enforced by the town by any lawful means. 
(Ord. No. O-14-87, § 3, 8-24-87; Ord. No. O-20-05, § 1, 11-14-05; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-27. - Distributor, operator; defined. 
(a)  The word distributor as used in this chapter shall be defined to mean any person, firm, association or corporation who engages in selling, distributing or conveying any ticket or ticket containers for trade or amusement purposes, at wholesale, to any person, firm, association or corporation in the Town for ultimate use by the public. 
(b)  The word operate as used herein shall mean a retail merchant, or other person, firm, association or corporation who shall display, offer for sale, or sell any ticket for trade or amusement purposes to the public by the use of ticket containers. 
(Code 1962, § 14-11; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Cross reference- Definition and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-28. - Schedule of business taxes. 
    The amount of business tax which shall be paid to the town per annum by each and every person, firm, associate or corporation engaged in or practicing such business, profession or occupation as herein contained shall be established by ordinance, in accordance with F.S. ch. 205. Such schedule of business taxes shall not be codified but shall be available at town hall for inspection by the public during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. O-25-86, § 5, 12-8-86; Ord. No. O-14-87, § 4, 8-24-87; Ord. No. O-14-88, § 2, 9-26-88; Ord. No. O-17-88, § 1, 12-12-88; Ord. No. O-3-89, § 1, 4-10-89; Ord. No. O-12-90, § 3, 7-23-90; Ord. No. O-2-94, § 6, 6-27-94; Ord. No. O-13-99, § 1, 10-11-99; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06; Ord. No. O-11-2007, § 1, 8-13-07; Ord. No. O-04-2009, 8-24-09; Ord. No. O-10-2012, § 1, 7-23-2012; Ord. No. O-05-2015, § 1, 7-13-15; Ord. No. O-08-2017, § 1, 7-10-17) 
Cross reference- Hours of sale of alcoholic beverages in nightclubs, § 3-1. 
Sec. 11-29. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11-30. - Roadside vendors regulated. 
(a)  Public rights-of-way and public property. The use of public rights-of-way and public property for the solicitation or sale of goods or services for profit is expressly prohibited. 
(b)  Private property. The use of private property for the solicitation or sale of goods and services for profit by mobile or stationary vendors, peddlers, hawkers, etc., other than in a permanent building which otherwise conforms to all ordinances of the town, is hereby prohibited, except where such uses: 
(1)  Are located within a business or commercial zone; 
(2)  Are specifically authorized, in writing, by the owner or lessee of the subject property; 
(3)  Are to exist on any given location within the town, for no longer than three (3) hours in any twenty-four-hour period; and 
(4)  Are issued a valid business tax receipt. 
(c)  Not for profit solicitation. All not-for-profit solicitation shall require a no-fee business tax receipt to be issued by the town council only to groups and organizations regularly meeting within the town. 
(Code 1962, § 14-6.1; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 1, 9-11-06) 
Secs. 11-31-11-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAME ROOMS 

Sec. 11-46. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the term "pinball and/or game room" shall mean any business location where the primary purpose of the business maintained therein is to provide gaming devices, machines, or apparatus for the use and/or entertainment of the public, said machine being any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc, or in any other manner manipulated, may be used as a game or amusement, whether or not registering a score and whether or not its operation demands skill or chance or both. 
(Code 1962, § 14-15) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-47. - Game room license required. 
    No person shall operate a pinball and/or game room in the town without first having obtained a game room license from the town. Such "game room license" shall be in addition to the requirement to obtain the appropriate business tax receipt as set forth herein above at Article II, Business Tax and Registration. 
(Code 1962, § 14-16; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 2, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-48. - Game room license fee. 
    The annual fee for a pinball and/or game room license shall be as established by resolution of the town council. The applicant/licensee must also pay all additional fees and/or taxes imposed by this chapter as established by resolution of the town council. 
(Code 1962, § 14-17; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 2, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-49. - Application for game room license. 
    An application for a game room license shall be made in accordance with this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 14-18; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 2, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-50. - Location. 
    No license shall be granted for a pinball and/or game room located within nine hundred (900) feet from the nearest boundary of a parcel of real estate having situated upon it a school, church, library, public park, playground or recreational facility, or another pinball and/or game room as defined herein. 
(Code 1962, § 14-19) 
Sec. 11-51. - Regulations. 
(a)  A licensed pinball and/or game room shall: 
(1)  Be closed to the public between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. and prior to 12:00 noon on Sundays. 
(2)  The occupant load permitted in any pinball and/or game room or portion thereof shall be determined by dividing the net floor area or space assigned to that use by seven (7) square feet per person. This load permitted shall not exceed the allowable load as determined by exit requirements. 
(3)  Have an attendant over twenty-one (21) years of age on the premises at all times in which the business is open to the public, who shall be in such a position as to have clear view of all the amusement devices and activity taking place on the premises. 
(4)  Provide separate restroom facilities for male and female patrons. 
(5)  Provide adequate and orderly parking for all bicycles and keep the storefront unobstructed so that the sidewalks are clear and open to pedestrian traffic. 
(b)  No licensee, proprietor, manager or employee shall permit: 
(1)  Any gambling on the license premises; 
(2)  The consumption of alcoholic beverages within the licensed premises; 
(3)  Such noise, either by mechanical means or noise on the part of the patrons, which shall cause a disturbance of the peace to the adjacent and surrounding uses. 
(c)  A licensed premises shall be required to meet the requirements of the fire, zoning, sanitary, electrical, building and plumbing codes of the town. 
(Code 1962, § 14-20) 
Sec. 11-52. - Revocation of game room license. 
    A game room license issued hereunder shall be subject to revocation by the town council for a violation of any of the provisions of this article after a hearing thereon; licensee to receive ten (10) days' notice of said hearing and the reasons for which said licensee must show cause why his license should not be revoked. 
(Code 1962, § 14-21; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 2, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-53. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article, or permitting a violation hereof, in addition to the revocation of the license, shall be guilty of a violation of this article as determined by the Lantana Code Enforcement Board and shall be fined in accordance with the rules and regulations as established by the board pursuant to F.S. Ch. 162. 
(Code 1962, § 14-22) 
Secs. 11-54-11-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GARAGE SALES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 

Sec. 11-66. - Definition. 
    "Garage sales," as used in this article, is hereby defined to mean any sale or offering for sale of personnel property by a person or persons of a family or other household unit, said personal property having been acquired, possessed and used by the family or household for personal as opposed to business or commercial use, when such sale is conducted at the present residence of such family or household. "Garage sales" shall include sales commonly referred to as patio sales, driveway sales, yard sales, and other such sales. "Garage sales" shall not include the sale or offering for sale of goods of more than one family or household. 
(Code 1962, § 14-30) 
Sec. 11-67. - Permit required. 
    No garage sale may be conducted within the town without a permit having been first issued for such sale by the town. Such permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such garage sale. No more than two (2) permits may be issued to one residence and/or family or household during any calendar year. Such permit shall be limited in time to no more than the daylight hours of two (2) consecutive days. If the sale commences without a permit, the owner will be required to cease operations, remove displayed goods and obtain a permit. 
(Code 1962, § 14-31) 
Sec. 11-68. - Written statement required. 
    Prior to issuance of any garage sale permit, the person conducting such sale shall file a written statement with the town, setting forth the following information: 
(1)  Person's interest in the residential property-ownership, current lessee or such other control as the person may have; 
(2)  Ownership of the property to be sold; 
(3)  Purposes to which the property to be sold has been previously used; 
(4)  Affirmative statement that the property to be sold was neither acquired nor consigned for the purpose of resale. 
(Code 1962, § 14-32) 
Sec. 11-69. - Permit fee. 
    No garage sale permit shall be issued by the town until a fee in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) has first been received therefor. 
(Code 1962, § 14-33) 
Sec. 11-70. - Sign permitted. 
    Three (3) garage sale signs shall be issued by the town to the resident along with the garage sale permit. One (1) sign of the issued signs shall be the only sign allowed to be displayed on the property of the residence where the garage sale is being conducted. However, two (2) of these signs may be displayed off premises providing the signs are free standing and shall not be attached to trees, sign poles and/or anything else whatsoever. These off-premises signs may be placed on private property with consent of the property owner and/or on public right-of-way (swale areas adjacent to public roadways), if such public right-of-way is adjacent to a municipal road. Signs may not be placed on county or state road rights-of-way. Signs are allowed only during the times of the sales as designated on the permit and must be removed immediately after the garage sale has concluded. The resident conducting the garage sale is responsible for the removal of the above said signs and will be subject to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) imposed by the Town of Lantana for signs not removed immediately after the garage sale has concluded, in accordance with the dates allowed by permit. 
(Code 1962, § 14-34; Ord. No. O-03-94, § 1, 6-13-94) 
Sec. 11-71. - Parking. 
    All parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. Further, the police department may enforce such temporary controls which would alleviate any special hazards and/or congestion created by any garage sale. 
(Code 1962, § 14-35) 
Sec. 11-72. - Display of permit. 
    The permit required by this article shall be prominently displayed at such sale in such a way so that same may be easily viewed by the public. 
(Code 1962, § 14-36) 
Sec. 11-73. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to sales of personal property made pursuant to a valid order of a court of competent jurisdiction, nor to sales by churches, schools, civic organizations or charitable organizations. 
(Code 1962, § 14-37) 
Sec. 11-74. - Compliance with other regulations. 
    Garage sales shall be conducted in compliance with all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations not in conflict herewith. 
(Code 1962, § 14-38) 
Sec. 11-75. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate a provision of this article, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or permit a violation thereof in conducting any garage sale not in accordance with the provisions hereof, shall be guilty of a violation of this article as determined by the Lantana Code Enforcement Board and shall be fined in accordance with the rules and regulations as established by the board pursuant to F.S. Ch. 162. 
(Code 1962, § 14-39) 
Secs. 11-76-11-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BINGO GAMES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Bingo, F.S. § 849.093. 

Sec. 11-91. - Charitable, nonprofit organizations. 
    Nonprofit or veteran's organizations engaged in charitable, civic, community, benevolent, religious or scholastic works and/or other similar activities, which organizations have been in existence for a period of three (3) years or more may conduct bingo games or guest games, as authorized by F.S. section 849.093 by donating the entire proceeds derived from the conduct of games to these stated endeavors, under the additional town regulations herein. If a nonprofit organization is not engaged in any of the endeavors stated, then its right to conduct games hereunder shall be conditioned upon the return of all the proceeds from such games to the players in the form of prizes. If at the conclusion of play on any day there remains proceeds which have not been paid out as prizes, then on the next scheduled day of play the organization shall conduct the game without charge so as to exhaust the proceeds carried over. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-1) 
State Law reference- F.S. § 849.093(2), (3). 
Sec. 11-92. - Application and registration fee. 
    Such organization shall file an application under oath on forms provided by the town. A nonrefundable registration fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid annually for the cost of processing the application, investigation of the applicant, identification card of the bingo operators, inspection fees and auditing the financial records. The registration fee must accompany the application. The fee is not prorated according to the date of the application and must be paid once each fiscal year to the town regardless of the number of games to be played. If the annual registration fee is not paid on or before October 31st in the second and all succeeding years, then the permit of the organization shall be null and void. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-2) 
Sec. 11-93. - Departmental approvals; final permit by town council. 
    The sworn application shall be received by the town clerk in duplicate. After initial filing with the town clerk, the application is to be submitted for approval or disapproval with specific reasons for disapproval to the chief of police, fire chief and building inspector. Thereupon the town council shall, upon consideration of the application, at its next regular meeting or special meeting either grant or deny the issuance of a bingo permit in its sound and sole judgment. In the event of denial, the council must make findings of fact and state reasons for its decision. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-3) 
Sec. 11-94. - Bingo operator; designation, identification, etc. 
    The operator of any bingo or guest game must be a resident of Lantana, a bona fide member of the organization sponsoring such games, and shall not be compensated in any way, including salary or expenses, for the operation of said games. The operator shall obtain a Lantana police identification card with photograph and right thumb print affixed thereon, and which I.D. card shall be in his possession during all games and shall be exhibited to any of the enumerated town department heads upon request. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-4) 
Sec. 11-95. - Books and records; annual accounting; inspection, audit. 
    The organization through its bingo operator and officers shall maintain accurate records in a bound book with numbered pages detailing the hours and dates of the games played, number of games played, unit cost of cards, gross amount of monies received per day, amount of monies given for prizes or cost of prizes, cost or overhead with purpose and to whom paid, and net revenue derived per day. Such books and records, as well as any related data of the organization, are subject to inspection and audit at any reasonable hour by the chief of police, acting chief of police and the mayor. An annual accounting of all receipts and disbursements shall be filed with the city clerk on or before October 31 of each year. The town council shall have the right to require additional information and reports as may be necessary to insure that all laws are being observed. Any change in the officers of the organization shall be reported by letter signed by an officer to the mayor and town clerk. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-5) 
Sec. 11-96. - Restriction on location of games; adults only. 
    No bingo or guest games shall be played at the town hall. No one is allowed to play who is under eighteen (18) years of age. The organization must hold said games at the scheduled times and places in a manner so as not to create a nuisance in the neighborhood of the approved site. 
(Code 1962, § 5A-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 849.093(9). 
Sec. 11-97. - Two games per week; jackpot and prize limits. 
    Bingo or guest games shall not exceed two (2) per week for an organization. There shall be no more than three (3) prizes or jackpots on any one day of play. Jackpots shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). All other game prizes shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00). (Code 1962, § 5A-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 849.093(4)-(6). 
Sec. 11-98. - Penalty provision. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct such games and to use the proceeds thereof except in strict compliance with F.S. section 849.093 and this chapter. Although the permit does not contain a termination date, the continuance of the permit from year to year is conditioned on the terms and provisions contained herein, and the permit may be revoked by official action of the town council after reasonable notice of violation to the organization. (Code 1962, § 5A-8) 
Secs. 11-99-11-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VENDING MACHINES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Signs and advertising, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 11-120. - Business tax receipt-Display and contents. 
    A business tax receipt issued under the provisions of the applicable portion of section 11-28 of this Code shall be securely pasted to the machine for which such business tax receipt has been issued; same shall bear the serial number of such machine and shall be signed by the appropriate town official and shall have affixed thereto the official town seal. 
(Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 3, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-121. - Same-Removal or misuse. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove any business tax receipt for a vending machine from the machine upon which such business tax receipt has been affixed, or to place the business tax receipt for one machine upon any other machine. 
(Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 3, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-122. - Same-Rebates prohibited. 
    No rebate shall be made upon any vending machine business tax receipt because of the loss or destruction of the machine, or its discontinuance from operation. 
(Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 3, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-123. - Location of vending machines. 
(a)  Applicability. As used herein, "vending machine" shall include every machine, excluding newsracks, dispensing merchandise of any kind or nature, including but not limited to food, drinks, accessories, novelties and photographs, upon the insertion or depositing of coins or currency; or dispensing the same or similar goods free of charge. 
(b)  Outdoors. Vending machines shall not be allowed to be placed or operated within the town unless or until a permit has been issued by the town. Such permit shall be issued upon payment of a permit fee and in accordance with the regulations set forth herein and in section 11-28 of this Code. 
(c)  On right-of-way. No vending machine shall be permitted to encroach upon any public sidewalk, street, thoroughfare, or right-of-way. 
(d)  Residential districts. No vending machine may be located in any single-family residential district within the town. (Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-124. - Newsracks-Defined. 
    The term "newsracks, " as used in this article, is defined as a machine dispensing newspapers or other reading materials upon the insertion or depositing of coins or currency, or free of charge. (Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-125. - Same-Prohibited on roadways. 
    No person shall install, use or maintain any newsrack which projects onto, into or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests, wholly or in part, upon, along or over any portion of a roadway. 
(Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-126. - Same-Prohibited in certain cases on sidewalks, parkways. 
    No person shall install, use or maintain any newsrack which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any sidewalk or parkway, when such installation, use or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property; or when such site or location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes, or other government use; or when such newsrack unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, the ingress into or egress from any residences, place of business, or any legally parked or stopped vehicle, or the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes or other objects permitted on or near said location; or when such newsrack interferes with the cleaning of any sidewalk by the use of any mechanical sidewalk cleaning machinery or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-127. - Same-Standards when located on sidewalks, parkways. 
    Any newsrack which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any sidewalk or parkway shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  No newsrack shall exceed four (4) feet in height, two (2) feet in width, or two (2) feet in depth. 
(2)  Newsracks shall only be placed near a curb or adjacent to the wall of a building. Newsracks placed near the curb shall be placed no less than eighteen (18) inches nor more than twenty-four (24) inches from the edge of the curb. Newsracks placed adjacent to the wall of a building shall be parallel to such wall and not more than six (6)inches from the wall. No newsrack shall be placed or maintained on a sidewalk or parkway opposite a newsstand or other newsrack. 
(3)  No newsrack shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any property not owned by the owner of the newsrack. 
(4)  Newsracks may be chained or otherwise attached to one another; however, not more than three (3) newsracks may be joined together in this manner, and a space of not less than eighteen (18) inches shall separate each group of three (3) newsracks so attached. 
(5)  No newsrack or group of attached newsracks allowed under subsection (4) hereof shall weigh, in the aggregate, in excess of one hundred (100) pounds when empty. 
(6)  No newsrack shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
a.  Within five (5) feet of any marked crosswalk. 
b.  Within fifteen (15) feet of the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk. 
c.  Within three (3) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, or other emergency facility. 
d.  Within five (5) feet of any driveway. 
e.  Within five (5) feet ahead and fifteen (15) feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop. 
f.  Within five (5) feet of any bus bench. 
g.  At any location where the clear space for passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than six (6) feet. 
h.  Within five (5) feet of any area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs or trees, or within five (5) feet of any display window of any building abutting the sidewalk or parkway in such a manner as to impede or interfere with the reasonable use of such window for display purposes. 
(7)  No newsrack shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than that dealing with the display, sale or purpose of the newspaper or news periodical sold therein; or dispensed free of charge. 
(8)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a clean and neat condition and in good repair at all times. (Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-128. - Same-Information to be shown on rack. 
    Every person who places or maintains a newsrack on the streets of the town shall have his name, address and telephone number affixed thereto in a place where such information may be easily seen. (Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 11-129. - Same-Violations; penalties. 
    Any newsrack, installed or maintained in violation of this Code shall, if the owner thereof fails or refuses to correct the violation within ten (10) days of written notices of the violation, subject the owner of the newsrack to the penalties provided for in Section 1-12 of this Code and/or to the jurisdiction of the code enforcement board of the town. (Ord. No. O-2-88, § 1, 2-8-88) 
Secs. 11-130-11-140. - Reserved.
