ARTICLE VIII. - ADDITIONAL EXCISE OR LICENSE TAXES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. O-4-89, adopted Mar. 13, 1989, amended Ch. 11 by adding a new Art. VII thereto as well as § 11-135. Inasmuch as there already existed an Art. VII, the editor has redesignated the new provisions as Art. VIII, § 11-155. 
Cross reference- Occupational license taxes, § 11-16 et seq. 

Sec. 11-155. - Property insurance. 
    That there is hereby assessed, imposed, and levied on every insurance company, corporation, or other insurer now engaged in or carry on, or who shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of property insurance as shown by the records of the state department of insurance an excise tax in addition to any lawful license or excise tax now levied by the town, which tax shall be in the amount of one and eighty-five hundredths (1.85) percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on property insurance policies, covering property within the corporate limits of the town. In the case of multiple-peril policies with a single premium for both property and casualty coverages in such policies, seventy (70) percent of such premium shall be used as the basis for the one and eighty-five hundredths (1.85) percent tax. This license or excise tax herein levied shall be due and payable annually on the first day of March in each year hereafter. (Ord. No. O-4-89, § 1, 3-13-89) 
Note- See the editor's footnote to the title of this article. 
State Law reference- Municipal firefighters' pension trust fund, F.S. Ch. 175; premium tax, F.S. § 175.101. 
Sec. 11-156. - Casualty insurance. 
    That there is hereby assessed, imposed, and levied on every insurance company, corporation, or other insurer now engaged in or carrying on, or who shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of casualty insurance as shown by the records of the state department of insurance, an excise tax in addition to any lawful license or excise tax now levied by the town, which tax shall be in the amount of eighty-five hundredths (0.85) percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies covering property within the corporate limits of the town. In the case of multiple-peril policies with a single premium for both property and casualty coverages in such policies, thirty (30) percent of such premium shall be used as the basis for the eighty-five hundredths (0.85) percent tax. This license or excise tax herein levied shall be due and payable annually on the first day of March in each year hereafter. 
(Ord. No. O-5-89, § 1, 3-13-89) 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of this article. 
State Law reference- Municipal police officers' retirement trust fund, F.S. Ch. 185; premium tax, F.S. § 185.08. 
Secs. 11-157-11-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CONVENIENCE STORES 

Sec. 11-160. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "convenience store" means any place of business that is engaged in the retail sale of groceries, including the sale of prepared foods, and gasoline and services, that is regularly open for business at any time, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., and that is attended during such hours by one (1) employee. The term "convenience store" does not include a store which is solely or primarily a restaurant. 
(Ord. No. O-2-91, § 1, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 11-161. - Convenience store security. 
    Each convenience store located within the corporate limits of the town shall: 
(1)  Be equipped with the following security devices: 
a.  A silent alarm that notifies local law enforcement or a private security agency that a robbery is taking place; 
b.  A security camera system capable of returning an image to assist in the identification and apprehension of a robber; and 
c.  A drop safe or cash management device that provides minimum access to the facility's cash receipts; 
(2)  Lighted parking lots illuminated at an intensity of two (2) foot-candles per square foot with a uniformity ratio of no more than five (5) to one (1) at eighteen (18) inches above the surface; 
(3)  Post a conspicuous sign in the convenience store entrance which states that the cash register contains fifty dollars ($50.00) or less; 
(4)  Maintain window signage so that there is a clear and unobstructed view of the cash register and transaction area; 
(5)  Prohibit window tinting on the windows of the establishment if such tinting reduces exterior or interior viewing during the hours of operation to which this article is applicable; 
(6)  Install height markers at the entrance of the establishment which display height measures from the floor; and 
(7)  Establish a cash management policy to limit the amount of available cash on hand between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. O-2-91, § 1, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 11-162. - Training of employees. 
    No later than June 30, 1991, the owner or principal operator of a convenience store shall provide proper robbery deterrence and safety training to [all] its employees who work between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. The convenience store owner or operator may utilize a training program of his or her choice, however, said program must be submitted in writing to the attorney general for approval. 
(Ord. No. O-2-91, § 1, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 11-163. - Noncompliance. 
    Should any convenience store fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article, written notice shall be mailed to the owner and principal operator of the store requesting compliance within ten (10) days. 
    If noncompliance with this article is corrected within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice of said noncompliance, no further action will be taken. However, any owner or principal operator of a convenience store who fails to comply after the ten-day written notice shall be determined to have willfully and deliberately violated the requirements of this article which shall be enforced through the code enforcement board or code enforcement citation system or shall be assessed a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day, not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) which shall constitute a civil fine and which shall be paid to the town upon a complaint being filed by the town with the appropriate court. 
(Ord. No. O-2-91, § 1, 4-22-91) 
Secs. 11-164-11-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PAY TELEPHONE INSTALLATION 

Sec. 11-191. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide standards for the following: 
The erection, construction, reconstruction, installation, operation, maintenance, dismantling, testing, repair and use of pay telephones in, upon, along, across, above, over, under or in any manner connected with public lands and/or the streets and/or sidewalks within the corporate limits of the town, as now or in the future may exist. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-192. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article and any agreement or permit entered into or issued in accordance herewith, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall be defined as follows: 
    Department shall mean the building department of the town. 
    Official shall mean the building official of the town or his/her designee. 
    Pay telephone shall mean any self-service or coin or credit card operated telephone, including any enclosure, or bank of such telephones placed adjacent to each other, that in any manner is connected with public lands and/or the public streets and/or sidewalks within the town. 
    Pay telephone permit agreement shall mean the document by which a privilege is granted by the town to authorize a person to erect, construct, reconstruct, install, operate, maintain, dismantle, test, repair and use pay telephones which occupy any public lands and/or the streets and/or sidewalks within the town. Any pay telephone permit agreement approved in accordance herewith shall be nonexclusive and shall be subject to approval as to form by the town attorney. 
    Permittee shall mean any person issued a permit in accordance with the provisions of this article who is responsible for the erection, construction, reconstruction, installation, operation, maintenance, dismantling, testing, repair and use of pay telephones in any manner connected with the streets and/or sidewalks within the town. 
    Person shall mean an individual, business, firm, corporation, association, partnership or other organization or group of persons. 
    Sidewalk shall mean that area reserved for the public use of pedestrian traffic within the town's rights-of-way. 
    Street shall mean all that area reserved for the public use for public right-of-way purposes and shall include, but not be limited to: highways, avenues, roads, drives, lanes, boulevards, courts, concourses, bridges, culs-de-sac, tunnels, waterways, parks, roadways, parkways and alleys. 
    Town shall mean the Town of Lantana, Florida, its elected officials, its agents and employees. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-193. - Pay telephone permit agreement required. 
(a)  No person may place or maintain any pay telephone on or above any street or sidewalk in the corporate limits of the town without having first entered into a pay telephone permit agreement with the town as provided in this article, having obtained a business tax receipt as a public utility service provider and having paid all applicable permit fees. 
(b)  Any pay telephone permit issued by the town shall continue in full force and effect so long as the permittee is in compliance with this article, all applicable federal, state and local ordinances and regulations are followed and the space occupied is not needed for public purposes. Failure to comply with any applicable ordinances or laws, or failure to pay required fees, including annual renewal fees, shall result in automatic revocation of any permit issued and immediate removal of the pay telephone(s). 
(c)  In the event any pay telephone permit shall be revoked or shall lapse, the applicable pay telephone(s) shall be removed from the streets and/or sidewalks by the former permittee in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98; Ord. No. O-12-06, § 4, 9-11-06) 
Sec. 11-194. - Permit locations. 
(a)  Any pay telephone permit issued in accordance herewith shall apply only to the location stated on same. 
(b)  The exact location and means of installation of pay telephones shall be subject to the department's approval. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as a representation, promise or guarantee by the town that any other permit or other authorization required under any town ordinance for the installation of pay telephone(s) shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-195. - Technical standards. 
    All technical standards governing construction, reconstruction, installation, operation, maintenance, dismantling, testing, repair and use of pay telephones provided for herein shall be in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, including but not limited to the most recent editions of the Building Code and the Electrical Code adopted by the town. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-196. - Powers and duties of the building official. 
    The building official shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To receive and review applications for pay telephone permits; and 
(2)  To review and cause to be audited all reports and filings submitted by the permittee to the town pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-197. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  A building permit fee shall be required for the installation of each pay telephone which utilizes public [publicly] owned lands or public rights-of-way. Such building permit may not be issued until a pay telephone permit agreement, as referenced in section 11-193 hereinabove, has been fully executed and submitted to the department along with applicable fees. The amount of the pay telephone permit agreement fee, annual renewal fee, and any and all other applicable fees shall be set by resolution of the town council and may be amended from time to time, as necessary. 
(b)  Any pay telephones currently existing on public lands or within the public rights-of-way must make application for a permit within three (3) months of the date of adoption of this article. Failure to comply shall result in removal of the pay telephone. 
(c)  Failure to pay all fees on a timely basis shall result in automatic revocation of the permit and removal of the pay telephone in accordance with section 11-193. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-198. - Other fees; taxes. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit the liability of the permittee for all applicable federal, state and local taxes and/or fees. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-199. - Use of streets and/or sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for the permittee or any other person to open or otherwise disturb the surface of any street and/or sidewalk for any purpose whatsoever without obtaining approval to do so after having been issued a building permit for the construction or installation work. Additionally, a pay telephone permit agreement must be fully executed and submitted to the town along with the then applicable pay telephone permit agreement fee prior to the commencement of any installation. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-200. - Location and placement of pay telephones. 
(a)  The installation of pay telephones in any manner connected with the streets and/or sidewalks within the town shall be subject to approval by the building department and shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  It shall be free of interference with the flow of pedestrians, wheelchairs or vehicular traffic; 
(2)  It shall allow ingress or egress from any residence or place of business; 
(3)  It shall be free of interference with the function of traffic signs or signals, hydrants or mailboxes. 
(b)  Pay telephones shall be placed or otherwise secured, so as to prevent their being blown down or around the street and/or sidewalk, but they shall not be chained or otherwise secured to any traffic or street signs, signals, hydrants, mailboxes or other street amenities. 
(c)  Pay telephones shall be placed, installed, used or maintained so as to be in compliance with the town Code and shall not be located within five (5) feet of any pedestrian crosswalk, bus stop, taxistand or counter window or within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box or other emergency facility. 
(d)  The following minimum distance requirement, measured along the route of ordinary pedestrian travel, shall apply: Unless approved in writing by the building official, no pay telephone shall be placed within three hundred (300) feet of any other pay telephone or telephone bank on the same side of the street on a sidewalk in a multifamily, commercial or industrial zoning district as described in Chapter 23, Zoning. 
(e)  Pay telephones shall not be installed in the R1A, R1 or R3 residential zoning districts as described in Chapter 23, Zoning. 
(f)  Should the location and/or use of a pay telephone constitute a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the community in the opinion of the building official, the permit issued by the building department shall be revoked after ten (10) days' written notice to the permittee and the pay telephone shall be removed from the street or sidewalk at the expense of the permittee. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-201. - Standards for maintenance, installation and operation of pay telephones. 
    Pay telephones shall comply with the requirements of all applicable federal, state and local laws, including the applicable provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1992 and the following standards: 
(1)  Pay telephone enclosures surrounding pay telephones shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height, four (4) feet in width or four (4) feet depth. 
(2)  Pay telephone enclosures shall be lighted by means of low voltage lighting. 
(3)  Pay telephones shall be equipped with coin return mechanisms to permit a person using the pay telephone to secure an immediate refund when there is a busy signal or no answer to a call placed. The coin return mechanism shall be maintained in good working order. 
(4)  Each pay telephone shall have affixed to it, in a place visible to everyone using the pay telephone, the name and address of the permittee, and the telephone number of a working service to report a malfunction of the pay telephone or to secure a refund. 
(5)  The design of all pay telephone enclosures, including signage, shall be subject to the approval of the building department. 
(6)  Pay telephones shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times. 
(7)  Any permittee who fails to maintain its pay telephone in working condition may be given a 30-day written notice by the building department to repair the pay telephone. If the pay telephone is not in working condition at the end of the 30-day period after proper notice is given, the building department may revoke the permit and the pay telephone shall be removed by the former permittee or by the town. If the town removes same, it shall be stored within a town facility. The town does not assume any liability for damage to the equipment removed and stored pursuant to this subsection. Any permittee whose pay telephone(s) has been removed and stored by the town pursuant to this subsection may reclaim said pay telephone(s) after payment to the town of the total costs incurred for its removal and storage. 
(8)  Permittee shall within thirty (30) days after prior written request is given by the building department, seek permission from the public service commission to restrict the pay telephone to outgoing calls. Permittee shall restrict the calls to outgoing calls within ten (10) days after receiving permission from the public service commission to do so. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-202. - Free of charge calls; posting rates; refund information. 
(a)  All pay telephones shall permit the following calls to be placed free of charge: 
(1)  Calls to the 911 emergency number; 
(2)  Emergency calls placed through operator assistance to the police and fire departments; 
(b)  Current local coin call initial rates shall be posted on the pay telephone or on the pay telephone enclosure and shall not exceed the amount established by the public service commission. 
(c)  An instruction card containing information regarding refunds and type of calls which may be made from a pay telephone shall be posted on a conspicuous place on the pay telephone or on the pay telephone enclosure. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Sec. 11-203. - Compliance required for existing pay telephones; existing agreements exempt. 
    All existing pay telephones shall comply with the requirements of this article within sixty (60) days of its effective date, however, those pay telephones installed pursuant to an existing agreement with the town, need not comply with the provisions of this article until the expiration date of said existing agreement(s). Any pay telephone(s) not in compliance by the date prescribed hereinabove shall be removed in accordance with the procedure outlined in this article. 
(Ord. No. O-06-98, § 1, 8-24-98) 
Chapter 12 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-46; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; discharging of certain matter into the water prohibited, § 5-33; use of vessels for dwelling purposes prohibited in certain areas, § 5-41; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; satellite dish antenna regulations, § 6-66 et seq.; radio and television antennas, § 6-81 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 11; garage sale restrictions, § 11-66 et seq.; offenses, Ch. 13; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; signs and advertising, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 21; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Public nuisances, F.S. Ch. 386. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Depositing, throwing litter, rubbish, debris, etc.-Prohibited; removal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally scatter any litter, rubbish or debris, or to throw or permit to be deposited or scattered the same upon any public property. These prohibitions to not apply to lawful placement of garbage/refuse as may be authorized under Chapter 9 of the Town Code. 
(b)  All lands in the town shall be kept free from litter, rubbish, debris and vegetation including trees or any other matter which by reason of height, proximity to neighboring structures, physical condition or other peculiar characteristics might in time of hurricane winds prevalent in this region cause injury to life or damage property within the immediate area surrounding such region. The existence of any litter, rubbish, debris, vegetation or other matter as shall create such a hazard is declared to be a public nuisance and a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 13-10) 
Cross reference- Illegal disposal of garbage, etc., § 9-17; licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 11; subdivisions, Ch. 17.5. 
Sec. 12-2. - Same-Notice; lien. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to notify any person who commits a nuisance as defined in section 12-1 if he can be found. If he cannot be found, then a copy of the notice shall be mailed to his last known address, if any, and a copy posted upon the lot or land of the person requiring him to abate such nuisance. If such person does not abate the nuisance within ten (10) days after notice and opportunity to be heard, the town council may by its duly authorized agent abate such nuisance at its expense and shall have a lien on such lot or land for the amount so expended, together with interest at the legal rate from the date of such expenditure. The lien shall be enforced as provided by law for the enforcement of special assessment liens. 
(Code 1962, § 13-9) 
Sec. 12-3. - Abatement procedures. 
(a)  All property and structures, including all swale areas, which contain conditions that constitute a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare or which are improperly maintained as required under this Code to the extent that the property or structure constitute a hazard or an otherwise dangerous or unsightly condition is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated by the town by repair and/or rehabilitation or demolition in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  When the code inspector determines that any property or structure constitutes a public nuisance defined above or as in any other section of the Town Code, the code inspector shall notify the owner of the property or structure of the violations and the repairs or other actions which are necessary to bring the property or structure into compliance with Town Code. Enforcement proceedings to correct and/or abate nuisances shall generally be conducted in accordance with article IV, code of enforcement of chapter 2, administration, of the Town Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Upon a finding by the special magistrate that a nuisance exists and the issuance of a nuisance abatement order the town may proceed to abate said nuisance. 
(3)  If the town abates any nuisance, the actual cost thereof shall be billed to the owner in the same manner as provided for in section one (1) above. The bill shall state that the amount due must be paid within twenty-one (21) days of the billing date, which date shall be reflected on the bill. 
(4)  If the owner fails or refuses to pay the full amount due, the costs incurred by the town may be assessed against the property as authorized by section 12-5 hereinbelow. All assessments shall be paid in full no later than the close of town business on the twenty-first (21 st ) day after the property owner has received notice of the assessment. Thereafter, the unpaid amount of the assessment will accrue interest at the maximum rate allowed by law. 
(b)  The provisions of this section are not exclusive and are available to the town in addition to any other remedies and/or penalties provided by state statute, town ordinance or by this chapter. 
(c)  The town shall have the right to seek a civil injunction against the owner and/or occupant of the property or structure for any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2014, § 1, 1-27-14) 
Sec. 12-4. - Notice of assessment. 
    Upon completion of the abatement of a nuisance undertaken by the town, the town shall notify in writing the property owner that a special assessment has been imposed on the property. The notice shall be delivered to the owner, and if applicable, the agent, custodian, lessee, or occupant in the manner set forth delivery of the notice of violation in section 2-57 of the Town Code of Ordinances. 
    The notice of assessment shall set forth the following: 
(a)  A description of the violation, a description of the actions taken by the town to abate the nuisance, and the fact that the property has been assessed for the costs incurred by the town in abating the nuisance; 
(b)  The aggregate amount of such costs and an itemized list of such costs; 
(c)  The intent of the town to place the assessment on the tax bill as a non-ad valorem assessment if not paid by June 1 st ; 
(d)  The potential for the property to be subject to the sale of a tax certificate bearing interest at a rate as high as eighteen (18) percent per annum, if the non-ad valorem assessment is not paid as part of the tax bill on the property; and 
(e)  The potential for the property to be sold and conveyed by tax deed if the tax certificate is not redeemed by payment of the non-ad valorem assessment in full, plus interest, as required by Florida law. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2014, § 2, 1-27-14) 
Sec. 12-5. - Assessments for abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  Establishment of special assessment district. The Town of Lantana, in its entirety, as its town boundaries exist of the date of enactment of this section and as they may be expanded or contracted from time to time, is hereby declared a special assessment district for the purposes of abating nuisances prohibited by this chapter or Town Code. Individual properties within the town's boundaries, as they may exist from time to time, may be assessed for the costs incurred by the town in abating nuisances prohibited by this chapter or Town Code. 
(b)  Levy of non-ad valorem assessments. There is hereby levied, and the town council is authorized to levy from time to time, a non ad-valorem assessment against each and every property in the town (i) on which there occurs or has occurred a violation of this chapter or Town Code, (ii) the town undertakes or has undertaken action pursuant to this chapter or Town Code to abate the nuisance and, thereby, incurs or has incurred costs, and (iii) the property owners fails or refuses or has failed or refused, for whatever reason, to pay timely the amount owed to the town under this chapter or Town Code for the costs incurred by the town in carrying out such abatement. The assessment for the abatement of a nuisance shall constitute a lien upon the parcels so assessed equal in rank and dignity with the liens of all state, county, district or municipal taxes and non-ad valorem assessments. Except as otherwise provided by law, such lien shall be superior in dignity to all other liens, titles and claims, until paid. The lien for the nuisance abatement assessment shall be deemed perfected upon adoption by the town council of its annual resolution and shall attach to the property included on the assessment roll as of the prior January 1, the lien date for ad valorem taxes. 
(c)  Collection of non-ad valorem assessments. The town council elects to use the uniform method to impose and collect non-ad valorem assessments against properties on which nuisances occur or have occurred. The non-ad valorem assessments collected pursuant to this chapter will be included in the combined notice of ad valorem taxes and non-ad valorem assessments as provided in F.S. § 197.3635. Non-ad valorem assessments collected pursuant to this section are subject to all collection provisions in F.S. § 197.3632, including provisions relating to discount for early payment, prepayment by installment method, deferred payment, penalty for delinquent payment, and issuance and sale of tax certificates and tax deeds for nonpayment. 
(d)  Agreement to reimburse Palm Beach County Property Appraiser and Palm Beach County Tax Collector. In order to utilize the uniform method for the levy, collection, and enforcement of the non-ad valorem assessments, the town is authorized to enter into a written agreement with the Palm Beach County Property Appraiser and the Palm Beach County Tax Collector for the reimbursement of their costs incurred in the administration and collections of the non-ad valorem assessments levied under this chapter. 
(e)  Annual non-ad valorem assessment roll. Each year the town council will approve a non-ad valorem assessment roll at a public hearing between January 1 and September 15. The non-ad valorem assessment roll will be comprised of properties that have had levied against them non-ad valorem assessments under this chapter, and such assessments have not otherwise been paid in full prior to approval of the roll. The finance director is authorized and directed each year (i) to prepare the notice that must be provided as required by F.S. § 197.3632, and (ii) to prepare and publish the notice required by F.S. § 197.3632. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2014, § 3, 1-27-14) 
Secs. 12-6-12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOISE 

Sec. 12-16. - Purpose. 
    The intent and purpose of this article is to eliminate, regulate and restrict sources and occurrences of noise and disturbances which interfere with the peaceful enjoyment of residential property and which are contrary to public welfare and constitute a nuisance to the public at large. 
(Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, 5-12-86) 
Sec. 12-17. - Definitions. 
    Ambient noise means the all-encompassing noise associated with a given environment, being a composite of sounds from many sources at a given location. Certain zoning districts, therefore, will have varying ambient noise levels associated with the uses permitted in such districts. 
    Loud and raucous noise means any sound which because of its volume level, duration and character disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities within the limits of the town. This term includes the kinds of noise generated by the activities enumerated in section 12-19, whenever such loud noise is also "raucous", as characterized by noise's accompanying rough-sounding, harsh, boisterous and disorderly qualities. 
(Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, 12-8-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, repealed § 12-17, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 12-17 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, adopted May 12, 1986; and Ord. No. O-05-94, § 1, adopted Dec. 12, 1994. 
Sec. 12-18. - Noise limitations; generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or create any loud and raucous noise which disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities anywhere within the town. The term "disturbs" shall be interpreted objectively to mean that there is an actual or imminent interference with peace or good order or that the noise would unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of persons in the vicinity thereof. The phrase "loud and raucous" shall be interpreted objectively by considering the volume, intensity and duration of the noise; whether the noise is usual or unusual for the location; and the volume and intensity of the ambient noise at the location. Additionally, the fact that the property from which the noise originates is adjacent to a waterfront area shall be a factor for consideration as to whether a neighborhood is being unreasonably impacted by noise, (i.e. whether such sounds are audible across the water in residentially zoned neighborhoods situated across the water from commercially zoned waterfront businesses due to unbroken air spaces across the span of water and the unique characteristics of the transmission of sound across water surfaces). Alleged noise violations shall be reviewed in accordance with a "reasonable person" standard. 
(Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, 12-8-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, repealed § 12-18, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 12-18 pertained to noise limitations and derived from Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, adopted May 12, 1986; and Ord. No. O-05-94, § 1, adopted Dec. 12, 1994. 
Sec. 12-19. - Prohibitions; categories of noise prohibitions: special regulations for mixed use zoning districts. 
    The following activities are prohibited when such are found to unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of persons in the audible vicinity thereof. In addition, a rebuttable presumption exists that the ambient noise level of the town is reduced during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays and on Sundays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight; and the ambient noise level at the time the noise is created shall be considered in an objective determination as to whether the noise levels are loud and raucous causing actual or imminent interference with the general peace and good order: 
(a)  Commercial, industrial, manufacturing, and construction noise. It shall be unlawful for any commercial, industrial, construction or manufacturing activities to be conducted within the town in such a manner that the noise resulting from such activity is determined to be unreasonably loud and raucous, and the reasonableness of such commercial, industrial, construction or manufacturing noise will be determined, in part, based upon the rebuttable presumption that the ambient noise level of the town is significantly reduced within the residential zoning districts R1A, R1, R3, and R15 during the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays and during the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on Saturdays and Sundays and on designated Town holidays, and for all other zoning districts during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Furthermore, in determining whether unreasonably loud and raucous noise is associated with specific construction activities, the reasonableness of the noise will be determined, in part, based upon the presumption that such construction noise is normally associated with work done between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Finally, all such activities addressed in this subsection shall be conducted in a controlled manner so as not to create unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, and disturbing noise or any like noise which is a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility. 
(b)  Noise from buildings, premises or property. No person owning or in possession or control of any building or premises shall use the same or rent the same to be used for any business or employment or residential use or for the purpose of pleasure or recreation, if such use shall, by its nature, be loud and raucous and thereby unreasonably disturb the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises is situated. 
(c)  Radios, electronic audio equipment and musical instruments. No person shall use, operate or play any radio, phonograph, stereo set, tape player, television set, sound amplifier or other electronic audio device or any musical instrument, whether amplified or not, which produces or reproduces sound in such a manner as to cause loud and raucous noise and thereby unreasonably disturbs the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises is situated. The reasonableness of the musical sound/noise will be determined, in part, based upon the rebuttable presumption that the ambient noise level of the town is reduced between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Unreasonable noise caused by operation of radios or other mechanical soundmaking devices within a motor vehicle shall be regulated by the provisions of state law as set forth at F.S. § 316.3045. 
(d)  Noisy and boisterous conduct. It shall be unlawful to knowingly and willfully cause or create loud and raucous noise by engaging in boisterous, jarring, noisy and loud conduct while upon a public street, sidewalk or parkway, so as to unreasonably disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, store, dwelling, hotel, motel or residence within the area of audibility. 
(e)  Nuisance by noise emitted by animals. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having custody of any animal, domestic or otherwise, to permit such animal to create a nuisance by making loud and raucous noises which unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(f)  Noise determinations within the mixed use zoning districts. In making determinations as to whether violations regarding the above-referenced prohibitions (a) through (e) have occurred in the mixed use zoning districts, as defined at sections 23-101-23-104., the nature of this type of zoning district, representing a uniquely planned mix of uses to provide for residential, commercial and business uses situated in close proximity to each other, shall be considered as an additional factor in the determination as to the "reasonableness" of the noise created. Furthermore, the fact of the placement of the "MW waterfront mixed use district" adjacent to the waterfront shall also be a factor for consideration as to which neighborhoods are being unreasonably impacted by noises created within the MW district. (i.e. whether such sounds are audible across the water in other zoning districts situated across from the MW district due to the unbroken air spaces across the span of water and the unique characteristics of the transmission of sound across such water surfaces.) 
(Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, 12-8-03; Ord. No. O-1-2016, § 2, 1-11-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, repealed § 12-17, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 12-17 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, adopted May 12, 1986; and Ord. No. O-05-94, § 3, adopted Dec. 12, 1994. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 351.03(3)(a). 
Sec. 12-20. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sound emitted from the operation of motor vehicles legally operating on any public right-of-way which are regulated by Chapter 316, Florida Statutes, Uniform Traffic Control Law; provided, however, that this exemption shall not operate to exempt any sound-emitting device which may be physically attached to any motor vehicles, such as radios, amplifiers, loudspeakers or other similar devices. 
(2)  Any noise generated by interstate motor and rail carriers and aircraft or airport operations. Any other subjects to the extent preempted by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(3)  Any noise generated as a result of emergency work or for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of any emergency. 
(4)  Any noise generated by any public speaking or public assembly activities conducted in accordance with a duly authorized license or permit. 
(O-12-86, § 2, 5-12-86) 
Sec. 12-21. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  The procedure for enforcing the provisions of this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  If the noise level is determined to be in violation of this article, the appropriate town official shall give a warning to the person, persons and/or entity responsible for the unreasonably loud and raucous noise. 
(2)  If the unreasonably loud and raucous noise is not abated within a reasonable time after warning, a notice of violation by the appropriate town official shall be issued. 
(b)  This article may be enforced by citation to the code enforcement board or special magistrate and/or through any other lawful means available to the town to regulate unreasonably loud and raucous noises existing in violation of this article. No one (1) means of enforcement shall be the exclusive remedy. 
(Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, 12-8-03; Ord. No. O-05-2019, § 1, 1-28-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-10-03, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, repealed § 12-21, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 12-21 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, adopted May 12, 1986; and Ord. No. O-05-94, § 4, adopted Dec. 12, 1994. 
Sec. 12-22. - Variance procedure. 
    Any person desiring to be exempt from the provisions of this article may apply for a variance in order to allow the creation of noise that would otherwise be in violation of this article. The town council may grant a variance upon a showing by the applicant that: 
(1)  Additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify the activity in order to comply with the provisions of this article; or 
(2)  The activity, operation or noise source will be a temporary duration and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with the provisions of this article; and 
(3)  No reasonable alternative is available to the applicant. Any variance granted pursuant to this section shall contain thereon all conditions upon which such variance has been granted, including, but not limited to, the effective date, time of day, location, sound level limit, or equipment limitation and duration of variance. 
(Ord. No. O-12-86, § 2, 5-12-86) 
Secs. 12-23-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOTS AND LANDS CLEARING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; excavation of land procedure, § 6-51 et seq. 

Sec. 12-31. - Permitting accumulation of refuse; nuisance. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any lot or piece of ground in the town to suffer or permit any stagnant water, filth, refuse matter, animal or vegetable, or any putrid or unwholesome substance to accumulate thereon, or to suffer or permit any stable, hen house, dog kennel or any place where any animals are kept, or any water closet or septic tank thereon to become in such a condition as to emit offensive odors and be injurious or dangerous to the health of the neighborhood. Any such condition above described is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and the same shall be abated. 
(Code 1962, § 13-7) 
Sec. 12-32. - Trash and weeds; declared nuisance. 
    Deposit of accumulated trash, of whatever nature, growth of weeds, grass, or other vegetative matter which exhibits an unkempt appearance or which exceeds twelve (12) inches in height, or a rank vegetable growth which exhales unpleasant or noxious odors, or high or rank vegetable growth that may conceal filthy deposits or which is conducive to harboring vermin or other harmful creatures upon any lot, piece or parcel of land within the town, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1962, § 12-22; Ord. No. O-8-93, § 1, 1O-25-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-33. - Weeds and undergrowth, nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any occupant, owner or agent of any lot or piece of land in this town to suffer or permit any weeds, undergrowth or brush to grow or remain on such lot or piece of land, or on the street or alley abutting thereon so as to be or become dangerous or detrimental to the health or safety of the inhabitants, and the commission of any of the acts herein prohibited is declared to be a nuisance and shall be abated. 
(Code 1962, § 13-8) 
Sec. 12-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-02-2014, § 4, adopted January 27, 2014, repealed § 12-34, which pertained to surveys of real property by town manager; notice to abate and derived from the Code of 1962, § 12-24 and Ord. No. O-8-93, adopted October 25, 1993.

ARTICLE IV. - JUNKED AND ABANDONED VEHICLES AND APPLIANCES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, adopted Sept 12, 2011, amended Art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. IV, §§ 12-51-12-55, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from: Code 1962, §§ 12-27-12-31; and Ord. No. O-23-86, §§ 1-4, adopted Nov. 10, 1986. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; offenses, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Seized, abandoned, wrecked or derelict property, F.S. Ch. 705; reporting of towed motor vehicles, F.S. § 715.05; Florida Junkyard Control Law, F.S. § 339.241. 

Sec. 12-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle or appliance is any vehicle or appliance, as defined herein, which is not located in an enclosed building, is in a state of disuse, neglect or abandonment, and whose owner cannot be located with reasonable inquiry. 
    Appliance is any of the following household goods: Kitchen stove or oven; radar range, automatic garbage packer, dishwasher, refrigerator, freezer, washing machine, clothes dryer, television set, stereo or high fidelity console unit, air conditioner, or other similar device. 
    Article is any appliance or vehicle as defined herein. 
    Code enforcement officer shall mean those authorized agents or employees of the town whose duty it is to insure code compliance. 
    Department is the police department of the town. 
    Junked vehicle or appliance is any vehicle or appliance, as defined herein, which is not located in an enclosed building, is not fully shielded from public view, and is in a wrecked, junked, dismantled, partially dismantled, deteriorating, derelict or inoperative condition. Evidence that a vehicle or appliance is "wrecked, junked, dismantled, partially dismantled, deteriorating, derelict or inoperative" may include, but shall not be limited to, any one (1) or a combination of the following factors: 
(1)  The vehicle or appliance being wrecked; 
(2)  The vehicle or appliance being inoperative, as evidence by vegetation underneath as high as the vehicle or appliance body or frame; refuse or debris collected underneath; or, the vehicle or appliance being used solely for storage purposes; 
(3)  The vehicle or appliance being partially dismantled, having no visible engine, transmission, or other major parts; 
(4)  The vehicle or appliance having major and visible parts which are dismantled; 
(5)  The vehicle or appliance being incapable of functioning as a vehicle or appliance in its present state; 
(6)  The vehicle or appliance having only nominal salvage value; 
(7)  The vehicle being without either a valid and current vehicle license tag affixed thereto, which is properly registered to the vehicle upon which it is affixed, or if ownership of the vehicle does not require a license tag, then the vehicle being without a valid and current registration; 
(8)  The vehicle which, excluding its windows, windshield, and underside, is rusted on at least fifty (50) percent of its exterior body; or 
(9)  The vehicle being incapable of safe operation under its own power, or a vehicle that cannot be self-propelled or moved in a manner it was originally intended to move. 
    Nominal salvage value means a salvage value of not more than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) as appraised under standard practices by a salvage dealer or appraiser. 
    Not fully shielded from public view means not within a completely enclosed building or structure, which includes a wall to screen stored junked vehicles or appliances from public view and/or from the view of any adjoining or neighboring property. A vehicle covered with a car cover does not constitute enclosure of a vehicle. 
    Private property shall mean any real property within the town which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. 
    Public property shall mean any street or alley and shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purposes of vehicular travel, and shall also mean any realty dedicated to public use or owned in fee simple by the town. 
    Vehicle means any device, licensed or unlicensed, designed to travel along the ground or waterway and shall include, but not be limited to, watercraft, boats, ships, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, mobile homes, campers and trailers. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, 9-12-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-52. - Nuisance declared; exceptions. 
(a)  Declared. No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any junked vehicle or appliance as defined herein, or any abandoned vehicle or appliance, as defined herein, upon any public or private property within the town for a period of time in excess of seventy-two (72) hours. The presence of such junked or abandoned article on public or private property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Exception. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any vehicle or appliance completely enclosed and fully shielded from public view within a building on private property; 
(2)  Lawfully established salvage yards, junk yards, wrecking yards, storage yards or other similar establishments which are legally licensed and zoned for the operation of such types of businesses and which fully comply with all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations pertaining to the operation of such types of businesses; 
(3)  Vehicles or appliances, or parts thereof, stored or parked on private property solely for prompt repair at a duly licensed business or enterprise operated and conducted for the repair of vehicles or appliances in full compliance with applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, 9-12-11) 
Sec. 12-53. - Procedure for removal. 
(a)  Notice to remove. Whenever it comes to the attention of the department or code enforcement officer that any public nuisance as above-defined, exists on private property in the town, a notice of violation in writing shall be served upon the occupant of the private property, and upon the owner of such realty, if different than the occupant, in accordance with F.S. Ch. 162. The notice of violation shall describe the existence of the nuisance and request its removal in the time specified in this article. The notice of violation shall also be posted in a conspicuous place upon the article constituting the nuisance, or the private property on which the nuisance is located. If, through reasonable diligence, the town determines that a junked or abandoned vehicle is registered to a person or entity other than the owner or occupant of the private property on which the vehicle has been parked or stored, then the written notice of violation shall also be served upon the registered owner of such vehicle via certified mail, return receipt requested, and regular mail at their last known address. In cases involving a junked or abandoned vehicle on public property, written notice of removal shall be afforded by certified mail, return receipt requested, and regular mail to the registered owner of the vehicle at their last known address as described in subsection (g). 
(b)  Responsibility for removal. The owner of the junked or abandoned article, and where applicable, the owner or occupant of private property on which the same is located, either or all of them, shall be responsible for its removal. In the event of removal and disposition by the town, the owner of the article and owner or occupant of the realty where same was located shall be jointly and severally liable for all expenses incurred. 
(c)  Notice procedure. If the nuisance is located on private property, the department or code enforcement officer shall give the owner or occupant of the private property on which the article is located, or the registered owner of the vehicle if different than the occupant or owner of the private property, at least ten (10) days to cure the violation before the matter is set for a code enforcement hearing. In all cases, it shall constitute sufficient notice when a copy of same is posted in a conspicuous place upon the article constituting the nuisance, or the private property on which the nuisance is located, if applicable, and duplicate copies are sent by certified and regular mail to all persons required to receive notice under this article. If the nuisance is located on public property, the department or code enforcement officer is not required to give the owner of the article time to cure the violation, and may remove the article from the premises. 
(d)  Content of notice. If the nuisance is located on private property, the notice shall be in the following form: 
NOTICE OF VIOLATION 
TOWN OF LANTANA POLICE DEPARTMENT 
LANTANA, FLORIDA 
You are in violation of Section 12-52, Code of Ordinances, Town of Lantana, Florida, and are required thereby to remove the below-described article within ten (10) days from the date of this letter. 
Time _____ ___.m.       Date________________________________ 
By________________________________________________________________ 
Code Enforcement Officer Phone Number _________________________________________ 
Description of Article to Be Removed _____ 
Section 12-52(a) of the Lantana Code of Ordinances provides: 
No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any junked vehicle or appliance as defined herein, or any abandoned vehicle or appliance, as defined herein, upon any public or private property within the town for a period of time in excess of seventy-two (72) hours. The presence of such junked or abandoned article on public or private property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
If you fail to abate the nuisance within ten (10) days from the date of this letter, you are hereby notified to appear at the Town Council Chambers, Town of Lantana, 500 Greynolds Circle, Lantana, FL at _____ m. on the _____ day of ________, _____, at which time your case will be heard by the Code Enforcement Special Magistrate for the Town of Lantana. Failure to appear may result in adjudication and fine entered against you. 
If you agree that the vehicle, appliance, article and/or parts thereof are in violation and desire the article(s) to be removed from your property prior to the expiration of the ten-day period, please execute the attached release agreement form and return same immediately to the town clerk, along with the vehicle registration, if same can be located. 
Should you fail to remove the below-described article(s), it will be removed by the town after the code enforcement hearing and you will be liable to the town for all expenses incurred in said removal. Your failure to remove it is also punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day the violation continues past the date set for compliance for a first violation, and a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day the violation continues past the date set for compliance for a repeat violation.

(e)  Code enforcement hearing. If the nuisance is located on private property and the persons to whom the notices are directed fail to cure the violations within the time specified in the written notice, the town may set the matter for a code enforcement hearing before the code enforcement special magistrate for the town. The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable and persons to whom the notices are directed shall be advised of the time and place of said hearing at least ten (10) days in advance thereof. At such hearing the town and the persons to whom the notices have been directed may introduce such witnesses in evidence as either party deems necessary. The hearing will be conducted in accordance with F.S. Ch. 162. 
(f)  Removal of nuisance from property. If the nuisance is located on private property, and the existence of the violation is affirmed by the code enforcement special magistrate, the department or code enforcement officer shall have the right to take possession of the article and remove it from the premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose of removing an article under the provisions herein. If the nuisance is located on public property, the department or code enforcement officer shall have the right to take immediate possession of the article and remove it from the premises. 
(g)  Notice of removal. Within forty-eight (48) hours after removal, the department or code enforcement officer shall give notice to all persons required to receive notice under subsection (a) that the article has been impounded and stored for violation of this article. The notice shall give the location where the article is stored and the costs incurred by the town for removal. 
(h)  Waiver of due process rights. Any owner may waive his due process rights herein provided by signing the release agreement, as set forth above in subsection (d) hereof, to pay all removal expenses incurred by the town, and releasing the town of any and all liability. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, 9-12-11) 
State Law reference- Reporting of impounded, unclaimed motor vehicles, F.S. 715.05. 
Sec. 12-54. - Disposition of removed article. 
(a)  Generally. Upon removal under the provisions contained in this article, the town shall after ten (10) days cause it to be appraised. If the article is appraised at the nominal salvage value of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) or less, the department or code enforcement officer shall execute an affidavit so attesting and describing the article, including the license plates, if any, and stating its location and appraised value. The department or code enforcement officer, after complying with the above, may summarily dispose of the article and execute a certificate of sale or disposition. If the appraisal is over seventy-five dollars ($75.00), the department or code enforcement officer shall give notice of public sale not less than ten (10) days before the date of proposed sale. 
(b)  Contents of public sale notice. The notice of sale shall state: 
(1)  The sale is of abandoned or junked property in the possession of the town; 
(2)  A description of the article which will accurately identify it; 
(3)  The terms of the sale; 
(4)  The date, time and place of sale. 
(c)  Public sale. The article shall be sold to the highest and best bidder. At the time of payment of the purchase price, the department or code enforcement officer shall execute a certificate of sale in duplicate. The original of which is to be given to the purchaser, and the copy thereof to be filed with the town clerk's office. Should the sale for any reason be invalid, the town's liability shall be limited to the return of the purchase price. 
(d)  Liability of owner or occupant. Upon the failure of the owner of the vehicle or the owner or occupant of private property on which abandoned or junked articles have been removed by the town to pay the unrecovered expenses incurred by the town in such removal, a lien shall be placed upon the private property for the amount of such expenses. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, 9-12-11) 
Sec. 12-55. - Redemption of the impounded articles. 
    The owner of any article seized under the provisions of this article may redeem such article at any time after its removal but prior to the sale or destruction thereof upon proof of ownership, and payment to the town of such sum as may be determined and fixed for the actual and reasonable expense of removal, and any preliminary sale advertising expenses, plus reasonable storage fees for each article redeemed. 
(Ord. No. O-02-2011, § 1, 9-12-11) 
Secs. 12-56-12-64. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FALSE INTRUSION ALARMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- False fire alarms, § 8-81 et seq.; convenience store silent alarms, § 11-161. 

Sec. 12-65. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to encourage owners of alarm systems to keep their alarm systems in good working order. All alarm system owners and/or users shall be allowed three (3) months from the date of installation of their system to make certain it is in good working order. Thereafter, three (3) false alarm signals are allowed within any twelve-month period (commencing on October 1 of each year; see definitions, section 12-66 twelve-month period below) prior to a service charge being levied in order that the owner will have an opportunity to correct any problem or deficiency in his system prior to being charged a fee. However, thereafter a successive service charge shall be levied against alarm owners in order to reimburse the town for reasonable administrative expenses expended in continually responding to false alarm signals. See also section 8-81 et seq. for all rules and regulations pertaining to false fire alarms. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-66. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, whenever any of the following words or terms are used herein, they shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Alarm user shall mean any person occupying or controlling the premises of an occupancy or business which is protected by an automatic detection system. 
    Automatic alarm system shall mean any system employing intrusion detectors, motion detectors, heat, sensing or electrical field sensing devices for the purpose of detecting and automatically transmitting an alarm. 
    Central station system shall mean a system or group of systems in which the operation of circuits and devices are signaled automatically to, recorded in, maintained and supervised from an approved central station having competent and experienced observers and operators who, upon receipt of a signal, notify the police department and take such other action as is required by the Code of Ordinances. 
    Central station systems contractor shall mean a person, firm or corporation whose principal business is the furnishing and maintaining of a supervised signaling service known as a central station system. 
    False alarm shall mean the transmission of a police alarm signal indicating an intrusion requiring the immediate response of a police department when an intrusion does not exist and no evidence thereof is apparent to the police officer arriving on the scene. 
    Person shall mean any individual, partnership, association or corporation. 
    Twelve-month period shall mean the twelve (12) months constituting the town's fiscal year commencing on October 1 of each year and ending on September 30 of the next year. Should an automatic alarm system be installed at any time during the fiscal year, the false alarm shall be counted from the date of installation as noted herein but shall end on the next succeeding September 30 in order that all alarm systems may be monitored on a fiscal year basis. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-67. - Alarm permits required-Voluntary or required installation. 
    No person shall have an alarm installed to be operational or use an existing alarm serving a premises or a building, or a portion thereof, occupied or controlled by such person, either on a voluntary or required basis, unless an alarm permit in the form of a decal has been issued hereunder, and is in force authorizing the use of such alarm. A voluntary installation shall be deemed to mean an installation of an alarm which is not required by local or state law. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-68. - Application for alarm permit. 
(a)  Form; contents. Applications for alarm permits for voluntary installations and installations of alarm which are required by local or state law shall be made to the town on forms provided by the town. A permit fee shall be charged; which fee shall be a reasonable administrative fee to be set by resolution of the town council. The application shall be signed by the alarm user and/or owner and shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the alarm user; 
(2)  Address and telephone number of the alarm user's premises or building to be served by the alarm; 
(3)  Emergency contact names, addresses and telephone numbers of the person or persons of the premises or building served by the alarm, who are to be called in the case of an alarm; 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of the person or entity installing said alarm; 
(5)  The name, address and telephone number of the person or entity monitoring said alarm; 
(6)  The name, address and telephone number of the person or entity providing maintenance and repair service to said alarm; 
(7)  An agreement by the alarm user, binding upon the alarm user's heirs and successors in interest, to promptly pay or lawfully contest any penalties assessed against the alarm user for an excessive number of false alarms as described in this article. 
(b)  Permit amendments. A permit amendment shall be filed within ten (10) days after there are any changes in the information provided in the original application for permit. An amended alarm permit shall be issued without charge or fee. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-69. - Excessive false alarm signals declared a public nuisance. 
    The transmission of more than three (3) false alarm signals by an automatic detection system protecting any occupancy or business within any twelve-month period of time is excessive and constitutes a serious public nuisance, and is hereby declared to be unlawful and a violation of this section. No person shall allow, permit, cause or fail to prevent the transmission, for any reason, by an automatic detection system used by him, or any such system serving a premises or a building occupied and controlled by such person, of more than three (3) false alarm signals within any twelve-month period of time (See definitions, section 12-66, twelve-month period, above). 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-70. - Interference with police department telephone trunk lines prohibited. 
    No person shall use or cause to be used any telephone or electronic device or attachment that automatically selects a public primary telephone trunk line of the police department, and then reproduces any prerecorded message to report any fire, intrusion or other emergency. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-71. - False alarm signal service charge, collection. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply for a period of three (3) months from the date a permit is issued by the town for the installation of an automatic alarm system. Thereafter, the alarm user will be allowed three (3) false alarm signals in one (1), twelve-month period at no charge. The alarm user and/or owner shall be charged a service fee by the town of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the fourth false alarm signal in any twelve-month period; fifty dollars ($50.00) for the fifth false alarm signal in any twelve-month period; and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the sixth and each successive false alarm signal in excess of six (6) in any twelve-month period. The police chief or his designee shall determine whether a false alarm signal has been transmitted and the frequency of such false alarm signals, and the police chief or his designee shall notify alarm users and/or owners of amounts owed to the town, shall make demand therefor, pursuant to the provision of this section; which amounts shall be paid within thirty (30) days unless an appeal is filed before the thirty (30) days have elapsed. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-72. - Appeals. 
    Should the alarm owner or user desire to contest the finding of the police chief or his designee regarding the number of false alarm signals, an appeal in writing may be made to the code enforcement board within thirty (30) days of the determination of the police chief or his designee. An appeal, timely filed in writing to the code enforcement board shall automatically stay the fine until the matter can be heard at the next regularly scheduled board hearing. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-73. - Responsibility of central station systems contractor to repair alarm signals. 
    Nothing in this article shall be deemed to relieve a central station systems contractor of the responsibility for promptly reporting all automatic detection signals signaling an alarm from an occupancy or business supervised by them to the police department. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Sec. 12-74. - Enforcement. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the Code hereby adopted; or shall fail to comply therewith; or shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder from which no appeal has been taken; or shall build in violation of any details, statements, specifications or plans submitted or approved thereunder; or shall operate not in accordance with the provisions of any certificate, permit or approval issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken; or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the police chief or his designee or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed herein, shall individually and severally for each and every violation and noncompliance, respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-12. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation nor shall the violation be permitted to continue. All such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time as determined by the chief of police or his designee, and when not otherwise specified, the application of the penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. Alternatively, the matter may be referred to the code enforcement board for enforcement. 
(Ord. No. O-3-92, § 1, 7-13-92) 
Chapter 13 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes:
