e.  If the firefighter dies before payments from DROP begin, the beneficiary of the firefighter shall have the same rights as the firefighter. 
(Ord. No. O-7-95, § 12, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 14-118. - Repeal or termination of fund. 
    The plan shall remain in effect until the final benefit payment has been made to the last participant or beneficiary and shall then be terminated in accordance with F.S. § 175.361. 
(Ord. No. O-11-03, § 2, 11-24-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-11-03, § 2, adopted Dec. 24, 2003, repealed § 14-118, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 14-118 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-6-92, § 1, adopted Sept. 28, 1992; and Ord. No. O-7-95, § 12, adopted Sept. 25, 1995. 
Chapter 15 - POLICE RESERVE OFFICERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-31 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; forfeiture of vehicles and apparatus used in transportation or removal of or concealment of any illegal liquor, § 3-5; nudity on premises where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale prohibited, § 3-6; animals, Ch. 4; certain conduct prohibited on public beaches, § 5-18; nuisances, Ch. 12; personnel, Ch. 14; police relief and pension fund, § 14-76 et seq.; casualty insurance premium tax levied for police officers pension fund, § 18-36; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 15-1. - Reserve police force created; under direction of chief of police. 
    In order to provide for the pubic safety, to provide for better and more efficient law enforcement, to provide assistance for regular police officers of the town in the performance of their duties, and to provide a trained reserve of police officers to serve the town in time of emergency, there is hereby created and established a reserve police force for the town. The reserve police force shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of the chief of police. 
(Code 1962, § 19-2) 
Sec. 15-2. - Applications for membership in reserve; qualifications and examination of applicants. 
    Applications for membership in the reserve police force shall be made to the chief of police. The applicant shall have such qualifications and take such examinations as may be prescribed, from time to time, by state law. The chief of police shall investigate the character and reputation of applicants for membership in the reserve police. 
(Code 1962, § 19-3) 
Sec. 15-3. - Preparation of eligible list for reserves; certification of names to chief of police. 
    Every applicant found to be physically, mentally, and morally fit for service in the reserve police force, under the provisions of section 15-2, shall be placed upon an eligibility list to be kept by the town manager, and the name of such person shall be certified to the chief of police of the town. 
(Code 1962, § 19-4) 
Sec. 15-4. - Appointment of reserve members. 
    The chief of police shall appoint with the approval of the town manager from the names appearing on the eligibility list described in section 15-3, reserve police officers to serve in the reserve police force. 
(Code 1962, § 19-5) 
Sec. 15-5. - Oath of reserves. 
    Before entering upon his duties as a reserve police officer of the town, each officer shall take oath before the town clerk that he will uphold and defend the Constitution of the United States and of this state, and that he will enforce the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the town, and all lawful orders, rules or regulations promulgated under authority of the charter and ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1962, § 19-6) 
Sec. 15-6. - Reserve training and active duty. 
    Reserve police officers may be called, from time to time, by the chief of police for training in service with the regularly employed police officers of the town. They shall also be subject to call for active duty at such times and places within the town as the chief of police may deem necessary in order to fully protect life and property within the town. 
(Code 1962, § 19-7) 
Sec. 15-7. - Powers and duties of reserve. 
    While on duty under the orders of the chief of police, reserve police officers shall possess all of the powers and perform all of the duties and functions of members of the regular police force of the town. 
(Code 1962, § 19-8) 
Sec. 15-8. - Uniforms and insignia for reserves. 
    When called for training in service or for active duty, reserve police officers shall wear such identifying uniform and insignia as may be prescribed, from time to time, by the chief of police. It shall be unlawful for any reserve police officer to wear such identifying uniform and insignia except while on duty. It shall also be unlawful for any reserve police officer to attempt to enforce any provision of this Code or other town ordinances, or to carry out any order, rule or regulation of the town while such reserve police officer is not wearing such identifying uniform and insignia. 
(Code 1962, § 19-9) 
Sec. 15-9. - Probation of reserve officers; training; regulation by police chief. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe and establish a training program for reserve police officers and in addition, may prescribe and establish training programs for reserve police officers. The chief of police shall have authority to make such rules regarding training, discipline, duties, and employment of reserve police officers, not inconsistent herewith, as he may deem necessary. Reserve police officers shall be deemed to serve at the pleasure of the chief of police and may be discharged or suspended by the chief of police at any time and without cause. 
(Code 1962, § 19-11) 
Chapter 16 - SIGNS AND ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, adopted Oct. 27, 2003, repealed Ch. 16, Arts. I-VII, §§ 16-1-16-4, 16-21-16-27, 16-41, 16-53-16-67, 16-80-16-84, 16-100-16-105, 16-120-16-128, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 16 pertained to similar subject matter. For a detailed history of the provisions for former Ch. 16, see the Code Comparative Table. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
    The following phrases, words and terms shall have the following meanings and basic limitations: 
    Address: Words and/or numerals indicating the location of a structure, use or tenant. An address depicted in words or numerals in excess of eight (8) inches in height is construed to be a sign for purposes of administering and enforcing this article for non-single family residential structures. 
    Advertising structure: A structure erected or intended for advertising purposes with or without advertising purposes thereon. 
    Awning: A structure projecting from the exterior wall of a building, typically constructed of nonrigid materials except for the supporting framework. 
    Balloon: A container, typically constructed of nonrigid material, filled with air or gas. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
    Banner: See "Sign-Banner". 
    Building: Any structure constructed for the support, enclosure, shelter, or protection of persons or personal property; the term includes the word "structure," and shall be construed as being followed by "or any portion thereof". 
    Building official: The chief administrative officer of the town building department, or designee. 
    Canopy: Roof-like structure, generally self-supporting and freestanding, which may be attached to a principal structure, providing shade and weather protection, typically utilized over drive-through facilities and gasoline pumps. 
    Clear vision triangle: See "sight triangle". 
    Copy: Written or graphic material which is placed, displayed, depicted or otherwise indicated on a sign. 
    Establishment: A place of commercial or enterprise with its furnishing and staff. The term also includes "business" and "business establishment." 
    Facade: The entire building front, including the parapet. 
    Flag: A piece of material, typically cloth, on which is depicted a national, state, municipal, governmental agency, civil or house of worship symbol, nautical symbol, commercial name, information, or logo, or internationally recognized symbol. 
    Frontage: The length of the front property line of any one (1) business premises. 
    Grade: Average finished ground level of a parcel on which a sign is located. 
    Graphic(s): Copy, logo, color use, or combination thereof, as determined by the building official, to comprise or be part of a sign. 
    Logo: Copy or graphic(s) depicting the name, trademark, or symbol of a use, tenant, business or business entity, association, development or project. 
    Lot: A parcel of real property, as defined in chapter 17.5, Subdivision and Platting Regulations of the Lantana Code. 
    Mansard roof: A roof having two (2) slopes on all four (4) sides with the lower slope almost vertical and the upper almost horizontal includes mansard roofs used as an architectural decor, but not an integral part of the roof structure. 
    Major right-of-way: An abutting public right-of-way which has the greatest vehicular design capacity or current traffic volume relative to all other abutting public rights-of-way. 
    Marquee: Any hood, awning or canopy of permanent construction which projects from the wall face of a building. 
    Memorial: See monument. 
    Monument: A structure, typically permanent, paying homage to, glorifying and/or memorializing an individual, group, activity or political or social movement, which has no advertising purpose; also known as a "memorial". 
    Mural: A graphic or artwork displayed on the exterior of a building that covers all or substantially all of the wall which must consist of a scene depicting natural surroundings indigenous to Florida or having historical significance to the Town of Lantana and is provided for the purpose of decoration or artistic expression. A mural may be a painting, a fresco or a mosaic. Since the mural area shall not be counted toward the total sign area allowed on any property, a mural may not contain advertising messages and will be reviewed and approved by the town with regard to its graphic and artistic qualities as such elements contribute to the aesthetic quality of the Town of Lantana. The mural shall be reviewed by the town to provide for conformance to the above content requirements while also providing for harmonious colors, texture and lines designed to make a substantial contribution to the overall neighborhood streetscape. The approval process for a proposed mural is set forth at section 16-27. 
    Parapet: A false front or wall extension above the roof lines. 
    Pennant: A long, narrow, relatively small flag, often triangular, used for signaling or for identification. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
    Planned commercial development (PCD): A land area a minimum of one (1) acre in size under unified control designed and planned to be developed as one (1) parcel to accommodate more than one (1) commercial use (may utilize prescheduled development phases). 
    Planned industrial development (PID): A land area a minimum of one (1) acre in size under unified control designed and planned to be developed as one (1) parcel to accommodate more than one (1) industrial use in the industrial (I) district (may utilize prescheduled development phases). 
    Shopping center: A group of commercial retail and service establishments planned, developed, managed and operated as a unit with off-street parking provided on the property and related in its location, size and type of establishments to the trade area which the unit serves. 
    Sight triangle or clear vision triangle: The triangular area designated to be kept clear for visibility from automobiles which is formed by a diagonal line connecting two points on the street right-of-way lines located twenty-five (25) feet from the intersection of street right-of-way lines or a right-of-way line and the edge of a driveway and from two (2) feet above the ground to nine (9) feet above the ground. No visual obstructions, such as landscaping or signage (except for traffic control signs installed by the town or other governmental agency) shall encroach in this area. 
    Sign: An identification, description, depiction, illustration or device which directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution or business; or any emblem, painting, banner, pennant, placard or temporary sign designed to advertise, identify or convey information. The following numbered definitions identify specific types of signs: 
(1)  A-Frame: See sidewalk or sandwich sign. 
(2)  Advertising: A sign or sign structure situated upon or attached to real property, including the improvements thereon, intended for advertising purposes and to aid, directly or indirectly, in the sale, use or promotion of a product, commodity, service, activity or entertainment, or to aid, directly or indirectly, in the sale of real or personal property. 
(3)  Animated: A sign which moves or changes color. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(4)  Announcing: A sign announcing a project to be under construction or an intended use of the premises in the immediate future. 
(5)  Awning: A sign incorporated into, painted on or attached to an awning. 
(6)  Banner: A sign made of cloth, fabric, paper, nonrigid plastic or similar type of material (generally prohibited except as allowed by section 16-67.). 
(7)  Bench: Any sign painted on/or attached to a bench. 
(8)  Billboard: Any sign and/or framework thereof usually placed on a freestanding structure for the purpose of advertising or directing attention to a business, commodity, service, entertainment or attraction, sold, offered or existing elsewhere than upon the same lot or premises where such sign is located and made available to national and/or local advertisers. See off-premises sign. 
(9)  Building identification: A sign located on a building facade identifying the building by name. 
(10)  Canopy: A sign incorporated into, painted on or attached to a canopy. 
(11)  Changeable copy: A sign, other than a time or temperature sign, designed for and displaying copy that is not permanently affixed to or made a part of the sign. Prohibited except for exceptions listed at subsection 16-41(3). 
(12)  Construction project: A temporary sign identifying an active construction project. 
(13)  Cube: A sign or advertising structure comprised of four (4) faces, with copy on three (3) or more faces. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(14)  Directory: A sign listing multiple names of tenants of a building or group of buildings. 
(15)  Directional: (also known as "informational sign" or "traffic sign". 
a.  A sign erected by a governmental agency to denote the name of any thoroughfare; to point out the route to any city, educational institution, public building, historic place or hospital, or other use, facility, or attraction; to direct and regulate traffic; and to denote any railroad crossing, bridge or other transportation facility for the convenience and safety of the general public; 
b.  A notice or symbol as to the time and place of regular civic meetings and activities and services; 
c.  An on-premises sign which identifies and provides directions to facilities, service areas, and/or structures located on the premises, and which may include copy such as "enter," "caution," "exit," "drive-through," "parking," "no trespassing" or similar terms, and/or a directional arrow(s); with commercial copy limited to logo and business name; or 
d.  An on-premises sign identifying the address, number, or name of a structure, and parking area(s) therefor; with commercial copy limited to logo and business name. 
(16)  Dual-faced: A sign with two (2) faces, which are usually, but not necessarily, parallel. 
(17)  Flashing: Any sign which contains a continually intermittent or sequential flashing light source. The term also includes flashing lights with or without copy or logo(s) which are either freestanding, affixed to a structure, and/or affixed or part of a window sign. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(18)  Flat: A wall sign erected parallel to the facade of any building to which it is attached and supported throughout its entire length by the facade or outside wall of the building. 
(19)  Gasoline price: A sign indicating prices for gasoline and similar petroleum products, available on-site. 
(20)  Ground: A freestanding sign which is erected flush to the ground. 
(21)  Illegal: A sign installed without a permit as required by this chapter, prohibited by this chapter or installed in violation of any of the requirements of this chapter. 
(22)  Illuminated: Any sign designed to emit artificial sources of artificial light, whether or not said lights or tubes are physically attached to sign. 
(23)  Mansard: Any sign which is placed on the lower slope of a mansard roof. 
(24)  Menu pricing: A sign with changeable copy, listing food items and purchase prices, located at a drive-thru restaurant or by the front entrance of a restaurant. One (1) per business location only. 
(25)  Model sales office: A sign identifying a project-model sales office. 
(26)  Model name: A sign which designates a particular dwelling unit design which is not for sale, but rather represents other units of similar design, that are for sale. 
(27)  Monument: A low-profile, freestanding (i.e. not attached to any building for support) sign with a solid base located on the ground, typically designed to incorporate materials, architectural features and design of the principal structure(s) located on the property. See section 16-101. 
(28)  Nameplate or owner designation: A sign, other than a directory sign, indicating the name, and/or profession or address of the person or persons residing on the premises or legally occupying the premises, provided that no such sign shall include letters and/or other symbols exceeding eight (8) inches in height for non-single family residential structures. 
(29)  Nonconforming: A sign or advertising structure legally constructed, permitted and existing within the town limits on October 27, 2003 which by its design, height, type, content, electrical wiring, square foot area, location, use or structural support or otherwise did not conform to the requirements of this chapter on that date. 
(30)  Occupant identification: A sign which advertises or directs attention to the use or establishment located on the premises or a product or service available on-premises. 
(31)  Off-premises: Any sign which advertises a use, establishment, product or service that is sold, produced, manufactured or furnished at a place other than on the property on which said sign is located. (Also called an outdoor advertising sign or billboard.) See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(32)  Painted: Includes murals, mosaics and signs painted on any building surface. Not allowed on roof surface. Must be professionally designed and painted. 
(33)  Paper window: A temporary sign displayed within glass display windows for promotion of the business conducted therein. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(34)  Parapet: A sign attached to and dependent upon the parapet for structural support. 
(35)  Permanent: Any sign which, when installed, is intended for permanent use. For the purposes of this chapter, any sign with an intended use in excess of twelve (12) months from the date of installation shall be deemed a permanent sign. 
(36)  Pole: A freestanding sign which is supported by one (1) or more poles, posts, columns, pyramids or other extensions from the ground level. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(37)  Political campaign: Any sign used in connection with a local, state, or national election campaign; also referred to as a "political campaign advertisement". 
(38)  Portable: Any sign which is manifestly designed to be transported by trailer or on its own wheels, including such signs where the wheels may be removed and the remaining chassis or support structure(s) converted to an "A" or "T" frame sign and attached temporarily or permanently to the ground. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(39)  Price: See "Informational sign". 
(40)  Price rate gas service station: See "Gasoline price sign". 
(41)  Projecting: Shall include any sign which is attached to a building or structure and extends beyond the line of the building or structure or beyond the surface of that portion of the building or structure to which it is attached. Includes signs suspended under a porch or other structural element that would exist with or without the sign. 
(42)  Public convenience: A sign identifying, or providing direction to, public telephones, restrooms, and the like. 
(43)  Public utility: A sign identifying the location of underground utility facilities, high voltage equipment, and the like. 
(44)  Public warning: A sign identifying the location of hazardous or dangerous areas, conditions, or events. 
(45)  Real estate: A temporary sign erected by the owner, or his agent, advertising for sale, rent or lease the property upon which the sign is located. 
(46)  Remodeling or contractor: A temporary sign designating the name of the general and/or subcontractor undertaking the remodeling and/or renovation of an existing structure, or the construction of a new structure. 
(47)  Roof: A sign erected over, across, or on the roof of any building, which is dependent on the roof, parapet or upper walls of any building for support. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(48)  Sidewalk or sandwich: A moveable sign not secured nor attached to the ground placed on public or private property, visible from a public right-of-way where the apparent purpose is to advertise a product, service or activity, or direct people to a business or activity located on the same or nearby property. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(49)  Snipe: A small sign of any material, including but not limited to, paper, cardboard, wood or metal, which is tacked, nailed, posted, pasted, glued or otherwise attached to trees, poles, fences or other objects. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(50)  Special event: A sign which calls attention to a civic event or activity or other similar activity of a temporary nature. 
(51)  Subdivision entrance: A sign designating or identifying a particular residential subdivision or area. 
(52)  Temporary: A sign designated, constructed, and intended to be used on a short term basis. All temporary signs, except for municipal service signs, must be set back a minimum of ten (10) feet from the right-of-way or property line, whichever is further from the adjacent roadway. 
(53)  Three-dimensional product display: Products or representations thereof assembled or designed for display, sale, or advertising. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(54)  Traffic: See "Directional signs". 
(55)  Vehicular: Any sign affixed to a vehicle or trailer for the purpose of advertising. See article III, Prohibited Signs. 
(56)  Wall: A sign erected parallel to the outside wall facade of any structure, including flat, individual letter or cabinet signs. 
(57)  Window: A permanent or temporary sign which is painted on or displayed upon or within a storefront window or door, including decals, paper, plastic, cardboard or other temporary signs. 
    Sign face: The part of a sign that is or may be used for advertising purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 1, 5-24-04) 
Sec. 16-2. - Purpose and scope of regulations. 
(a)  In general. The purpose of this chapter is to encourage the effective use of signs as a means of communications in the town; to maintain and enhance the aesthetic environment and the town's ability to attract sources of economic development and growth; to improve pedestrian and traffic safety; to minimize the possible adverse effect of signs on nearby public and private property; to foster the integration of signage with architectural and landscape designs; to enable the fair and consistent enforcement of these sign regulations and to promote the implementation of the town's comprehensive future land use plan. Additionally, this chapter provides for regulations to achieve the following: 
(1)  Property value protection. Signs should not create a nuisance to the occupancy or use of other properties as a result of their size, height, brightness or movement. They should be in harmony with buildings, the neighborhood and other conforming signs in the area. 
(2)  Communication. Signs should not deny other persons or groups the use of sight lines on public rights-of-way, should not obscure important public messages and should not overwhelm readers with too many messages. Signs can and should help individuals to identify and understand the jurisdiction and the character of its subareas. 
(3)  Preservation of community's beauty. Small towns such as this which include a public beach as well as small office, retail, residential and industrial uses rely heavily on their natural surroundings and beautification efforts to retain their economic viability. This concern is reflected by the active and objective regulations of the appearance and design of signs. 
(b)  Regulations strictly enforced. It shall be unlawful for any persons to post, display, change or erect a sign or sign structure that requires a permit without first having obtained a permit therefor in accordance with section 16-21. Signs or sign structures erected without a valid permit shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and it shall be mandatory to obtain the applicable permit, or remove the sign or sign structure immediately. All signs not expressly permitted by this chapter are strictly prohibited. 
(c)  Non-commercial message. Notwithstanding anything contained in subsections (a) and (b) above to the contrary, any sign erected pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may, at the option of the applicant, contain either a non-commercial message unrelated to the business located on the premises where the sign is erected or a commercial message related to the business and located on the business premises. The non-commercial message may occupy the entire sign face or portion thereof. The sign face may be changed from commercial to non-commercial messages as frequently as desired by the owner of the sign, provided that the size and design criteria conform to the applicable portions of this chapter, the sign is allowed by this chapter, the sign conforms to the requirements of the applicable zoning designation and the appropriate permits are obtained. For the purposes of this sign code, non-commercial messages, by their very nature, shall never be deemed off-premises. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-3. - Identification label. 
    All approved signs shall have affixed thereto and conspicuously displayed in the lower right-hand area a sign identification tag or label which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Permit number; 
(2)  Date of permit issuance; and 
(3)  Name of permittee. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-4. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business of constructing, fabricating, erecting, altering or maintaining signs within the town unless and until such person or firm shall have a valid occupational license issued by the town, and unless and until such person shall have filed with the building official a certificate of public liability and property damage insurance policy executed by a company authorized to do business in the State of Florida in a sum of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury in any one (1) occurrence, and not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for damage of property. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-5. - Signs made and installed by licensed contractor/painter. 
    All permanent signs must be manufactured, constructed, fabricated, erected, altered, assembled, painted, installed and maintained by a licensed sign contractor/painter. Exceptions to this requirement are as follows: temporary signs made and erected by charitable organizations having 501(c)(3) status and used to advertise their special events; and temporary signs made and erected by residential homeowners for their personal use only at the property on which they reside. 
(Ord. No. O-16-05, § 1, 10-10-05) 
Secs. 16-6-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS 

Sec. 16-21. - Required. 
    It shall hereafter be unlawful and deemed a prima facie violation of this chapter for any person to place, erect or maintain or cause to be placed, erected or maintained, any sign, temporary or permanent, or structural alteration thereto without having first obtained a permit in conformance with the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided herein. Any person who commences any work to place, erect or cause to place or erect a sign prior to obtaining a permit as required shall be subject to a penalty of two hundred (200) percent of the normal fee in addition to the required permit fee. The payment of the required fee plus penalty amount shall not affect the decision of the town to initiate other applicable code enforcement actions against a person related to a violation of the sign code regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 2, 10-10-05) 
Sec. 16-22. - Application. 
    All plans and layouts for a sign shall be accompanied by an application which shall be filed with the building official prior to the issuance of any sign permit. The application shall be on a form approved by the building official and shall describe and set forth the following: 
(1)  The type of sign as defined in this chapter; 
(2)  The street address of the property upon which the sign is to be located and the proposed location of the sign on the property; 
(3)  The square footage area per sign and message content; 
(4)  The name and address of the person or persons in control or possession of the property upon which the sign is to be located. The authorization of the property owner is required if a sign is to be erected by anyone other than the owner or agent; 
(5)  A sketch, blueprint or similar presentation drawn to scale, showing the square footage of the sign area as well as the sign face, height of letters, colors, materials, lighting, equipment, if any, and the proposed sign's position relative to structures and/or property lines, showing all pertinent structural details, wind pressure requirements and display materials in accordance with all requirements of the building code. The seal of a Florida registered engineer or architect shall be affixed to any sketch, blueprint or similar presentation on signs over thirty (30) square feet in area. These requirements do not pertain to certain nameplate or owner designation signs, real estate, temporary contractor and remodeling signs and certain other signs. See section 16-25. 
(6)  Such other pertinent information as the building official or council determine to be reasonably necessary to evaluate the application. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-23. - Interpretation. 
    In all applications for permits where a matter of interpretation arises, the most restrictive definition shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-24. - Permit, inspection and appeal fees. 
    A fee schedule adopted by resolution of the town council shall set forth the necessary fees and charges imposed to cover the administrative costs associated with sign permits, deposits, reviews, appeals and site inspections for the installation and/or placement of signs or advertising structures. The applicable fee shall accompany the permit or appeal application. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-25. - Signs not requiring permit or permit fees. 
    The following signs or types of signs shall be governed by and are subject to all applicable provisions of this chapter, however no permit application or fee is required. 
(1)  Nameplate or owner designation signs when the signs do not exceed two (2) square feet in area nor two (2) feet in width. 
(2)  Residential real estate signs. See subsection 16-55(7) for size requirements. 
(3)  Credit card signs. 
(4)  Public convenience signs. 
(5)  Public utility signs. 
(6)  Public warning signs. 
(7)  Flags, shall be limited to twenty-four (24) square feet in area per flag, and shall not exceed three (3) per parcel, lot, facility, or structure, as applicable. 
(8)  Seasonal displays or decorations not advertising a product or establishment. 
(9)  Temporary contractor and re-modeler's signs on active and permitted construction projects. See section 16-66, for sign requirements. 
(10)  Nonresidential real estate signs, "for sale" signs, rental signs, and lease signs. See applicable zoning district section for sign requirements. 
(11)  Addresses depicted in words and/or characters not to exceed twelve (12) inches in height. 
(12)  Refurbishing an existing sign, provided the copy and color are not changed; provided that the cost of any repair does not exceed fifty (50) percent of the original cost of the sign; provided the sign remains substantially the same as originally approved; provided that no electrical repairs are necessary, except for normal maintenance; and provided it is not nonconforming. 
(13)  Advertising and identifying signs located on taxicabs, buses, trailers, trucks, or vehicle bumpers. 
(14)  Political campaign signs. See section 16-53. 
(15)  Civic, religious and public service temporary directional signs which are displayed on the day of the event for no longer than a twenty-four (24) hour period. Such signs shall be limited to two (2) per event and may be no larger than four (4) square feet each; the top of such signs shall be no higher than three (3) feet from grade. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-26. - Record of ownership and application. 
    The building official shall keep on file all sign applications and permits for ready reference as to ownership and periodic inspection. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-27. - Review of application by building official; issuance of permits and inspection. 
(a)  The building official shall, upon the filing of an application for a sign or mural permit, examine the plans and specifications and other data required hereunder and inspect and examine the premises upon which the sign or structure is proposed to be erected or the mural depicted, and determine whether the proposed sign, mural and/or structure complies with all the requirements of this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the town. Additionally, the building official shall forward any proposed plans or sketches for a mural to the plan review committee for its review and recommendation to the town council, which shall have final approval regarding the painting or fabrication of any proposed mural. 
(b)  Upon satisfactory compliance with the requirements herein, the building official shall cause a written sign or mural permit to be issued. The building official shall issue a no-fee permit for a proposed mural in conformance with the approval of such by the town council. 
(c)  After the issuance of a permit, the following inspections shall be made by the town at the request of the permit holder: 
(1)  A foundation inspection prior to pouring concrete for any freestanding, ground sign. 
(2)  An electrical inspection for electrical or monument signs. 
(3)  A final inspection for completion of the sign or mural in accordance with the approved final plans or sketch of mural. 
Secs. 16-28-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROHIBITED SIGNS 

Sec. 16-41. - List of prohibited signs. 
    The following signs or types of signs shall be prohibited within the town: 
(1)  Balloons used for advertising purposes; 
(2)  Banners, with the exception of the following which may be displayed as more particularly set forth in section 16-67: 
a.  Grand opening banners; 
b.  Banners placed on street light poles by the town as holiday and/or seasonal decorations, public announcements, etc.; 
c.  Sidewalk sale banners; and 
d.  Banners used as special event signs. 
(3)  Changeable copy signs, with the exception of the following which may be displayed as set forth in this chapter: 
a.  Gasoline price signs located on pump islands or on monument signs; 
b.  Informational signage located on property zoned public ownership or publicly owned buildings located in other zoning districts; 
c.  Menu pricing signs; 
d.  Movie theater marquee signs; 
e.  House of worship signs. 
(4)  Cube signs; 
(5)  Flashing signs or animated signs; 
(6)  Illuminated signs in any residential zoning district, except for residential nameplate or subdivision signs which may be illuminated, with a soft and muted effect; 
(7)  Off-premises or billboard signs; 
(8)  Paper window signs; 
(9)  Pennants; 
(10)  Pole signs (excepting those directional, real estate, political campaign, temporary, public convenience, public utility, public warning, remodeling, contractor, and announcing signs which are permitted herein); 
(11)  Portable signs; sidewalk signs; sandwich signs; 
(12)  Roof signs; 
(13)  Search light promoting, advertising, or bringing attention to a business, enterprise, or event; 
(14)  Snipe signs; swinging signs; 
(15)  Signs placed, attached, posted, or located, on or to any tree, utility pole, street light, sidewalk, curb, fire hydrant, bridge or any other public property, except for public utility, convenience, and warning signs, and signs erected by governmental agencies; 
(16)  Signs created by colored illumination or shadow casting on structures; 
(17)  Signs placed on bus benches, bus shelters or waste receptacles (except as may be allowed by contract with the town); 
(18)  Signs which copy or imitate official signs or which purport to have official status; 
(19)  Signs which display any obscene or illegal, written or graphic message; 
(20)  Signs which project into or over any dedicated public rights-of-way; 
(21)  Signs which obstruct or interfere with any door, fire exit, stairway, ladder or opening intended to provide light, air, ingress or egress for any building; 
(22)  Signs which are not properly maintained, or are in dilapidated or hazardous condition. The basis of judgment for this determination shall be the specifications as set forth in the building code and/or in this chapter as applied by the building official; 
(23)  Signs which constitute a traffic safety or fire hazard by reason of size, location, coloring or method of illumination, obstruct vision of motorists or pedestrians; and which obstruct or detract from any official traffic control devices; or utilize the word "stop," "look," "danger," or any other word or phrase, symbol or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic; 
(24)  Three-dimensional product displays including cars, appliances, animal likenesses or any other object in excess of three (3) feet in length, one (1) foot in height and one (1) foot in depth; 
(25)  Vehicular signs with a total sign area on any vehicle in excess of five (5) square feet, when the vehicle: 
a.  Is parked for more than sixty (60) consecutive minutes within fifty (50) feet of any street right-of-way; 
b.  Is visible from the street right-of-way that the vehicle is within fifty (50) feet of; and 
c.  Is not regularly used in the conduct of the business advertised on the vehicle. A vehicle used primarily for advertising, or for the purpose of providing transportation for owners or employees of the business advertised on the vehicle, shall not be considered a vehicle used in the conduct of the business. 
(26)  Any other sign not specifically permitted by this chapter. 
Secs. 16-42-16-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PERMITTED SIGNS 

Sec. 16-53. - Political campaign signs. 
(a)  Political campaign signs may be displayed in any zoning district, not more than thirty (30) days prior to an election. Political campaign signs shall not exceed six (6) feet in height from grade level, six (6) feet in width, nor sixteen (16) square feet in area. Display of political campaign signs shall be limited to two (2) such signs per candidate, ballot item, and/or referendum question, for each frontage of a parcel. Political campaign signs shall not be illuminated. 
(b)  Each candidate, whether for a federal, state, county, or town office, shall remove all of his political campaign advertisements within ten (10) days after: 
(1)  Withdrawal of his candidacy; 
(2)  Having been eliminated as a candidate; or 
(3)  Being elected to office. 
However, a candidate is not expected to remove those political campaign signs which are in the form of signs used by an outdoor advertising business as provided in F.S. Chapter 479. The provisions herein do not apply to political campaign signs and advertisements placed on motor vehicles or to campaign messages designated to be worn by persons. 
(c)  If political campaign advertisements are not removed within the specified period, the building official has the authority to remove such advertisements and may charge the candidate the actual cost for such removal. Funds collected for removing such advertisements shall be deposited to the general revenue fund of the town. 
(d)  No political campaign advertisements shall be erected, posted, painted, tacked, nailed, or otherwise displayed, placed, or located on or above any town, state, or county road right-of-way or the FEC railroad right-of-way. 
(e)  The town clerk before whom a candidate qualifies for office shall notify the candidate, in writing, of the provisions in this section. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-54. - Gasoline price signage. 
    Gasoline price signage may only be located at pump islands, subject to a maximum price sign area of fifteen (15) square feet per pump island or row (which is separated by a vehicular lane from a building, or other pump island or row) or on a monument sign not to exceed four (4) feet in height from grade. Gasoline price signs shall incorporate the color scheme and architectural features of the principal structure(s). Gasoline price signs may be illuminated. See section 16-83 for additional illumination requirements. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-55. - Single-family, multifamily and mobile home residential districts (R1A, R1, R3, R15, MHP). 
    The following signs are permitted in the single-family and multifamily residential districts: 
(1)  One (1) nameplate per individual dwelling unit, which shall not exceed two (2) square feet in surface area (sign face) and shall not exceed two (2) feet in width. 
(2)  Not more than two (2) subdivision or neighborhood entrance signs may be permitted at each entrance (one (1) on each side) of any residential subdivision or neighborhood. The sign structure shall not exceed seven (7) feet in height from grade level and shall contain no advertising or commercial copy. The height of letters used in copy of the sign shall not exceed eighteen (18) inches. Applications shall be submitted to the plan review committee for review and recommendation to the Lantana Town Council who shall have final authority regarding the exact location, design, landscaping, irrigation, lighting and determination of architectural compatibility of the sign with the surrounding area. * 
(3)  Flags, not to exceed three (3) per lot or dwelling unit, displayed on or from the lot or dwelling unit, as applicable. 
(4)  Directional signs, each not to exceed two (2) square feet in sign area per lot or dwelling unit, as applicable, 
(5)  Building identification signs. 
(6)  Temporary open house signs. 
a.  All zoning districts, except R1A residential district. Temporary open house signs within these districts shall not exceed four (4) square feet in surface area (sign face) and four (4) feet in height from grade. Signs shall be removed within (12) twelve hours after completion of open house activities. 
b.  R1A residential district. Temporary open house signs within this district shall not exceed two (2) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor four (4) feet in overall height. Such signs shall contain a white background with black lettering, and shall be supported by a single wood pole, painted white, not exceeding four (4) inches by four (4) inches in lateral dimensions, or by metal pole(s) painted black or white. Not more than one (1) sign shall be permitted on each lot of record. Signs shall be removed within twelve (12) hours after completion of open house activities. 
(7)  Real estate signs. 
a.  All residential zoning districts, except R1A residential district. Real estate signs within these districts shall not exceed four (4) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor four (4) feet in height from grade. Not more than one (1) sign shall be permitted on each lot of record. 
b.  R1A residential district. Real estate signs within this district shall not exceed two (2) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor four (4) feet in height from grade. Such signs shall contain a white background with black lettering, and shall be supported by a single wood pole, painted white, not exceeding four (4) inches by four (4) inches in lateral dimensions, or by metal pole(s) painted black or white. Not more than one (1) sign shall be permitted on each lot of record. 
(8)  Special event sign. Includes signs announcing public, civic or neighborhood group events, meetings, activities, as well as "House of the Month" or other signs associated with programs or events sponsored by the Town of Lantana or neighborhood groups. Special event signs shall not exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area (sign face), four (4) feet in width and six (6) feet in height from grade 
(9)  Houses of worship signs. In residential zoning districts R-3, R-15 and MHP, a house of worship is allowed one (1) monument sign. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. The sign can be single or dual faced. Signs must incorporate the materials, architectural features, color scheme and design of the principal structure(s). 
(10)  Changeable copy sign for a house of worship or for a publicly owned building, whenever either structure is located as permitted in a residential zoning district. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(11)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83 for additional illumination requirements. 
Sec. 16-56. - Public ownership (P). 
    The following signs or types of signs are permitted in the public ownership district: 
(1)  Not more than two (2) monument signs may be permitted at each entrance to the property not to exceed thirty (30) square feet in surface area (sign face), and not to exceed seven (7) feet in height from grade level, with exterior illumination only. Applications shall be submitted to the plan review committee for review and recommendation to the Lantana Town Council who shall have final authority regarding the exact location, design, landscaping, irrigation, lighting and determination of architectural compatibility of the sign with the surrounding area. 
(2)  Flags not to exceed three (3) per lot or facility, as applicable. 
(3)  Directional signs. 
(4)  Changeable copy sign for a publicly owned building or other public facility located in the public ownership district. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(5)  Building identification signs. 
(6)  All signs in the public ownership district (P) may include exterior illuminated signs only. 
(7)  Real estate signs-One (1) per property allowed not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor six (6) feet in height from grade. 
(8)  Special event signs. See section 16-69 for additional requirements and restrictions. 
(9)  Banners which advertise businesses or organizations that sponsor town-organized special events are allowed to be placed within the public ownership district on a temporary basis with the written approval of the town manager. 
(10)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-57. - Commercial (C1 and C2) properties larger than five (5) acres in size. 
(a)  The following signs or types of signs are permitted on properties in the commercial districts (C1 and C2) that are larger than (5) acres in size: 
(1)  Awning sign: See section 16-62 for maximum dimensions. An awning sign cannot coexist with a wall sign. 
(2)  Building identification signs: Not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(3)  Canopy sign: See section 16-62 for maximum dimensions. 
(4)  Directional sign: Each sign not to exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. 
(5)  Flags: Three (3) per development, with each flag not to exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in area. 
(6)  *Monument signs: Maximum of two (2) signs which must be separated by a minimum of two hundred (200) feet. The sign(s) shall be located not less than ten (10) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(7)  *Corner properties located at the intersection of two (2) or more rights-of-way are allowed two monument signs, one on each street and to be separated by a minimum of two hundred (220) feet. The sign(s) shall be located not less than ten (10) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. Corner buildings that are located adjacent to a right-of-way may, in addition to the front wall signage authorized in subsection (10)e. below, place one (1) wall sign on a side wall, not to exceed ten (10) percent of the side wall area. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(8)  *Out-parcels (or property functioning as an out-parcel) are allowed one monument sign. Out-parcels located at the intersection of two (2) or more rights-of-way are allowed two (2) monument signs, one on each street and to be separated by a minimum of two hundred (220) feet. Buildings on out-parcels may, in addition to the above-referenced signage, place one (1) additional wall sign on the building, in accordance with subsection (10)e. below. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(9)  Real estate signs: One (1) per property allowed, not to exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in surface area (sign face) nor eight (8) feet in height from grade. 
(10)  For each individual business within a commercial development: 
a.  Nameplate or owner designation sign: One (1) mounted on or near the front and/or rear door not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
b.  Window signs: Total area must not exceed thirty (30) percent of the window area and sign placement shall allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. Interior signage placed or displayed within two (2) feet of the window area shall be subject to this provision. 
c.  *Parapet/mansard roof sign: One (1) sign per business. Mansard roof sign must be on the lower slope of the roof and no part may extend above the top. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
d.  *Projecting sign: One (1) on the business front and one (1) in an alley. If on a corner lot, add one (1) sign. Must display only the name of the business to which it is attached. No extension allowed above the roof line/parapet wall. Maximum of one (1) per fifty (50) linear feet and not within seven (7) feet of another projecting sign. Maximum area of sign face is nine (9) square feet and the bottom of the sign must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above grade. 
e.  *Wall sign: One (1) sign located on the front wall. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
f.  Murals, entrance/exit signs, automated teller machine (ATM) identification signs, and other customer oriented directional signs shall not be counted toward the total sign area. (As above) 
g.  A business may have only one (1) of the following types of signs on the primary structure: a wall sign, a mansard sign, an awning sign, a projecting sign or a sign painted on the building. In addition to these signs, one canopy sign is allowed on a canopy structure. Multiple signs are not permitted, except on a building located on a corner lot. 
(11)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(b)  The maximum total combined sign area for each individual business within a commercial development is based on the business frontage as follows: 
Business Frontage Maximum Square Footage Signage 50 or less 50 51 to 99 75 100 to 150 120 150 and larger One (1) square foot per one (1) linear foot to a maximum of 300 square feet  
(c)  Applications for signs on commercial (C1 and C2) properties larger than five (5) acres in size (except individual businesses and real estate signs) shall be submitted to the plan review committee for review and recommendation to the Lantana Town Council who shall have final authority regarding the exact location, design, landscaping, irrigation, lighting and determination of architectural compatibility of the sign with the surrounding area. 
(d)  Changeable copy signs as allowed as set forth at subsection 16-41(3). See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 3, 10-10-05) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83 for additional illumination requirements. 
Sec. 16-58. - Commercial (C1 and C2) properties five (5) acres in size or smaller. 
(a)  The following signs or types of signs are permitted on properties in the commercial districts (C1 and C2) that are five (5) acres in size or smaller: 
(1)  Awning sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. An awning sign cannot coexist with a wall sign. 
(2)  Building identification signs: Not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(3)  Canopy sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(4)  Directional sign: Each sign not to exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. 
(5)  Flags: Three (3) per development, with each flag not to exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in area. 
(6)  *Monument sign: Maximum of two (2) signs per development which must be separated by a minimum of two hundred (200) feet. The sign(s) shall be located not less than seven (7) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. Sign(s) can be single or dual faced. Signs must incorporate the materials, architectural features, color scheme and design of the principal structure(s). See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(7)  Nameplate or owner designation sign: On or near the front and/or rear door of each business conducted on the premises not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(8)  Window signs: Total area must not exceed thirty (30) percent of the window area for each business and sign placement shall allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. Interior signage placed or displayed within two (2) feet of the window shall be subject to this provision. 
(9)  *Parapet/mansard roof sign: One (1) per business. Mansard roof sign must be on the lower slope of the roof and no part may extend above the top. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(10)  *Projecting sign: One (1) on the business front and one (1) in an alley. If on a corner lot, add one (1) sign. Must display only the name of the business to which it is attached. No extension allowed above the roofline/parapet wall. A projecting sign shall not be located within fifteen (15) feet of another projecting sign. Maximum area of sign face is nine (9) square feet, with the exception of projecting signs located under a covered walkway which shall only be two (2) square feet in area and the bottom of the sign must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above grade. 
(11)  Signs painted on buildings: One (1) sign per development. Includes murals, mosaics and signs painted on any building surface. Not allowed on roof surface. Must be professionally designed and painted. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(12)  *Wall sign: One (1) sign located on the front wall. One (1) additional sign allowed for corner lots. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(13)  Real estate signs: One (1) per property allowed, not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor six (6) feet in height from grade. 
(14)  Individual business locations: On the primary structure, individual business locations within a commercial development may display the types and sizes of signs as described in subsections (a)(7) Nameplate and (8) Window signs and only one of the following: (1) Awning sign , (9) Parapet/mansard roof sign, (10) Projecting sign, (11) Signs painted on buildings, or (12) Wall sign referenced above. In addition to these signs, one (1) canopy sign is allowed on a canopy structure. 
(15)  Murals, entrance/exit signs, automated teller machine (ATM) identification signs, and other customer oriented directional signs shall not be counted toward the total sign area. 
(16)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(b)  The maximum total combined sign area for commercial development, each individual business within a commercial development and stand alone business on properties in the commercial districts (C1 and C2) that are five (5) acres in size or smaller is based on the business frontage as follows: 
Business Frontage Maximum Square Footage Signage 50 or less 50 51 to 99 75 100 to 150 120 150 and larger One (1) square foot per one (1) linear foot to a maximum of 300 square feet  
(c)  Changeable copy signs as allowed as set forth at subsection 16-41(3). See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 3, 10-10-05) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83 for additional illumination requirements. 
Sec. 16-59. - Industrial (I) properties larger than five (5) acres in size. 
(a)  The following signs or types of signs are permitted on properties in the industrial district (I) that are larger than five (5) acres in size: 
(1)  Awning sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. An awning sign cannot coexist with a wall sign. 
(2)  Canopy sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(3)  *Monuments: One (1) monument sign. The sign shall be located not less than ten (10) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(4)  *Wall: One (1) wall sign on the front of each building. Properties located at the intersection of two (2) or more rights-of-way are allowed two (2) such signs. See section 16-62 for maximum dimensions. 
(5)  Rear entrance wall sign: One (1) rear entrance wall sign which shall not exceed three (3) square feet in surface area (sign face). 
(6)  Directional signs: Each not to exceed two (2) square feet in surface area (sign face). 
(7)  Flags: Not to exceed three (3) per facility or building, with each flag not to exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in area. 
(8)  Building identification signs: Not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(9)  Real estate signs: One (1) per property allowed, not to exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in surface area, nor eight (8) feet in height from grade. 
(10)  For each individual business within an industrial development: 
a.  Nameplate or owner designation sign: One (1) mounted on or near the front and/or rear door not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
b.  Window signs: Total area must not exceed thirty (30) percent of the window area and sign placement shall allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. Interior signage placed or displayed within two (2) feet of the window area shall be subject to this provision. 
c.  Wall sign: One (1) sign located on the front wall. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
d.  Individual business locations within an industrial development may display the types and sizes of signs as described in subsections 16-58(a)(5) Rear entrance wall sign and (10)(b) Window signs and only one (1) of the following: (1) Awning sign, (4) Wall sign, (11) Signs painted on buildings or (14) Projecting sign, referenced above. In addition to these signs, one (1) canopy sign is allowed on a canopy structure. 
(11)  Signs painted on buildings: One (1) sign per development. Includes murals, mosaics and signs painted on any building surface. Not allowed on roof surface. Must be professionally designed and painted. See section 16-62, for square footage requirements. 
(12)  Murals, entrance/exit signs, automated teller machine (ATM) identification signs, and other customer oriented directional signs shall not be counted toward the total sign area. 
(13)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(14)  *Projecting sign: One (1) on the business front and one (1) in an alley. If on a corner lot, add one (1) sign. Must display only the name of the business to which it is attached. No extension allowed above the roofline/parapet wall. One (1) per fifty (50) linear feet or one (1) per storefront and not within seven (7) feet of another projecting sign. Maximum area of sign face is nine (9) square feet and the bottom of the sign must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above grade. 
(b)  The maximum total combined sign area for individual businesses within an industrial development is based on the business frontage as follows: 
Business Frontage Maximum Square Footage Signage 50 or less 50 51 to 99 75 100 to 150 120 150 and larger One (1) square foot per one (1) linear foot to a maximum of 300 square feet  
(c)  Applications for signs on industrial (I) properties larger than five (5) acres in size (except individual businesses and real estate signs) shall be submitted to the plan review committee for review and recommendation to the Lantana Town Council who shall have final authority regarding the exact location, design, landscaping, irrigation, lighting and determination of architectural compatibility of the sign with the surrounding area. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 3, 10-10-05) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83, for additional illumination requirements. 
Sec. 16-60. - Industrial (I) properties five (5) acres in size or smaller. 
(a)  The following signs or types of signs are permitted for each individual business in an industrial development on properties in the industrial district (I) that are five (5) acres in size or smaller: 
(1)  Awning sign: Section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. An awning sign cannot coexist with a wall sign. 
(2)  Building identification sign: Not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(3)  Canopy sign: Section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(4)  Directional sign: Each sign not to exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. 
(5)  Flags: Three (3) per development, with each flag not to exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in area. 
(6)  Monument sign: One (1) monument sign. The sign shall be located not less than seven (7) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(7)  Nameplate or owner designation sign: On or near the front and/or rear door of each business conducted on the premises not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(8)  Window signs: Total area must not exceed thirty (30) percent of the window area and sign placement shall allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. Interior signage placed or displayed within two (2) feet of the window shall be subject to this provision. 
(9)  *Parapet/mansard roof sign: One (1) sign per business. Mansard roof sign must be on the lower slope of the roof and no part may extend above the top. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(10)  *Projecting sign: One (1) on the business front and one (1) in an alley. If on a corner lot, add one (1) sign. Must display only the name of the business to which it is attached. No extension allowed above the roofline/parapet wall. One (1) per fifty (50) linear feet or one (1) per storefront and not within seven (7) feet of another projecting sign. Maximum area of sign face is nine (9) square feet and the bottom of the sign must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above grade. 
(11)  Signs painted on buildings: One (1) sign per development. Includes murals, mosaics and signs painted on any building surface. Not allowed on roof surface. Must be professionally designed and painted. See section 16-62, for square footage requirements. 
(12)  *Wall sign: One (1) sign located on the front wall. One (1) additional sign allowed for corner lots. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(13)  Real estate signs: One (1) per property allowed, not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area, nor six (6) feet in height from grade. 
(14)  Murals, entrance/exit signs, automated teller machine (ATM) identification signs, and other customer oriented directional signs shall not be counted toward the total sign area. 
(15)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(16)  Rear entrance wall sign: One (1) rear entrance wall sign which shall not exceed three (3) square feet in surface area (sign face). 
(17)  Individual business locations : On the primary structure, individual business locations within an industrial development may display the types and sizes of signs as described in subsections 16-60(a)(16) Rear entrance wall signs and (8) Window signs, and only one (1) of the following: (1) Awning sign, (9) Parapet/mansard roof sign, (10) Projecting sign, (11) Signs painted on buildings, referenced above or (12) Wall sign, referenced above. In addition to these signs, one (1) canopy sign is allowed on a canopy structure. 
(b)  The maximum total combined sign area for industrial development, each individual business within an industrial development and stand alone business on properties in the industrial district (I) that are five (5) acres in size or smaller is based on the business frontage as follows: 
Business Frontage Maximum Square Footage Signage 50 or less 50 51 to 99 75 100 to 150 120 150 and larger One (1) square foot per one (1) linear foot to a maximum of 300 square feet  
  
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 3, 10-10-05) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83 for additional illumination requirements. 
Sec. 16-61. - Mixed use districts-M1, M2, M3, MW. 
(a)  The following signs or types of signs are permitted on properties in the mixed use districts (M1, M2, M3 and MW): 
(1)  Awning sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. An awning sign cannot coexist with a wall sign. 
(2)  Building identification signs: Not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(3)  Canopy sign: See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(4)  Directional sign: Each sign not to exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. 
(5)  Flags: Three (3) per development, with each flag not to exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in area. 
(6)  *Monument sign: One (1) sign per development. The sign shall be located not less than ten (10) feet from the right-of-way lines and may not project into any public right-of-way. Sign can be single or dual faced. Signs must incorporate the materials, architectural features, color scheme and design of the principal structure(s). See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(7)  Nameplate or owner designation sign: On or near the front and/or rear door of each business conducted on the premises not to exceed three (3) square feet in area. 
(8)  Window signs: Total area must not exceed thirty (30) percent of the window area for each business and sign placement shall allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. Interior signage placed or displayed within two (2) feet of the window shall be subject to this provision. 
(9)  *Parapet/mansard roof sign: One (1) per business. Mansard roof sign must be on the lower slope of the roof and no part may extend above the top. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(10)  *Projecting sign: One (1) on the business front and one (1) in an alley. If on a corner lot, add one (1) sign. Must display only the name of the business to which it is attached. No extension allowed above the roofline/parapet wall. One (1) per fifty (50) linear feet and not within seven (7) feet of another projecting sign. Maximum area of sign face is nine (9) square feet and the bottom of the sign must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above grade. 
(11)  Signs painted on buildings: One (1) sign per development. Includes murals, mosaics and signs painted on any building surface. Not allowed on roof surface. Must be professionally designed and painted. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(12)  *Wall sign: One (1) sign located on the front wall. One (1) additional sign allowed for corner lots. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(13)  Real estate signs: One (1) per property allowed, not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area (sign face), nor six (6) feet in height from grade. 
(14)  Individual business locations : Individual business locations within a mixed use development may display the types and sizes of signs as described in subsections 16-61(a)(7) Nameplate or owner designation sign, (8) Window signs, and only one (1) of the following: (1) Awning sign, (9) Parapet/mansard roof sign, (10) Projecting sign, (11) Signs painted on buildings, or (12) Wall sign, referenced above. In addition to these signs, one (1) canopy sign is allowed on a canopy structure. 
(15)  Murals, entrance/exit signs, automated teller machine (ATM) identification signs, and other customer oriented directional signs shall not be counted toward the total sign area. 
(16)  No sign shall be erected within the sight triangle or clear vision triangle. 
(b)  The maximum total combined sign area for mixed use development, each individual business within a mixed use development and stand alone business on properties in the mixed use business frontage as follows: 
Business Frontage Maximum Square Footage Signage 50 or less 50 51 to 99 75 100 to 150 120 150 and larger One (1) square foot per one (1) linear foot to a maximum of 300 square feet  
(c)  Changeable copy signs as allowed as set forth at subsection 16-41(3) whenever associated uses or structures are permitted in the applicable mixed use zoning district. See section 16-62, for maximum dimensions. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04; Ord. No. O-16-05, § 3, 10-10-05) 
*Note- May be illuminated-See § 16-83 for additional illumination requirements.
