Sec. 16-63. - Mobile home park district (MHP). 
    Residential properties in a mobile home park district shall meet the requirements of section 16-55 set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-64. - Announcing signs. 
(a)  Signs announcing a subdivision, or property improvement, may be erected on the subject property in any zoning district after the final site plan has been approved. 
(1)  For lots up to one hundred (100) feet in width and any lot in the R1, R1A and R3 zoning districts- one (1) such sign, non-illuminated, with one (1) sign face only, parallel to the right-of-way, and not exceeding eight (8) feet in height from grade level, eight (8) feet in width, and thirty-two (32) square feet in area. 
(2)  For lots between one hundred (100) feet and three hundred (300) feet in width- one (1) such sign, non-illuminated, with one (1) sign face only, parallel to the right-of-way, and not exceeding eight (8) feet in height from grade level, twenty (20) feet in width, and one hundred twenty (120) square feet in area. 
(3)  For lots greater than three hundred (300) feet in width- two (2) such signs non-illuminated, each with one (1) sign face only, parallel to the right-of-way, and not exceeding eight (8) feet in height from grade level, twenty (20) feet in width, and one hundred twenty (120) square feet in area. 
(b)  The announcing sign must be removed upon issuance of the last certificate of occupancy for the property. 
(c)  The sign shall be removed if construction of infrastructure or structures has not commenced within ninety (90) days of a final site plan approval or issuance of the building permit unless additional time is allowed by council. 
(d)  Announcing signs shall not be illuminated. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-65. - Model sales office signs. 
(a)  One (1) model sales office sign, non-illuminated, erected to identify a model sales office, with one (1) sign face only, parallel to the right-of-way, not to exceed four (4) feet in height above grade level and four (4) square feet in area is allowed per subdivision or neighborhood. 
(b)  Model name signs, non-illuminated, erected to identify various models not exceeding four (4) square feet and not to exceed two (2) feet in height may be erected. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-66. - Remodeling or contractor signs. 
    Remodeling or contractor signs shall not be illuminated and may only be placed on property after issuance of building permit, and may remain until the permit expires, or construction is completed, whichever occurs first. 
(1)  Residential zoning districts: Remodeling or contractor signs with only one (1) face may be placed parallel to the right-of-way adjacent to the property, during the time of remodeling and/or renovation only, and such sign shall not exceed four (4) feet in height from grade level and four (4) square feet in area. 
(2)  Nonresidential zoning districts: Remodeling or contractor signs, with only one (1) face may be placed parallel to the right-of-way adjacent to the property, during the time of construction, remodeling, and/or renovation only, and such sign shall not exceed seven (7) feet in height from grade level and sixteen (16) square feet in area. For multi-use or multi-tenant projects, a remodeling or contractor sign may be displayed inside a tenant space window during remodeling or construction of a tenant space. Out-parcels may display one (1) such sign as set forth in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-67. - Grand opening signs, holiday signs, sidewalk sales signs, banners, special event signs. 
(a)  Flags are generally prohibited, except for placement limited by size and number as set forth at subsection 16-25(7). Banners, streamers, twirling balloons or other air or gas-filled figure and copy signs are also prohibited; except that by special permit, grand opening banners and/or flags shall be allowed for a maximum period of fourteen (14) days during the first ninety (90) days from: 
(1)  The opening day of a new business; 
(2)  The opening day of a business after a change of ownership; and/or 
(3)  The completion date of a substantial remodeling of a business premises requiring a building permit having a value of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. Only one (1) grand opening shall be permitted per 18-month period unless legal ownership changes. 
(b)  Holiday banners and flags shall be allowed for a period of seven (7) days prior to and six (6) days following a national holiday. 
(c)  Banners advertising a permitted sidewalk sale shall be allowed for a maximum of four (4) days from twenty-four (24) hours prior to the start of the sale subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  No more than one (1) banner not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet per business location; 
(2)  The banner shall be securely fastened to a substantial support on site at the business location and shall not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic or visibility; 
(3)  The banner shall not be attached to utility poles or landscaping, trees, antennae, trash receptacles, or the like; 
(4)  The banner shall be removed immediately after the permitted sidewalk sale ends and said permit expires. 
(5)  Banners may be placed on street light poles by the town as seasonal decorations, public announcements, etc. from time to time as deemed appropriate. 
(e)  Special event signs shall be allowed upon the issuance of a permit for a maximum of fourteen (14) days subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Special event signs may not exceed sixteen (16) square feet in surface area except when displayed as window signs, in which case, the total sign area of all special event signs in any one window may not exceed six (6) square feet and shall be placed to allow for a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building to the interior along a normal line of sight when viewing the cash register and sales transaction area. 
(2)  Banners used as special event signs are subject to the size and duration restrictions as set forth above and may be attached or fastened only in the manner described at subsection 16-67(c) 
(3)  Special event signs meeting all requirements of this chapter may be utilized to call attention to a civic event or other activity of a temporary nature held at that location. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03; Ord. No. O-06-04, § 2, 5-24-04) 
Sec. 16-68. - Temporary seasonal sales signs. 
    Commercial signage of a temporary nature advertising or promoting the sale of seasonal items (such as Christmas trees) is permitted to be displayed for not more than forty (40) days, said temporary seasonal sales signage not to exceed seven (7) feet in height and thirty-two (32) square feet in area. Businesses fronting on two (2) or more public right-of-ways may be permitted a maximum of two (2) such signs. Businesses located on out-parcels may, in addition to the above signage allowance, display an additional temporary seasonal sales sign facing the interior of the planned commercial development. All temporary seasonal sales signs must be removed within seven (7) days following the event. A permit is required. Temporary seasonal sales signs may be illuminated. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Secs. 16-69-16-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONSTRUCTION GUIDELINES 

Sec. 16-80. - Height measurement criteria. 
    The height of all monument signs shall be calculated from grade; "grade" is defined as the average finished ground level of a parcel on which a sign is located. The heights of monument signs located on berms shall be determined from grade level, and not from the top of a berm. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-81. - Sign area criteria. 
(a)  Monument and projecting signs. The area of a monument or projecting sign shall include the entire area within and enclosed by the exterior perimeter of all cabinets or modules within a single, continuous figure, including but not limited to, all written copy, logos, symbols, decorative embellishments and border or roof treatments. This shall include all open areas within said perimeters and all space separating said cabinets and modules. Only one (1) face (the largest) of any dual-faced sign shall be counted in calculating sign area. 
(b)  Wall signs. The area of a wall sign shall include the entire area within a single continuous perimeter composed of a square or rectangle which encloses the extreme limits of all sign elements affixed to the wall and/or window, including but not limited to, cabinet structures, written copy, logos, symbols, illustrations, decorative embellishments, border treatments and painted backgrounds framing the sign element. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-82. - Safety factors pertaining to all signs. 
    No sign shall be constructed or erected in such a manner that it will become a hazard to automotive or pedestrian traffic, nor shall any sign or lighting of such sign be so placed as to obstruct the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-83. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Structure. Every sign, together with its advertising structure, framework, braces, angles or other supports, shall be maintained in a safe condition, properly secured, supported and braced, shall be kept in good structural condition, and shall be clean and well painted at all times. 
(b)  Support. Every sign shall be constructed to withstand pressures as set forth in the building code, shall be rigidly and firmly braced, and shall be securely attached to the building or structure. 
(c)  Wood. All wood permitted to be used, either for new signs, for replacements of existing signs or for any part thereof, shall be of rot and deterioration-resistant materials. 
(d)  Illumination. 
(1)  Illuminated signs shall have their source of light concealed from view, except that where channel letters or figures are used for any sign, the illumination thereof may be visible if recessed within the depth of the channel. 
(2)  Illuminated signs shall have their intensity of illumination approved by the building official before issuance of any permit. 
(3)  Illuminated signs shall have all exterior electrical outlets terminated in a galvanized box with blank cover, which shall be flush with and not protrude beyond the finished surface of the exterior wall. 
(4)  Illuminated signs shall have all transformer boxes and other accessory equipment placed so that they are not visible from the exterior. 
(5)  Illuminated signs shall not have electric lights or fixtures attached to them in any manner, if they are of wood construction. 
(e)  Electrical. All illuminated signs shall, in addition, be subject to the provisions of the electrical code and the town building code and the permit fees required. All components used in electrical signs shall be approved by an approved testing laboratory and shall bear its label. 
(f)  Requirements. See section 16-22, for application submittal requirements. 
Sec. 16-84. - Wall signs. 
(a)  Wall signs shall not extend more than eighteen (18) inches from the wall or facade of the building to which they are attached. 
(b)  Wall signs shall not extend above the eaves of a building with a pitched roof or the parapet of a building with a flat roof. 
(c)  Wall signs shall be fastened directly to the wall by well-secured metal anchors in such manner as to withstand a fifty-pound-per-square-foot windload. 
Secs. 16-85-16-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NONCONFORMING SIGNS 

Sec. 16-100. - Defined. 
(a)  Any sign legally constructed pursuant to a valid permit and maintained within the town on October 27, 2003, or a sign or advertising structure legally constructed pursuant to a valid permit and maintained in an area annexed into the town after October 27, 2003, which by its height, type, area, location, use or structural support does not conform to the requirements of this chapter, shall be termed nonconforming. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the above, any sign legally constructed pursuant to a valid permit of a type allowed by this chapter, with dimensions that are within one hundred ten (110) percent of the dimensional requirements set forth herein shall not be subject to the removal and amortization provisions of section 16-101, but shall, however, be subject to the provisions of section 16-103, relating to damage and removal. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-101. - Removal and amortization schedule. 
(a)  All nonconforming signs or advertising structures not meeting the criteria as set forth in subsection 16-100(b) shall be removed or altered so as to conform to the provisions of this chapter by November 1, 2005, except for legally permitted freestanding non-pole signs which are exempt from removal and for pole signs which must be made to conform or be removed by January 1, 2004, since any such pole signs have been deemed non-conforming from the date of the last revision to the sign code on April 26, 1999 and will have had approximately five (5) years in which to realize an amortization of investment prior to the scheduled compliance or removal date of January 1, 2004. 
(b)  All signs which have been erected without benefit of a valid permit and all illegal signs shall be removed immediately. 
(c)  All nonconforming and illegal signs shall be removed at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-102. - Alterations to structure or sign face. 
    Alterations to the structure(s) or sign face(s) of nonconforming signs shall be permitted, so long as the alterations do not increase or enlarge the nonconforming nature of the sign. Prior to issuance of a permit to alter a sign structure(s) and sign face(s), the applicant shall acknowledge that issuance of a permit for alteration of a nonconforming sign structure(s) or sign face(s) shall not extend or modify the removal and amortization schedule set forth in section 16-101, and shall not entitle the sign owner to any reimbursement from the town at the time of removal of the nonconforming sign. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-103. - Damage. 
    Any nonconforming sign which is destroyed or damaged to the extent of fifty (50) percent or more of the sign and frame structure, inclusive, as determined by a professional appraisal, or is altered or replaced shall not be altered, replaced or reinstalled unless and until said sign has been made to conform to all applicable regulations of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-104. - Registration of nonconforming signs. 
    Each owner of any sign hereafter made nonconforming shall register said sign with the building official. Registration shall include the owners name and address, and the sign location. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-105. - Interpretation of conflicting provisions. 
    In the event of a conflict between any section, sentence, or clause, this chapter and any other section, sentence, or clause in this chapter, or any other chapter of portion thereof of this Code, or any other town ordinance, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Secs. 16-106-16-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 16-120. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The requirements of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the building official and/or code enforcement officers of the town and/or by any other lawful means. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-121. - Revocation. 
(a)  Every permit issued hereafter pursuant to the terms, conditions, regulations and provisions of this chapter may be revoked at any time by the building official upon the determination of the building official that a particular [sign] is not in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter; provided, however, that the building official has notified the owner of such sign in writing of such defect and the owner of such sign has not remedied the defect within the thirty (30) days allowed for the remedy of such defect. 
(b)  In the event the applicant for permit of a sign proposed to be established pursuant to the issuance of a valid permit has failed to construct, erect, establish or place the sign for which the permit was issued within three (3) months subsequent to the date of the issuance of permit, the permit shall automatically lapse and shall be of no further force and effect. Any individual erecting such sign after the revocation shall be deemed in violation of the terms, conditions, regulations and provisions of this chapter as if the owner or applicant had never received nor applied for a permit pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-122. - Inspection of existing signs. 
(a)  Upon inspection, the building official shall require the owner of any sign found to be in defective condition, or which does not comply with the terms, conditions and provisions of this article to be repaired or removed within thirty (30) days from the date of notice of such defect; provided, however, that if the building official shall determine that the maintenance or use of such sign shall adversely affect the public safety, he may require the immediate removal, at owner's expense, or prohibit the use of said sign until such defects shall have been remedied. 
(b)  The building official shall have the right, upon seven (7) calendar days' notice, to remove any sign which is not properly maintained, shows neglect, becomes dilapidated or is otherwise in violation of provisions of this chapter, if such sign is found unsafe or hazardous. The cost of such removal shall be paid by the owner. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-123. - Person responsible for fee. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or other person in control or possession of the real estate upon which any sign or advertising structure is located to keep all signs in good repair and to pay required fees, if any. Failure to pay required fees in a timely manner shall cause such sign to be a violation of this article and subject [to] removal as set forth at subsection 16-101(b). 
Sec. 16-124. - Vacant premises. 
    A sign shall be removed by the owner or lessee of the property when the use or business located on the property which the sign identifies or advertises is closed, abandoned, unoccupied, and/or the property is vacated, within thirty (30) days of closing, abandonment, or vacancy. The building official shall provide written notice to property owners or lessees who fail to remove signage within thirty (30) days, notifying the owner or lessee that the building official may remove the subject sign and assess the owner or lessee for the cost of removal. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-125. - Procedure on violations. 
(a)  A violation of any provision of this division shall be a violation of the Town Code of Ordinances, subject to fine, injunctive relief, code enforcement procedures and/or any other enforcement remedy legally available to the town. 
(b)  Signs erected without a valid permit, and/or prior to the issuance of a building permit, shall subject the property owner or sign contractor to a fine of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day, per sign. 
(c)  A sign contractor may also be subject to suspension or revocation of the town occupational license for repeated violations of this chapter. 
(d)  Failure to pay fines levied for violating this chapter may result in a moratorium on the issuance of sign permits for the violator until the subject fines have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-126. - Appeals. 
(a)  Appeal of building official decision regarding proposed signage. Any person or persons aggrieved by any final action of the building official with respect to proposed signage may file a notice of appeal setting forth the reasons for such appeal. Appeals must be filed with the town clerk within ten (10) days from the date of formal action by the building official accompanied by the appropriate fee as set by resolution of the town council. The filing of any appeal shall suspend the issuance of any building or other required permit until final action has been taken on the appeal. A timely-filed written appeal shall be placed on the next available town council agenda for final determination by the council after affording the appellant a full opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-127. - Issuance of permit not approval of violation. 
    The issuance of a permit upon plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for or approval of any violation of this chapter, nor shall such issuance prevent the building official from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said plans and specifications, or preventing the erection of any sign thereunder when in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Sec. 16-128. - Variances. 
(a)  A person seeking a variance to the provisions of this chapter shall file an application with the building official on forms provided by the town which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of petitioner; 
(2)  Location of building, structure or lot to which or upon which the sign or other advertising structure is located or is to be erected; 
(3)  Position of the sign or proposed sign in relation to nearby buildings and/or other structures; 
(4)  Twenty-seven (27) blueprints or inked drawings of the plans and specifications and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground; 
(5)  Justification for granting the variance requested utilizing the criteria for the granting of variances as set forth in subsection (c) of this section; 
(6)  Two (2) originals and twenty-five (25) copies of said application shall be submitted, through the building official. 
(b)  Within thirty (30) days of the receipt of the complete application and the payment of the required fee, together with the costs of public notice, a public hearing before the town council shall be scheduled. There shall be a publication of notice of the time, place and purpose of each hearing placed once in a newspaper of general circulation at least ten (10) days prior to such hearing. 
(c)  The standards to be considered by the town council prior to granting a sign variance are as follows: 
(1)  Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land on which the sign is proposed and that these conditions and/or circumstances are not applicable to other lands in the same zoning district or corridor. 
(2)  The special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant. 
(3)  The granting of the variance requested will not confer upon the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this chapter to others in the same zoning district or along the same corridor. 
(4)  Literal interpretations of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same zoning district or corridor under the terms of this chapter and would result in an unnecessary and undue hardship on the applicant. 
(5)  The grant of the variance is not contrary to the intent of this chapter, will be in harmony with the purpose of this chapter and will not be injurious to the area involved or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
(d)  Violations; time limitations. Violations of such conditions and safeguards as prescribed by the town council when made a part of the terms under which the variance is granted, shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and the variance shall be considered void. Variances shall become void if not exercised within six (6) months of the date granted. Before this six (6) month period has expired, the applicant may make a written request to the town council for an additional six (6) months extension. Any further extensions of time shall require a new application to be processed as a new case. 
(Ord. No. O-06-03, § 1, 10-27-03) 
Chapter 17 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-46; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; alcoholic beverages prohibited in certain public places, § 3-4; animals, Ch. 4; beaches, boats, waterways, Ch. 5; certain conduct prohibited on public beaches, § 5-18; limitations on anchoring, mooring, parking, etc., boats, § 5-32; discharging of certain matter into the water prohibited, § 5-40; use of vessels for dwelling purposes prohibited in certain areas, § 5-41; obstructing town boat ramp prohibited, § 5-43; bulkhead lines adopted, § 5-51; buildings prohibited beyond the established bulkhead line, § 5-52; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; excavation of land procedure, § 6-51 et seq.; satellite dish antenna regulations, § 6-66 et seq.; radio and television antennas, § 6-81 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 11; garage sale restrictions, § 11-66 et seq.; nuisances, Ch. 12; junked and abandoned vehicles and appliances, § 12-51 et seq.; obstruction of public easements, prohibited, § 13-5; police reserve officers, Ch. 15; signs and advertising, Ch. 16; subdivision and platting regulations, Ch. 17.5; speed limits on specific streets in the town, § 19-2; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; trailers and trailer camps, Ch. 20; parking regulations in trailer parks, § 20-2; parking prohibited in Bicentennial Park, § 20-3; utilities, Ch. 21; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Uniform minimum standards for roads, F.S. § 336.045. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Inspections. 
    All work performed on the public streets or sidewalks shall be inspected by the town engineer or other person designated by the town manager. 
(Code 1962, § 21-9) 
Sec. 17-2. - Exemption from county Ordinance No. 79-7 (county fair share contribution for road improvements ordinance). 
    It is the purpose of this ordinance that a "conflict" be established, as a term used in Article VIII, Section 1(f) between the provisions of this section and Ordinance No. 79-7, known as the "Fair Share Contribution for Road Improvements Ordinance," enacted by the Board of County Commissioners of Palm Beach, Florida, effective July 11, 1979. It is the intent of the town council that no portion of said county ordinance shall be applicable within the corporate limits of the Town of Lantana, Florida. The Town of Lantana shall not collect the road improvement impact fees as described in the aforesaid county ordinance during the term of this section. 
(Code 1962, § 21-26) 
Sec. 17-3. - Approval by city of private construction. 
    All proposed roads, streets, avenues, alleys, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, parkways and paving on private property shall be approved by the town engineer for correct grading and conformity to this chapter before construction is commenced. 
(Code 1962, § 21-3) 
Secs. 17-4-17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SWALE AREAS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O-10-86, § 1, adopted April 28, 1986, did not specifically amend this Code; hence codification of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as Art. II, §§ 17-31-17-36, was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 17-31. - Definition. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "swale area" shall mean those areas lying between the paved roadway and the sidewalk or between the paved roadway and the right-of-way boundary line adjacent to the paved roadway, which are the property of the town, or over which the town has exclusive control as part of its road and drainage right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(1), 4-28-86) 
Sec. 17-32. - Planting and removal; written approval required. 
    No trees shall be planted or removed from the areas except by the town or by private citizens who have obtained the written approval of the building official to plant or remove any tree. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(2), 4-28-86) 
Sec. 17-33. - Variety and location. 
(a)  Only those trees and/or vegetative matter which adhere to or are identified in the South Florida Water Management District Xeriscape Plant Guide No. 2 may be planted in swale areas within the town. This plant guide is on file with the building official of the town and may be consulted at any time during normal working hours. 
(b)  All trees and/or vegetation of any kind whatsoever, to be planted in swale areas must be planted in accordance with a site plan approved by the town. 
(c)  No other plantings of trees and/or any other type of vegetation shall be permitted in any swale area within the town. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(3), 4-28-86; Ord. No. O-6-91, § 1, 9-9-91; Ord. No. O-5-93, § 1, 1O-25-93) 
Sec. 17-34. - Sodding of swale areas; certain parking prohibited; continuous maintenance; certain material prohibited. 
(a)  The owner of any residential property within the town where a residence is under construction shall be required to sod the area between the lot line thereof and the street pavement, in a manner to be approved by the building official. This approval must be issued and the sod installed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the residence upon such lot. 
(b)  The owners of any residential property within the town where a residence or a residential structure is located shall be required to sod the area between the lot line thereof and the street pavement, in a manner to be approved by the building official. 
(c)  All sodded swale areas must be continually maintained by the property owner whose property abuts the swale area; the abutting property owner is responsible for the replacement of any sod in the swale area which is dead or which has been removed, damaged and/or destroyed. 
(d)  Parking in swale areas is strictly prohibited, except by the abutting property owner/resident and/or public service vehicle or except in emergency situations. In addition, parking any vehicle with a gross weight over six thousand eight hundred (6,800) pounds in a swale area in any residential zoning district, including the mixed-use districts, is strictly prohibited. Furthermore, parking any non-motorized vehicle, including but not limited to, boats, trailers, utility trailers or any other equipment, is prohibited in all swale areas and public rights-of-way; and no such non-motorized vehicles shall be parked and displayed for sale, lease or rent in these areas even on a temporary basis. Subsections 19-4(19) and (20) also set forth additional prohibitions against parking on commercially zoned property. The fine for these parking violations shall be as set forth in section 19-6 and may be enforced by the issuance of a parking citation by the town police department or by any other means available. These prohibitions against parking in the swale areas shall not apply for the following vehicles under the specific circumstances set forth as follows: 
(1)  Motor vehicles which are temporarily parked, during a period not to exceed eight (8) hours in any twenty-four-hour period, for the purpose of loading and unloading or vehicles making service calls; and 
(2)  The temporary parking of construction vehicles where construction is underway and for which a currently valid building permit has been issued by the town for display on the premises. 
(e)  No structure, building, obstruction, and/or material of any kind, whatsoever, is permitted within the swale areas in the town other than sodding and/or trees and vegetation planted in accordance with section 17-33 of the Town Code of Ordinances with an exception for round cement markers or turf blocks as set forth below in subsection (f); however, the placement of trees, vegetation, turf blocks or round cement markers in any swale area located within the town without a permit from the town is strictly prohibited. A permit for placement of such regulated materials within the swale area may be obtained from the town building official at no charge. 
(f)  Cement pyramids may not be used as swale protectors; however, round cement markers are not prohibited when placed a minimum of six (6) inches off street pavement edge, spaced at least three (3) feet apart subject to the permit requirement set forth above. Turf blocks may be used in certain areas of the swale subject to drainage considerations and the issuance of a permit in accordance with a proposed site plan depicting an appropriate swale area depression consistent with requirements listed in section 17-42 of the Lantana Code of Ordinances and approved by the town building official. The town building official may deny an application for a permit to install turf blocks in the swale when such proposed installation is determined to be detrimental to surface water drainage in the area. The following criteria will be used in the consideration of a swale drainage issue: 
(1)  The general topography of the area; 
(2)  The elevation of the swale area; 
(3)  The proposed swale area depression; and 
(4)  Recommendations of the utilities department. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(4), 4-28-86; Ord. No. O-5-93, § 2, 10-25-93; Ord. No. O-02-97, § 1, 2-10-97; Ord. No. O-21-00, § 1, 12-11-00; Ord. No. O-02-04, § 1, 3-8-04; Ord. No. O-02-04, § 1, 2-23-04) 
Sec. 17-35. - Paving prohibited. 
    No owner or occupant shall hereafter be permitted, nor shall they pave any portion of the swale area except for approved driveways for ingress and egress to the property. In this context, paving shall include concrete, asphalt, paving blocks, shellrock, soil cement and any other pervious or impervious paving material. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(5), 4-28-86) 
Sec. 17-36. - Variance. 
    The building board of adjustments and appeals shall hear any request for a variance from the provisions of this chapter. All procedures, rules and regulations shall be the same as those used by that board for its proceedings as fully set forth in the Standard Building Code, as adopted in Chapter 6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1(6), 4-28-86) 
Secs. 17-37-17-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAY ACCESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-1-90, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 1990, specifically amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Art. I, §§ 17-4-17-7. For classification purposes, said provisions have been redesignated as Art. III, §§ 17-41-17-44 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 17-41. - Curb cut; access width. 
    Driveway accesses shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in width at the right-of-way line unless an alternate means for retention of runoff waters is submitted to the building department as designed by a Florida registered engineer, with a design acceptable to the building official. 
(Ord. No. O-1-90, § 1, 1-22-90) 
Sec. 17-42. - Swale area depression. 
(a)  Driveway accesses within the swale area shall be depressed at a minimum of four (4) inches below the street pavement edge. The depression shall be placed at a minimum of four (4) feet from the street pavement edge, or equal distance from the pavement edge and the sidewalk or right-of-way/property line when no sidewalk exists. 
(b)  Deviation from the above-stated elevations due to topographic conditions may be allowed only when a plan designed and submitted by a Florida registered engineer is approved by the building official as an acceptable alternative to the requirements set forth in subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. O-1-90, § 1, 1-22-90; Ord. No. O-02-04, § 2, 2-23-04) 
Cross reference- Swale areas, § 17-31 et seq. 
Sec. 17-43. - Construction of accesses. 
    Driveway accesses within utility easements and street rights-of-way may be constructed with various pervious and impervious materials. All such materials shall be bound and restricted to the access area. Concrete construction shall be six (6) inches thick with no steel reinforcement within the swale, and shall have a construction/expansion joint at sidewalk or right-of-way line where no sidewalk exists. Construction finishes shall be flush with the finished surface of the adjoining sidewalk and/or driveway. Construction finishes at adjoining street pavement shall not exceed one (1) inch above the pavement edge. 
(Ord. No. O-1-90, § 1, 1-22-90) 
Sec. 17-44. - Building permit. 
    Permits issued are contingent upon compliance with the above standards, as written. Any contractor, individual, firm, corporation, or agent acting in violation of the above-written standards, as adopted by the town, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, subject to punishment as provided by state law. Any building permit issued for the construction which has been deemed in violation of any of the state codes and/or the ordinances of the town shall be demolished and removed at the sole expense of the contractor/individual, etc., unless, in the opinion of the building official, same can be corrected in such a manner so as to meet all codes. 
(Ord. No. O-1-90, § 1, 1-22-90) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 11. 
Secs. 17-45-17-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TREES AND SHRUBBERY IN PUBLIC PLACES 

Sec. 17-50. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed:] 
    Park Trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the town, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Streets trees are herein defined as shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the town. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
Sec. 17-51. - Public tree care. 
    The town shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The town public works department may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with Chapter 17, Article II, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
Sec. 17-52. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or town department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property except in cases where the public's health, safety and welfare may be in jeopardy as determined by the town public works department. The town shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light, or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter with the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempt from this ordinance at the determination of the town public works department. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
Sec. 17-53. - Pruning; corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the town shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be an adequate clear space above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
Sec. 17-54. - Dead, diseased and exotic tree removal on public property. 
    The town shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead, diseased or exotic trees, (as defined in Section 23-132(n) of the town Zoning Code), on public property within the town, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which could constitute a potential threat to other trees within the town. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
Sec. 17-55. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article may be enforced by the code enforcement procedures as set forth in Chapter 2, Article IV of this Code or may be enforced by any other lawful means available to the town. 
(Ord. No. O-1-92, § 1, 4-13-92) 
ARTICLE V. - RIGHT-OF-WAY REGULATIONS 

Sec. 17-56. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is: 
(1)  To establish a competitively neutral policy for the use of the public right-of-way for the provision of local exchange telecommunications services, toll telephone telecommunications services, and other utilities, including but not limited to, those defined in Section 337.401, Florida Statutes; 
(2)  To regulate the placement of structures and facilities in the public right-of-way pursuant to its governmental powers as set forth at Chapter 166, Florida Statutes; 
(3)  To prescribe reasonable rules for such uses pursuant to Sections 337.401 and 364.0361, Florida Statutes, so as to minimize disruption of services in the public right-of-way, regulate the use of the public right-of-way by telecommunications and other utilities providers, and to regulate the construction, installation, maintenance, repair, removal and replacement of facilities in the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00) 
Sec. 17-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antenna means communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic frequency signals used in providing wireless services. 
    Applicable codes means uniform building, fire, electrical, plumbing, or mechanical codes adopted by a recognized national code organization or local amendments to those codes enacted solely to address threats of destruction of property or injury to persons, and the regulations and design standards contained in this article. 
    Collocate or collocation means to install, mount, maintain, modify, operate, or replace one (1) or more wireless facilities on, under, within, or adjacent to a wireless support structure or utility pole. The term does not include the installation of a new utility pole or wireless support structure in the public rights-of-way. 
    Communications facility or system means any permanent or temporary plant, equipment and property, including, but not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, fiber optics, poles, antennae, converters, splice boxes, cabinets, hand-holes, manholes, vaults, drains, surface location markers, appurtenances, and other equipment or pathways placed or maintained, or to be placed or maintained, upon, under, over, or along any public rights-of-way of the town and used or capable of being used to transmit, convey, route, receive, distribute, provide or offer communications services. This includes any facility that may be used to provide communications services. Multiple cables, conduits, strands, or fibers located within the same conduit shall be considered one (1) communications facility. 
    Communications facility provider means a person who is engaged, directly or indirectly, in the business of leasing, licensing, subleasing, subletting or hiring, to one (1) or more communications service providers, all or a portion of the tangible personal property used in a communications facility, including, but not limited to, towers, poles, tower space, antennas, transmitters, and transmission lines placed or maintained upon, under, over, or along any public rights-of-way of the county. Provisions of this division that apply only to communications facility providers shall not apply to communications services providers, even if the communication services provider also operates, licenses, leases, subleases, or sublets communications facilities. 
    Communications services shall be as defined in F.S. § 202.11(1). 
    Communications services provider means any person, including a municipality or county, providing communications services through the placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way. Communications services provider shall also include any person, including a municipality or county that places or maintains a communications facility in public rights-of-way but does not provide communications services. 
    FCC shall mean the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Micro wireless facility means a small wireless facility having dimensions no larger than twenty-four (24) inches in length, fifteen (15) inches in width, and twelve (12) inches in height and an exterior antenna, if any, no longer than eleven (11) inches. 
    Pass-through provider includes any person who places or maintains a communications facility in the public rights-of-way of the town and who does not remit taxes to the town pursuant to chapter 202. 
    Person includes individuals, children, firms, associations, joint ventures, partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations, and all other groups or combinations. 
    Public right-of-way shall mean a public right-of-way, public utility easement, highway, street or alley owned by the town, dedicated to the town or to the public, or for which the town holds a property interest and exercises rights of management or control. This term shall include the surface, the air space over the surface and the area below the surface of all public roads, streets, highways, alleys, boulevards, bridges, tunnels, public utility easements, and all public grounds. 
    Registrant shall mean a company that has registered with the town in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
    Registration and register shall mean the process described in section 17-58 whereby a communications services provider or other provider provides certain information to the town. 
    Small wireless facility means a wireless facility that meets the following qualifications: 
(1)  Each antenna associated with the facility is located inside an enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet in volume or, in the case of antennas that have exposed elements, each antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet in volume; and 
(2)  All other wireless equipment associated with the facility is cumulatively no more than twenty-eight (28) cubic feet in volume. The following types of associated ancillary equipment are not included in the calculation of equipment volume: electric meters, concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation boxes, ground-based enclosures, grounding equipment, power transfer switches, cutoff switches, vertical cable runs for the connection of power and other services, and utility poles or other support structures. 
    Town shall mean Town of Lantana, Florida. 
    Utility or utilities shall refer to entities that place in the public right-of-way any electric transmission, voice, or telegraph lines, data or other communications services lines or wireless facilities, ditches, services, water, heat or gas mains, pipelines, fences; or any other structures, pipes, lines or facilities. 
    Utility pole, with regard to chapter 17, means a pole or similar structure that is used in whole or in part to provide communications services or for electric distribution, lighting, traffic control, signage, or a similar function. The term includes the vertical support structure for traffic lights but does not include a horizontal structure to which signal lights or other traffic control devices are attached and does not include a pole or similar structure fifteen (15) feet in height or less. 
    Wireless facility means equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless communications between user equipment and a communications network, including radio transceivers, antennas, wires, coaxial or fiber-optic cable or other cables, regular and backup power supplies, and comparable equipment, regardless of technological configuration, and equipment associated with wireless communications. The term includes small wireless facilities. The term does not include: 
(1)  The structure or improvements on, under, within, or adjacent to the structure on which the equipment is collocated; 
(2)  Wireline backhaul facilities; or 
(3)  Coaxial or fiber-optic cable that is between wireless structures or utility poles or that is otherwise not immediately adjacent to or directly associated with a particular antenna. 
    Wireless infrastructure provider means a person who has been certified to provide telecommunications service in the state and who builds or installs wireless communication transmission equipment, wireless facilities, or wireless support structures but is not a wireless service provider. 
    Wireless provider means a wireless infrastructure provider or a wireless services provider. 
    Wireless services mean any services provided using licensed or unlicensed spectrum, whether at a fixed location or mobile, using wireless facilities. 
    Wireless services provider means a person who provides wireless services. 
    Wireless support structure means a freestanding structure, such as a monopole, a guyed or self-supporting tower, or another existing or proposed structure designed to support or capable of supporting wireless facilities. The term does not include a utility pole. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-58. - Registration for placing or maintaining communications facility or other facilities in right-of-way. 
(a)  Any person that desires to erect, construct, install, maintain, place, repair, extend, expand, remove, locate or relocate a permanent or temporary communications facility or other facility in, on, under, over or across the public right-of-way in the town shall first register with the town in accordance with this article. 
(b)  Subject to the terms and conditions contained in this article, a registrant may erect, construct, install, place, repair, maintain, expand, remove, locate or relocate a permanent or temporary communications facility or other facility in, on, over, under, or across the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-59. - Nature of registration. 
    A registration shall not convey title, equitable or legal, in the public right-of-way. Registration under this article governs the occupation of public rights-of-way only. Registration does not excuse a communications services provider or other provider from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before locating its facilities on the town's or another person's facilities. Registration does not excuse any provider from complying with all applicable town ordinances, including this article. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-60. - Registration; effectiveness of registration. 
(a)  Registration. Any communications services provider or other utility provider desiring to use the public right-of-way shall file a registration form with the town which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name of the applicant; 
(2)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant's primary contact person in connection with the registration; 
(3)  Evidence of the insurance coverage required under this article and acknowledgment of the indemnity and other provisions of this article; which acknowledgment shall not be considered an agreement to the provisions; and 
(4)  The number of the applicant's certificate or certificates of authorization, if any, to provide communication services or any other type of services issued by the Florida Public Services Commission, the Federal Communications Commission or other applicable governing boards or commissions. 
(b)  Review by town. The town will review the information submitted by the applicant. If the applicant submits all information in accordance with subsection 17-60(a) above, the registration shall be effective and the town shall notify the applicant of the effectiveness of the registration in writing. If the town determines that the information has not been submitted in accordance with the above-referenced subsection, the town shall notify the applicant in writing of the non-effectiveness of registration. The town shall so reply to an applicant within thirty (30) days after receipt of the registration information from the applicant. 
(c)  Cancellation of registration. A registrant may cancel a registration upon written notice to the town that it will no longer place, maintain or own any communications facility or other facilities in public right-of-way of the town and will no longer need to pull permits to perform work in public right-of-way. A registrant cannot cancel a registration if the registrant continues to place, maintain or own any communications facility or other type facilities in the public right-of-way. 
(d)  No priority in registration. Registration does not establish any priority for the use of the public right-of-way; however an effective registration is required prior to the issuance of a permit to work in the public right-of-way. The fact that a communications services provider or other provider is registered shall not establish any right or priority for the use of the public right-of-way. 
(e)  Renewal of registration. A registrant shall renew its registration with the town by October 1 every two (2) years from the date of its initial registration in accordance with the registration requirements in this article. Within thirty (30) days of any change in the information required to be submitted pursuant to subsection 17-60(a) above, a registrant shall provide updated information to the town. If no information in the then-existing registration has changed, the renewal may state that no information has changed. Registrations are expressly subject to any future amendment to or replacement of this article and further subject to any additional town ordinances, as well as any state or federal laws that may be enacted during the term of the registration. If a registrant fails to renew its registration, the sole consequence shall be that the town may restrict the registrant from obtaining permits under subsection (g) below until the other provider has complied with the registration requirements of this article. 
(f)  Permits. A permit is hereby required by any person that desires to erect, construct, install, maintain, place, repair, extend, expand, remove, locate or relocate a permanent or temporary communications facility or other type facility in any public right-of-way except as provided below: 
(1)  Routine maintenance; 
(2)  Replacement of existing wireless facilities with wireless facilities that are substantially similar or of the same or smaller size; 
(3)  Installation, placement, maintenance, or replacement of micro wireless facilities that are suspended on cables strung between existing utility poles in compliance with applicable codes by or for a communications services provider authorized to occupy the rights-of-way and who is remitting taxes under chapter 202; 
(4)  Aerial facilities located between utility poles with associated pole attachments that do not provide wireless services. 
    An effective registration shall be a condition of obtaining a permit. An effective registration does not mean that applicable permitting requirements shall not apply or that such requirements have been or will be deemed to have been satisfied. Permit fees shall be paid upon the submissions of an application for same; the amount of such permit fee shall be set by resolution of the town council. As the town has elected to collect the higher tax rate, no permit fees shall be collected from communication services providers pursuant to F.S. § 337.401(3)(c). 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-61. - Transfer of registration. 
    If the registrant transfers or assigns its registration incident to a sale or other transfer of the registrant's assets located within the town, the transferee or assignee shall be obligated to comply with the terms of this article. Written notice of any such transfer or assignment shall be provided to the town as of the effective closing date of such transfer. In order for the transfer of registration to be effective, such written notice must include the identity of the transferee or assignee, and notice of any changes to the information provided under subsection 17-60(a), including any changed evidence of insurance coverage. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-62. - Existing communications facilities in right-of-way. 
    Lines or cables of communications facilities or other facilities which have been constructed or placed in the public right-of-way prior to the November 27, 2000 may remain in the right-of-way provided the provider complies with the registration provisions of this article. Providers with existing lines and cables have one hundred twenty (120) days from the November 27, 2000 to comply with the terms of this article, or be found in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-63. - Suspension of permits. 
    Subject to section 17-64 below, the town may suspend a permit for work in the public rights-of-way for one (1) or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  Violation of permit conditions, including conditions set forth in this article or other applicable town codes or regulations governing use of public right-of-way; 
(2)  Misrepresentation or fraud by registrant in a registration or permit application to the town; 
(3)  Failure to relocate or remove facilities as may be lawfully required by the town; or 
(4)  Failure to properly renew or ineffectiveness of registration. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-64. - Appeals. 
    Final, written decisions of the town manager suspending or denying a permit, denying an application for a registration or denying an application for renewal of a registration are subject to appeal. An appeal must be filed with the town manager within thirty (30) days of the date of the final, written decision to be appealed. Any appeal not timely filed as set forth herein shall be waived. The town council shall consider the appeal at the next regularly scheduled meeting and shall consider whether the applicant meets the requirements for a registration or permit based upon the provisions of this article and the applicable state and federal laws. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-65. - Construction in the right-of-way. 
(a)  Permits to construct. The registrant may construct the communications system or other utilities in the public right-of-way specifically identified in permits obtained in accordance with applicable provisions of this article or other applicable town codes and regulations. The permission to use and construct in the public right-of-way is only for those areas specifically identified in the permit. 
(b)  Compliance with town codes and regulations. Registrant agrees to comply with all applicable codes in constructing any communications facilities or other facilities in the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to, engineering regulations, permit requirements, contractor licensing requirements, fire codes and zoning codes. 
(c)  Registrant must obtain applicable permits. Except in the case of an emergency and as otherwise provided by section 17-60(g), registrant shall not commence any construction in the public right-of-way until all applicable permits have been issued by the town or other appropriate authority. The term emergency shall mean an out-of-service condition or other condition that may affect the public's health, safety and welfare. Registrant shall provide reasonable advance notice to the town of its intent to commence construction in the right-of-way in the event of an emergency. Registrant acknowledges that as a condition of granting such permits, the town may impose conditions on the permits as necessary and reasonable for the construction in the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Construction standards. Registrant shall construct, maintain, install, remove and/or repair the communications facilities or other utilities in the public right-of-way in compliance with all applicable construction standards as established by all local, state or federal law and in conformance with the town's codes and regulations. Registrant shall use and exercise due caution, care, skill and expertise in performing work in the public right-of-way and shall take all reasonable steps to safeguard work site areas. 
(e)  Installation and construction schedule; inspections. In the interest of the public's health, safety and welfare, registrant shall cooperate with town and town's management actions in coordinating use of the public right-of-way. Upon request of the town, a registrant shall coordinate work under a permit with any other construction, installation or repairs that may be occurring or immediately scheduled to occur in the subject public right-of-way and alter its construction schedule as necessary so as to minimize disruptions and disturbance in the public right-of-way. 
(f)  Maintenance. A registrant shall maintain its facilities in the public right-of-way in a safe condition. 
(g)  Notice to town. Prior to any excavation in the public right-of-way for construction, installation, repair or maintenance, the registrant must call prior to construction activity to locate any underground equipment in accordance with F.S. ch. 556, as it may be amended. A registrant must be a member of Sunshine State One Call of Florida, Inc. (1-800-432-4770) or any successor alert and warning system to protect and locate its underground equipment. 
(h)  Removal of registrant's cables/lines in right-of-way. To the extent authorized by F.S. § 337.403 town may require registrant to remove or relocate, and registrant shall, at town's direction, remove or relocate any cable, line, or installation in the public right-of-way when the town manager determines that such removal or relocation is necessary to protect or preserve the public health, safety and welfare, or to protect the proper operation of town's traffic signals or traffic control devices or other town facilities. Town shall provide ninety (90) days written notice to registrant before the lines must be relocated or removed. If registrant fails to commence and complete this removal work by the dates requested by the town in its written notice, or within thirty (30) days following the expiration or termination of this registration, then the town shall have the right to perform this removal work and charge registrant for the costs incurred by the town in performing this work. Upon payment by registrant of the costs to the town, the town shall promptly return to registrant equipment removed by town pursuant to this provision. 
(i)  Restoration of right-of-way. Upon the completion of each installation, construction, repair, maintenance, or removal in the right-of-way, a registrant shall restore the public right-of-way to a safe condition and to the town's standard specifications for right-of-way, at registrant's expense. Registrant shall, at its own expense, repair or replace any other property disturbed or damaged on account of its activities in the public right-of-way. 
(j)  Interference with other uses in public right-of-way. A registrant shall use reasonable efforts not to disturb or otherwise disrupt the operation or maintenance of any other utilities or uses in the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to, sewers, storm drains, gas or water mains, or other underground cables or conduits. 
(k)  No warranties or representations by town. The town makes no warranties or representations regarding the fitness or suitability of town's property for the installation of registrant's cables or conduits and any performance of work or costs incurred by registrant or provision of services shall be at registrant's sole risk. 
(l)  As-builts. Within thirty (30) days of a request by the town, the registrant shall provide the town with copies of as-built drawings on disk of the construction covered by the permit, in a format specified by the town manager, provided such format is maintained by the registrant. Any such maintained geographic data, media and information will be provided at no cost to town. In no event shall any proprietary confidential information be required to be disclosed pursuant to this section. 
(m)  Relocation of facilities and reservation of the town's rights. 
(1)  The town reserves the right to lay, and permit to be laid, sewer, gas, water, electric, storm drainage, communications, and other pipelines or cables or conduit, and to do and to permit to be done any underground installation or improvement that may be deemed necessary or proper by the town in, across, along, over or under any public right-of-way occupied by the registrant, and to change any curb or sidewalk or the grade of any street. The town, its contractors and subcontractors shall be required to call Sunshine State One Call of Florida, Inc. (1-800-432-4770), or successor alert and warning system, prior to excavation, in accordance with F.S. ch. 556, as it may be amended, in order to avoid damages to registrant's facilities. 
(2)  The town expressly reserves the right to change, or cause to be changed through exercise of its police powers, the grading, installation, relocation, or width of the town streets, sidewalks, bikeways, alleys, public thoroughfares, highways and public ways and places within the present limits of the town and within said limits as same may from time to time be altered, and the registrant shall relocate, at its own expense where allowed by F.S. § 337.403, as it may be amended, its poles wires, cables, anchors, manholes, conduits, and other facilities and appurtenances in order to accommodate the installation, relocation, widening or changing of the grade of any public streets, sidewalks, bikeways, alleys, public thoroughfares, highways and public ways and places, including if necessary relocating such poles, wires, cables, anchors, manholes, conduits or other facilities or appurtenances to a sufficient distance from the edge of the pavement to permit a reasonable work area for machinery and individuals engaged in installing, relocating, widening, or changing the grade of any such streets, sidewalks, bikeways, alleys, public thoroughfares, highways and public ways and places. Upon notice in writing from the town that changes in the public right-of-way are required pursuant to the town's police power in such a manner as will necessitate the relocation of its facilities in the public right-of-way, the registrant shall relocate the same at no expense to the town, where allowed by F.S. § 337.403, as it may be amended, so as to permit the construction of such improvements when ordered. Should the registrant fail to comply with such notice, the facilities may be relocated by the town and the cost thereof recovered from the registrant, where allowed by F.S. § 337.403, as it may be amended. 
(n)  A wireless facility that is a portion of a communication facility, such as an antenna, which is attached to a legally maintained vertical structure in the public rights-of-way, such as a light pole or utility pole ("vertical structure(s)"), shall be subject to the criteria below and processed in accordance with the timeframes specified in F.S. ch. 337.401: 
(1)  Such wireless facilities may not extend more than ten (10) feet above the highest point of the vertical structure (i.e., utility pole). Unless waived by the town council, the height of a new utility pole is limited to the tallest existing utility pole as of July 1, 2017, located in the same right-of-way, other than a utility pole for which a waiver has previously been granted, measured from grade in place within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed location. If there is no utility pole within five hundred (500) feet, the height of the new utility pole shall be limited to fifty (50) feet; 
(2)  Such wireless facilities that are attached to a vertical structure located in public rights-of-way that is fifteen (15) feet or less in width and is located adjacent to real property used as a single-family residence shall, to the extent possible given the volumetric allowances in F.S. § 337.401(7), be flush mounted to the vertical structure; 
(3)  Such wireless facilities shall not have any type of lighted signal, lights, or illuminations unless required by an applicable federal, state, or local rule, regulation, or law; 
(4)  Such wireless facilities shall comply with any applicable Federal Communications Commission Emissions Standards; 
(5)  The design, construction, and installation of such wireless facilities shall comply with any applicable local building codes; 
(6)  No commercial advertising shall be allowed on such wireless facilities; and 
(7)  Any accessory equipment and related housing in the public rights-of-way that are used in conjunction with such a wireless facility shall comply with all applicable codes governing the placement and design of such equipment; 
(8)  Any new or replacement poles shall be of similar design, material, and color to the utility poles within two hundred fifty (250) feet of in the same right-of-way, or as otherwise approved; 
(9)  Wireless facilities, including ground-mounted equipment, shall be placed so as to not materially interfere with the safe operation of traffic control equipment, sight lines or clear zones for transportation, pedestrians, public safety purposes, or the free flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic; 
(10)  The town may request that ground-mounted equipment use materials, colors, textures, screening, and landscape that will blend into the natural setting and surrounding built environment to minimize the visual impact, as permitted by F.S. § 337.401; 
(11)  The town may request ground-mounted equipment be placed in the public rights-of-way a reasonable distance from the vertical structure it serves as permitted by F.S. § 337.401(7); 
(12)  Ground-mounted equipment shall be placed so as to not materially interfere with the intended purpose of the right-of-way, swales, or stormwater drainage features and appurtenances. 
(13)  The town may deny a proposed collocation of a small wireless facility in the public rights-of-way if the proposed collocation: 
a.  Materially interferes with the safe operation of traffic control equipment. 
b.  Materially interferes with sight lines or clear zones for transportation, pedestrians, or public safety purposes. 
c.  Materially interferes with compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act or similar federal or state standards regarding pedestrian access or movement. 
d.  Materially fails to comply with the 2010 edition of the Florida Department of Transportation Utility Accommodation Manual. 
e.  Fails to comply with applicable codes. 
(14)  An applicant seeking to collocate small wireless facilities may file a consolidated application and receive a single permit for the collocation of up to thirty (30) small wireless facilities. 
(o)  Towers, excluding utility poles, having a sole purpose to serve as a mounting device for antennae, are expressly prohibited from being placed in the public rights-of-way, except as permitted by F.S. § 337.401. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-66. - Insurance and indemnification. 
(a)  Indemnification. Registrant shall agree to protect, defend, reimburse, indemnify and hold town, its agents, employees and elected officers and each of them free and harmless at all times from and against any and all suits, actions, legal or administrative proceedings, claims, demands, damages, liabilities, interest, attorney's fees, costs and expenses of whatsoever kind or nature whether arising in any manner directly or indirectly caused, occasioned or contributed to in whole or in part, by reason of any act, omission or fault, of anyone acting under registrant's direction or control, or on registrant's behalf in any matter related to registrant's use of the right-of-way or any property registrant is entitled or authorized to use as a result of the registration or other authorization. Registrant's aforesaid indemnity and hold harmless obligations, or portions or applications thereof, shall apply to the fullest extent permitted by law but in no event shall they apply to liability caused by the negligence or willful misconduct of the town, its respective agents, servants, employees or officers, nor shall the liability limits set forth in F.S. § 768.28 be waived. 
(b)  Insurance. A registrant shall maintain in full force and effect general liability insurance acceptable to the town, which may be satisfied by evidence of self-insurance or other types of insurance acceptable to the town, which specifically covers all exposures incident to the intent and responsibilities under this article in the amounts set forth below: 
(1)  Workers' compensation insurance within Florida statutory limits and employers' liability insurance with minimum limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each accident. 
(2)  Comprehensive general liability insurance with minimum limits of three million dollar ($3,000,000.00) as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury, personal injury and property damage. The policy shall provide blanket liability insurance and shall include coverage for products and completed operations liability, independent contractor's liability; coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage. 
(3)  Automobile liability insurance covering all owned, hired, and non-owned vehicles in use by the provider, its employees and agents, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the applicable state law, including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) as the combined single limit for each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
(4)  Named insureds. All certificates of insurance shall name the town as an additional insured. 
(5)  Cancellation of policies of insurance. At least sixty (60) days prior written notice shall be given to the town by the insurer of any intention not to renew such policy or to cancel, replace or materially alter same, such notice to be given by registered mail to the town. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 17-67. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any violation of any of the provisions of this article may be enforced as provided for in F.S. ch. 162. Each day or fraction thereof the violation continues shall be considered as a separate offense. In addition, the town can pursue any and/or all other lawful actions, including filing a complaint with Florida Public Service Commission or Federal Communications Commission advising of violations of town ordinances, filing an injunction in circuit court to enforce the terms of the article, registration or permit or to enjoin the use of the public right-of-way, pursuing action before the code enforcement board to impose daily fines, and/or denying permits or development orders for other projects or use of the right-of-way by the provider. These remedies shall be cumulative. 
(Ord. No. O-19-00, § 1, 11-27-00; Ord. No. O-16-2017, § 1, 2-12-18) 
Secs. 17-68-17-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TOWN PARKS 

Sec. 17-76. - Enforcement authority. 
(a)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the police department and operations department employees to enforce this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required by this article or for any person to fail to comply with any lawful or any reasonable order given by the police department officers or operations department employees. 
(c)  The town manager may adopt reasonable rules and regulations as he/she may deem necessary to manage and govern park property and activities. 
(Ord. No. O-04-2014, § 1, 2-24-14) 
Sec. 17-77. - Park hours of use. 
    Unless specifically stated herein, all town parks (including the Nature Preserve) shall be open each day from sunrise to sunset, every day of the year. Sportsman's Park and Bicentennial Park shall be open for use by the public twenty-four (24) hours per day, every day of the year. After sunset, the only activities and uses permitted in Sportsman's Park and Bicentennial Park shall be parking, access to and use of the restroom facilities, access to and use of the fishing pier and fishing from the parks' seawalls. The basketball courts at Sport's Park shall be open for use by the public on Sunday through Thursday from sunrise until 9:00 p.m. and on Friday and Saturday from sunrise until 10:00 p.m. every day of the year. 
(a)  No person shall enter or remain upon park property at any time during which the park is closed unless specific authorization for such after-hours use has been approved in writing by the town manager. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other regulations set forth hereinabove, the town manager shall have the authority to establish later opening hours and earlier closing hours for any park by posting signs clearly identifying the opening or closing hours. Additionally, the town manager shall also have the authority to temporarily close any park if he/she deems such closure to be in the best interests of the town. 
(c)  No person shall remain upon park property after a lawful command to leave by any law enforcement officer or by town operations employees, regardless of whether the park is open or closed. 
(Ord. No. O-04-2014, § 1, 2-24-14; Ord. No. O-10-2018, § 1, 12-10-18) 
Sec. 17-78. - Nature preserve-Smoking prohibited. 
    Due to the native Florida scrub and other native plants and habitats within the nature preserve, smoking and open flames represent a unique and dangerous threat to public safety and the nature preserve itself. Therefore, smoking and/or open flames of any type are specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-04-2014, § 1, 2-24-14) 
Secs. 17-79-17-100. - Reserved.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17.5-1. - Legislative intent.
