    The intent of this chapter is to establish procedures and standards for the development and subdivision of real estate in the town in an effort to, among other things, insure proper legal description, identification, monumentation and recording of real estate boundaries; aid in the coordination of land development in the town in accordance with orderly physical patterns; discourage haphazard, premature, uneconomic or scattered land development; insure safe and convenient traffic control; encourage development of an economically stable and healthful community; insure adequate utilities; prevent periodic and seasonal flooding by providing protective flood control and drainage facilities; provide public open spaces for recreation; insure land subdivision with installation of adequate and necessary physical improvements; insure that the citizens and taxpayers of the town will not have to bear the costs resulting from haphazard subdivision of land and the lack of authority to require installation by the developer of adequate and necessary physical improvements; insure to the purchaser of land in a subdivision that necessary improvements of lasting quality have been installed. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-2. - Limitation as to town maintenance. 
    Nothing in these regulations shall be construed as meaning that the town shall take over for maintenance any road, street, public parking or other public area, or drainage facility related thereto, except those designed and built in accordance with the town requirements and taken over for town maintenance by specific town council action. The assumption of maintenance by the town under these regulations shall not be construed to mean that the town shall assume installation, operating or other costs of street lighting. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-3. - Conflicts. 
    Where there is a conflict between this [chapter and] any other ordinance or regulation, the more stringent shall apply. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-4. - Other regulations. 
    Compliance with these regulations does not preclude the developer's responsibilities to comply with any and all applicable regulations administered by any county, state, or federal agency or department, which would affect the development of lands in the town. 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 17.5-5. - Definitions. 
    All words used in the present tense shall include the future tense; all words used in the plural number shall include the singular number unless the natural construction indicates otherwise; the words "used for" shall include the meaning "designed for"; the word "structure" shall include the word "building, " the word "lot" shall include the words "plot" and "tract"; and the word "shall" is mandatory. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the terms or words located in [Article XII, ] Appendix 13 shall be used in interpretation of the purpose [and] intent [herein.] 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION 

Sec. 17.5-6. - Requirements for platting. 
    No person, firm, corporation or any other association shall create a subdivision of a tract of land anywhere in the Town of Lantana except in conformity with this chapter. No subdivision shall be platted or recorded nor shall any building permit be issued unless such subdivision meets all the provisions of this chapter and those of any applicable laws of the State of Florida, and has been approved in accordance with the requirements as herein set forth, except that the following shall be exempt and not subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(a)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where no new parcels or residual parcels result in lots of less area, width, or depth than the original platted lots or the existing replotted lots, where no new street is created and where all current district regulations can be met for the zoning district in which the property is located. 
(b)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land to or between adjoining property owners where such sale or exchange does not create additional lots and does not reduce any lot to area less than the zoning district in which the property is located permits, and no dedications or improvements are required under this chapter. 
(c)  Mobile home parks developed for rental purposes under a unity of title. 
(d)  Tracts of parcels of land shown on unrecorded maps, plats, drawings or surveys which tract or parcel was at the time of preparation of such map, plat, drawing or survey under the ownership of a single person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, joint venture, estate, trust joint tenancy, tenancy by the entireties or other combinations of persons acting as a unit where such map, plat, drawing or survey was in existence prior to the effective date hereof and where at least thirty (30) percent of the parcels, tracts or lots shown on said unrecorded map, plat, drawing or survey were subject to deeds, agreement for deeds, installment land sales contracts, or other instruments of conveyance properly executed prior to the effective date of this chapter and where the land encompassed by said unrecorded map, plat, drawing or survey was registered with the Department of Business Regulation, Division of Florida Land Sales, prior to the effective date of this chapter, or such unrecorded map, plat, drawing or survey was certified by a land surveyor duly licensed by the State of Florida, or was an official part of the records of the Palm Beach County Tax Assessor's Office prior to the effective date of this chapter. 
(e)  The financing or leasing of apartments, offices, stores or similar space within an apartment building, industrial building, commercial building or office building. 
(f)  The division of real estate property is for the conveyance of land to a federal, state, county or municipal governmental agency, entity, political subdivision or a public utility, as defined herein. 
(g)  The subdivision, partition and/or recombination of real property located within a commercial, industrial, or mixed-use planned development which has an approved boundary plat, site plan, and declaration of covenants provided that: 
(1)  The planned development is delineated on a single boundary plat of record depicting all existing drainage and utility easements of record and all required limited access easements, water management tracts, and common area tracts, and including appropriate dedications or reservations for same; 
(2)  Any site plan or site plan amendment necessary to facilitate the subdivision, partition and/or recombination of the subject property has been reviewed by the plan review committee and approved by the town council, which shall become the final approved subdivision plan and site plan for the planned development; and 
(3)  All lands within the boundary plat of the planned development are subject to a common recorded unity of control or other such maintenance and use covenants for access, parking, stormwater management, and other required common areas or facilities, as approved by the town attorney. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87; Ord. No. O-5-90, § 1, 5-29-90; Ord. No. O-11-16, § 2, 10-10-16) 
Sec. 17.5-7. - Platting exception determination. 
    The developer shall submit a pre-application in the manner prescribed by this chapter. The town council shall review the pre-application and shall determine if in fact one (1) of the above conditions does exist and, upon such determination, shall delete the requirement for platting. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-8. - Requirements in lieu of platting. 
    If, pursuant to section 17.5-7 of this article, platting is not necessary, in lieu of platting, a certified survey shall be submitted to the town clerk. The town council shall reserve the right to require deeded rights-of-way and easements, reservations or improvements required in connection with platting under this chapter, including the posting of a performance and maintenance bond, as may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 17.5-9. - Responsibility for coordination and enforcement. 
    For the purpose of coordination, enforcement and administration, the town manager shall be deemed the administrative officer of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-10. - Plan review committee-Responsible for administration. 
    The plan review committee of the town shall serve as the body responsible for administration of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-11. - Same-Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the plan review committee to: 
(a)  Review subdivision preapplications for compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Review subdivision master plans for compliance with this chapter. 
(c)  Review applications for variance from the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-12. - Same-Meetings. 
    The plan review committee shall meet as needed to review preapplications and/or master plans or variance. The plan review committee meetings shall be open to the public and/or any person, subdivider or owner interested in a preapplication or master plan may attend any such meeting and present any appropriate matter thereat. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-13. - Information, recommendations and procedures. 
    Information, advice or recommendations concerning the preapplication and master plan, other than procedural, shall not be given by individual members of the plan review committee; but shall be rendered by the entire plan review committee only at regular meetings. Procedural information shall be rendered by the town manager or his duly authorized representative. Upon receiving the approval as prescribed in the "Procedures" section for the preapplication and master plan from the town council, the developer's engineer and surveyor shall coordinate the preparation of the construction plans and preliminary plat with the town manager or his representative. Upon approval of the commencement of work, the developer's engineer shall coordinate the construction of the required improvements directly with the town manager or his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
ARTICLE V. - PROCEDURES 

Sec. 17.5-14. - Zoning. 
    Prior to consideration of any proposed subdivision under the terms of this chapter, the area to be subdivided must have the appropriate zoning required for the intended use. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-15. - Preapplication. 
    The purpose of the preapplication is to allow the developer and the plan review committee the opportunity to consult informally prior to the preparation of the master plan and formal application. The preapplication is optional, but is recommended if the project is complex or if there is some question as to the potential problems of development. A written preapplication may be submitted to the town manager for placement on the agenda of the plan review committee. The preapplication shall contain: 
(a)  Ten (1) copies of a written statement generally describing the condition of the site and the proposed development of the entire subdivision. This statement shall include, but is not necessarily limited to, data on existing covenants, location of utility facilities, general soil characteristics and information describing the subdivision proposal such as number of units, typical lot, public areas, anticipated utility sources and any other information considered pertinent. 
(b)  Ten (10) copies of a sketc.h plan including the following on a twenty-four-inch by thirty-six-inch sheet; a vicinity sketc.h showing the location of the land to be subdivided; approximate acreage; natural features such as low or swampy areas, streams, lakes or canals; identification of adjacent lands; a brief description of the land to be subdivided, name, telephone number and address of the developer; date; northpoint; streets; general lot and block layout; layout of all adjoining streets; zoning classification of the tract and adjacent properties; location of existing improvements and any other significant features. 
(c)  A nonrefundable fee, the amount of which shall be set by the town council by resolution and amended from time to time as necessary, is required with the preapplication, to help defray the cost of processing the preapplication. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the statement, plan and fee, the town manager shall disperse copies to the members of the plan review committee and advise the developer of the time and place of the plan review committee meeting. After consultation with the plan review committee, the developer may proceed with the preparation and formal application for approval of the master plan as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-16. - Master plan. 
(a)  The developer shall retain the services of an engineer or surveyor registered in Florida to prepare the master plan of the subdivision and may employ a land planner, landscape architect, architect or other technical or professional services to assist in the development of the site plan. The master plan shall be coordinated with the major utility suppliers involved with providing services. 
(b)  A master plan of the proposed subdivision must be submitted to the town manager. 
(c)  The master plan, when submitted to the town manager, shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name of subdivision or identifying title which shall not duplicate or closely approximate the name of any other subdivision in the incorporated or unincorporated area of Palm Beach County. 
(2)  A vicinity sketc.h showing the location of the tract in reference to other areas of the town. 
(3)  North arrow, scale and date. 
(4)  Name, address and telephone number of the developer, along with the name and address of the engineer and surveyor responsible for the plan, plat and supporting data. 
(5)  The location and names of adjacent subdivisions, if any, and plat book and page reference. 
(6)  The tract boundary with bearings and distances along with a written description. 
(7)  Topographical conditions on the tract including all the existing watercourses, drainage ditches and bodies of water, marshes and other significant features. 
(8)  All existing streets and alleys on or adjacent to the tract including name, right-of-way width, street or pavement width and established centerline elevation. Existing streets shall be dimensioned to the tract boundary. 
(9)  All existing property lines, easements and rights of way, their purpose and their effect on the property to be subdivided. 
(10)  The location and right-of-way widths of all proposed streets, alleys, rights-of-way, easements and their purpose along with the layout of the lots and blocks. 
(11)  Access points to collector and arterial streets showing their compliance to the access requirements established by this chapter. 
(12)  Ground elevations by contour line at intervals of not more than one (1) foot based on National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) data. 
(13)  All existing drainage district facilities and their ultimate right-of-way requirements as they affect the property to be subdivided. 
(14)  Generalized statement of subsurface conditions on the property, location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil conditions and groundwater depth. 
(15)  Zoning classification of the tract. 
(16)  Utilities such as telephone, power, water, sewer, gas, etc., on or adjacent to the tract including existing or proposed water treatment plants and sewerage treatment plants. The master plan shall contain a statement that all utilities are available and have been coordinated with all required utilities. 
(17)  Sites proposed for parks, recreational areas and schools. The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the proposed master plan to the Palm Beach County School Board. 
(18)  Municipal impact statement for all developments over one (1) acre in size. 
(d)  A subdivision that generates three thousand (3,000) vehicle single directional trips per day or two hundred fifty-vehicle single-directional trips in a one-hour period must submit, along with the master plan, a traffic impact analysis. The traffic impact analysis shall be prepared by a professional engineer and shall be used to determine the number of lanes and capacity of the street system proposed or affected by the development, based on ultimate permitted development. 
(e)  A master stormwater management and drainage plan outlining the primary and secondary drainage facilities needed for the proper development of the subdivision, excluding tertiary facilities which are required on construction plans, shall be submitted along with the master plan. The master drainage plan shall consist of a plan and report indicating the method of drainage, existing water elevations, recurring high water elevations, the proposed design water elevations, drainage structures, canals and ditches and any other pertinent information pertaining to the control of storm and ground water. In cases where modifications or improvements are not planned for primary and secondary drainage facilities, this requirement may be accomplished by so indicating on the master plan. 
(f)  Upon filing the master plan with the town manager, the developer shall pay a fee to be set by the town council by resolution and amended from time to time as necessary. The fee is not reimbursable but is to help defray the cost of administrating and processing the master plan. If more than one (1) resubmittal of corrected or revised master plan is required by the town council, an additional fee in the same amount of the original fee shall be charged for each resubmittal. 
(g)  Upon receipt of the master plan and required data, the town manager shall disperse copies to the members of the plan review committee and advise the developer of the time and place of the plan review committee meeting(s). 
(h)  The plan review committee shall hold meetings as needed and shall review the master plan and required data with the developer. During consultation with the developer, the plan review committee shall inform the developer that the plan and data as submitted do or do not meet the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  When the plan review committee finds that the master plan and required data do not meet the provisions of this chapter, it shall advise the developer at the time of the meeting what corrections or revisions are necessary to meet the provisions of this chapter and shall, within seven (7) days, express the reasons in writing to the developer. Upon such findings, the developer shall make the corrections or revisions and resubmit the master plan and required data to the town manager for dispersement to the members of the plan review committee. The plan review committee shall reschedule the matter for review. 
(2)  When the plan review committee finds that the master plan and required data meet the provisions of this chapter, the plan review committee shall refer the master plan to the town council for consideration. If approved by the town council, authorization shall be given to sign the master plan indicating town council approval and the developer may proceed with the preparation of the construction plans and preliminary plat as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87; Ord. No. O-5-90, § 2, 5-29-90) 
Sec. 17.5-17. - Construction plans and preliminary plat. 
(a)  Upon approval of the master plan by the town council, the developer shall have prepared and shall submit to the town manager, within six (6) months, construction plans and the preliminary plat. Failure to submit the construction plans and the preliminary plat within six (6) months shall require resubmittal of the master plan under section 17.5-16. The subdivision of a large tract may be developed in two (2) or more increments and the developer may submit construction plans and preliminary plat for approval to develop the subdivision in increments. The construction and preliminary plat shall coincide with the master plan as approved by the town council, and major deviations must be approved by both the plan review committee and town council. Minor deviations may be approved by the town manager. 
(b)  After approval of the master plan, the construction plans and preliminary plat shall be submitted to the town manager along with a nonreimbursable fee, the amount of which shall be set by the town council by resolution and amended from time to time as necessary, to help defray the cost of processing the plans and plat. The applicant shall see that copies of the construction plans and preliminary plat are forwarded to any agency which is or may be affected by the subdivision for review and comment. The town engineer shall review the construction plans and preliminary plat as to their conformity with this chapter and, within thirty (30) days from the date of the submittal, shall inform the developer's engineer that the plans and/or plat do or do not meet the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-18. - Construction plans. 
(a)  Three (3) sets of construction plans shall be submitted to the town manager for all the improvements required by this chapter. The plans shall be under separate cover for each of the following when required: 
(1)  Paving, grading and drainage. 
(2)  Bridges. 
(3)  Water and sewerage systems and all other utilities. 
(4)  Street lighting, landscaping within public rights-of-way, parks, recreational areas and parking areas. Plans for street lights shall bear the approval of the requisite utility authorities involved. 
(b)  The plans shall be so complete that from them a complete review and analysis can be made without research of any outside data. The plans shall consist of and contain, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  A cover sheet, including a vicinity sketc.h. 
(2)  Plan showing complete details including water, sewer and storm drainage systems. 
(3)  A drainage map showing the complete drainage system including, but not limited to, closed drainage areas, design high water, recurring high water, acreage, the effect to and compatibility of drainage of surface waters and the complete calculations used to design the system. 
(4)  Typical sections and summary of quantities. 
(5)  Construction details. 
(6)  Special profile sheets, if necessary, showing special or unique situations. 
(7)  Bench mark, based on NGVD data. 
(8)  Soil analysis, showing the locations and results of test borings of the subsurface condition of the tract to be developed. 
(9)  The plans shall contain the special conditions and specifications pertaining to the subdivision in note form on the plans, such as: 
a.  Required compliance to this chapter. 
b.  Where applicable, required compliance with state standards as currently adopted and in use. 
c.  Minimum standards for materials. 
d.  Test requirements for stabilization, base and backfill. 
e.  Source of water and sewer service. 
f.  Required installation of subsurface construction such as water lines, sewer lines, public utilities and storm drainage prior to compaction of subgrade and roadway construction. 
(c)  Plans shall be prepared, certified and sealed by the developer's engineer. One (1) set of plans for paving and drainage; bridges; water systems; sewerage systems; and street lighting (bearing the approval of the requisite power authority), landscape, parks, recreational areas and parking areas shall be submitted to the town engineer by the town manager for review and approval. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-19. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  Two (2) prints of the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the town manager along with the construction plans. 
(b)  The preliminary plat shall coincide with the master plan as approved by the town council. When the subdivision of a large tract is to be developed in two (2) or more increments, the preliminary plat shall coincide with the increment to be developed. 
(c)  When a large tract is developed into two (2) or more increments, and the incremental development does not provide for the continuous development or does not totally encompass drainage outfalls shown on the master plan, a description for a separate instrument providing a drainage easement or right-of-way must be submitted with the preliminary plat. Upon submittal of the final plat, the drainage easement or right-of-way instrument shall be submitted, fully executed, in sufficient form for recording. 
(d)  The preliminary plat shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  The plat shall be prepared on sheets having overall dimensions of twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches, reserving three (3) inches on the left margin and a half-inch margin on all remaining sides. A three-inch by five-inch space shall be provided in the upper righthand corner to be used by the clerk of the circuit board for recording information. 
(2)  The plat is to be drawn from an accurate survey at a scale of not smaller than one hundred (100) feet to the inch, or as otherwise determined by the town manager or his authorized representative. 
(3)  If more than two (2) sheets are required, the plat shall contain an index sheet as page 1, showing the entire subdivision on one (1) sheet indexing the area shown on each succeeding sheet. 
(4)  The plat shall have a vicinity sketc.h, showing the subdivision's location in reference to other areas of the town. 
(5)  There shall be lettered or printed upon the plat a full and detailed description of the land embraced in the plat. The description shall show the section, township and range in which such lands are situated, if not platted or not in a land grant, or portions thereof, and must be so complete that from it, without a reference to the map, the starting point can be determined and the boundaries run. 
(6)  The plat shall contain the name of the subdivision, surveyor and streets. The plat shall show the scale and data, north arrow with north being at the top or right side of the map or within that ninety-degree quadrant of the map when practical; boundary line of the proposed subdivision, lot lines, parcels of land to be dedicated to the public, easements, street right-of-way lines and other property lines drawn to scale with tentative dimensions. 
(7)  The preliminary plat shall show the proposed location of permanent reference monuments as required by Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended. 
(8)  The preliminary plat shall show all municipal, county, township, range and section lines occurring within the subdivision accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and bearing. Where such lines do not occur within the subdivision, bearings and distances shall be provided to the nearest established section or quarter section corner and shall be accurately described on the plat. 
(9)  The preliminary plat shall show the name or number and right-of-way width of each street or right-of-way shown on the plat and the location, dimension and purpose of any easements. Proposed streets, which are obviously in alignment with others existing and named, shall bear the assigned name of the existing streets. In no case, except as indicated in the preceding sentence, shall the name of the proposed street, excluding a numerical system, duplicate or be phonetically similar to existing street names irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, boulevard, drive, place, court, etc. 
(10)  The preliminary plat shall show the numbering or lettering of all lots and blocks. All lots shall be numbered or lettered individually throughout the subdivision or progressively numbered or lettered in each block. Blocks in each incremental plat shall be numbered or lettered consecutively throughout a subdivision. 
(11)  Excepted parcels not included in the plat must be marked "not part of the plat." Not included parcels shall not be surrounded by the subdivision without adequate access. 
(12)  The preliminary plat shall identify all adjacent property as to whether it is unplatted or if subdivided, the name of the subdivision with plat book and page numbers. 
(e)  The preliminary plat shall contain on the face or first page of the plat the form and signature space for the following certifications and approvals, [2] acknowledged as required by law, all being in the form set forth in the appendix to this chapter, but need not be executed until the plat is submitted in final form: 
Appendix 1  Dedication by owner 
Appendix 2.  Title certification 
Appendix 3.  Surveyor's certification 
Appendix 4.  Mortgagee's consent (when applicable) 
Appendix 5.  Approval of the plan review committee 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The appendices are included in Art. XII of this chapter. 

Sec. 17.5-20. - Approval of construction plans and preliminary plat. 
(a)  When the town engineer finds that the construction plans and/or preliminary plat do not meet the provisions of this chapter, he shall notify the town manager and the town manager shall advise the developer's engineer in writing and reference shall be made to the specific section with which the plans and/or plat do not comply. 
(b)  When the town engineer finds that the construction plans and preliminary plat meet the provisions of this chapter, he shall notify the town manager who, in turn, shall advise the developer's engineer and furnish a written statement of conditional approval. Upon receipt of conditional approval, the developer's engineer shall submit four (4) sets of the construction plans at the time of submission of the final plat. 
(c)  Conditional approval of the construction plans and preliminary plat shall not constitute acceptance of the final plat, rather it shall be deemed an expression of acceptance of the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. 
(d)  Conditional approval of the construction plans and preliminary plat shall not be construed as authority for filing the plat with the clerk of the circuit court of Palm Beach County, nor as authority for the sale of lots in reference thereto. 
(e)  Prior to completing the requirements of the final plat sections of this article, building permits shall not be issued for any structure other than temporary construction trailers and models on a lot wherein the final plat has not been recorded in the manner prescribed unless the recording of the plat is not required by Article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-21. - Final plat. 
    As the final step in the review procedure to obtain approval for a subdivision in the town, the developer shall have prepared and shall submit a final plat. Submission and approval of a final plat shall be required prior to construction of the improvements required under this chapter. No such improvements, including streets, drainage and the like shall be accepted and maintained by the town, unless and until the final plat has been approved by the town council and duly recorded by the clerk of the circuit court of Palm Beach County. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-22. - Fee. 
    Upon filing application for final plat approval, the developer shall pay a fee the amount of which shall be set by the town council by resolution and amended from time to time as necessary to help defray the cost of processing the final plat and administration of the construction of the subdivision. The estimated cost of construction shall be prepared by the developers engineer and submitted to the town manager who may refer the estimate to the town engineer for review and comment. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-23. - Reapplication. 
    Within six (6) months from the date of the written conditional approval of the construction plans and preliminary plat, the final plat shall be prepared and submitted to the town manager. Failure to submit the final plat within six (6) months shall require reapplication under sections and of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-24. - Phasing. 
    The final plat shall conform to the approval preliminary plat and shall constitute only that portion of the approved master plan which the developer proposes to develop within twelve (12) months. The improvements required by this chapter which apply to the final plat shall be completed within twelve (12) months from the date of recording of the plat or, if construction of improvements is undertaken prior to recording the plat, within twelve (12) months from the date of approval of the final plat. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-25. - Size and content of final plat. 
    The final plat shall be drawn or printed on twenty-four-inch by thirty-six-inch chronoflex, mylar or other approved material. The final plat shall be prepared by a land surveyor currently registered in the State of Florida and is to be clearly and legible drawn with black permanent drawing ink or veritype process to a scale of not smaller than one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet, or as otherwise determined by the town engineer. The final plat shall be prepared in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended, and shall conform to the following requirements: 
(a)  Name of subdivision. The plat shall have a title or name acceptable to the town. When the plat is a new subdivision, the name of the subdivision shall not duplicate or by phonetically similar to the name of any existing subdivision. When the plat is an addition to a recorded subdivision, it shall carry the same name as the existing subdivision. 
(b)  Title. The plat shall have a title in bold legible letters containing the name of the subdivision; the name of the town, county and state; the section, township and range, as applicable, or, if in a land grant, so stated; and if the plat is a replat, amendment or addition to an existing subdivision, it shall include the words "section, unit, replat, amendment, etc." 
(c)  Description. There shall be lettered or printed upon the plat a full and detailed description of the land embraced in the plat. The description shall show the section, township and range in which the lands are situated or, if a land grant, so stated, and must be so complete that from it, without reference to the map, the starting point can be determined and the boundaries run. 
(d)  Index. If more than one (1) sheet is required for the map, the plat shall contain an index sheet on page 1, showing the entire subdivision on the sheet indexing the area shown on each succeeding sheet and each sheet shall contain an index delineating that portion of the subdivision shown on that sheet in relation to the entire subdivision. When more than one (1) sheet must be used to accurately portray the lands subdivided, each sheet must show the particular number of that sheet and the total number of sheets included, as well as clearly labeled match lines to each sheet. 
(e)  Survey data. The final plat shall show the length of all arcs together with central angles, radii and points of curvature. Sufficient survey data shall be shown to positively describe the boundary of each lot, block, right-of-way, easement and all other areas shown on the plat and all areas shall be within the boundary of the plat as shown in the description. The survey data contained on the plat shall also include: 
(1)  The scale, both stated and graphically illustrated, on each sheet. 
(2)  A north arrow shall be drawn on each sheet and the bearing or azimuth reference shall be clearly stated on the face or first page of the plat in the notes or title. The north direction shall be at the top or right side of the map or within the ninety-degree quadrant, when practical. 
(3)  The point of beginning shall be boldly shown together with the letters "P.O.B." in bold letters. 
(4)  All intersecting street right-of-way lines shall be joined by the long chord of a minimum radius of twenty-five (25) feet and all dimensions shall be shown. 
(5)  All adjoining property shall be identified by a subdivision title, plat book and page or if unplatted, the land shall be so designated. 
(6)  Permanent reference monuments shall be shown in the manner prescribed by Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended, and shall be installed prior to submission of the final plat. 
(7)  There shall be reserved on each sheet of the plat a three-inch by five-inch space in the upper righthand corner to be used by the clerk of the circuit court for recording information and each sheet shall reserve three (3) inches on the left margin and a half-inch margin on all remaining sides. 
(8)  The map shall mathematically close within one-hundredth (0.01) of a foot and shall be accurately tied to all town, township, range and section lines occurring within the subdivision by distance and bearing. 
(9)  The cover sheet or first page of the plat shall show a vicinity sketc.h, showing the subdivision's location in reference to other areas of the town. 
(f)  Lot and block identification. Each lot and block shall be numbered or lettered. All lots shall be numbered or lettered by progressive numbers or letters individually throughout the subdivision or progressively numbered or lettered in each block. Blocks in each incremental plat shall be numbered or lettered consecutively throughout a subdivision. 
(g)  Street names. The plat shall contain the name of each street shown on the plat. Proposed streets which are in alignment with other existing and named streets shall bear the same name of the existing street. In no case, except as indicated in the preceding sentence, shall the name of the proposed street, excluding a numerical system, duplicate or be phonetically similar to existing street names, regardless of the use of the suffix street, avenue, boulevard, drive, place, court, etc. 
(h)  Not included parcels. Not included or excepted parcels must be marked "not part of this plat." No strip or parcel of land shall be reserved by the owner unless the same is sufficient in size and area to be of some particular use or service. The intended use of all reserved areas shall be shown on the plat in note form on the cover sheet. 
(i)  Rights-of-way and easements. All right-of-way and easement widths and dimensions shall be shown on the plat. The plat shall contain a statement that no building or any kind of construction or trees or shrubs shall be placed on easements. 
(j)  Restrictions, reservations and restrictive covenants. Restrictions pertaining to the type and use of water supply; type and use of sanitary facilities; use and benefits of water areas, canals and other open spaces; odd-shaped and substandard parcels; restrictions controlling building lines; establishment and maintenance of buffer strips and walls; and restrictions of similar nature shall require the establishment of restrictive covenants and such covenants shall be noted on the plat. Documents pertaining to restrictive covenants shall be submitted with the final plat. 
(k)  Private streets and related facilities. All streets and their related facilities designed to serve more than one (1) property owner shall be dedicated to the public use, however, private streets shall be permitted within property under single ownership, a property owner's association or a condominium or cooperative association, as defined by Florida law. Where private streets are permitted, ownership and maintenance association documents shall be submitted with the final plat and the dedication contained on the plat shall clearly dedicate the roads and maintenance responsibility to the association without recourse to the town or any other public agency. The rights-of-way and related facilities shall be identified as tracts for road purposes under specific ownership. 
(l)  Certifications and approvals. The plat shall contain on the face or first page the following certifications and approvals, acknowledged as required by law, all being in the form set forth in the appendices to this chapter: 
(1)  Dedications. The purpose of all reserved areas shown on the plat shall be defined in the dedication on the plat. All areas reserved for use by the residents of the subdivision shall be so dedicated and all areas reserved for public use, such as parks, rights-of-way for roads, streets or alleys, however the same may be designated; easements for utilities, rights-of-way and easements for drainage purposes and any other area, however designated, shall be dedicated by the owner of the land at the time the plat is recorded. 
(2)  Mortgagee's consent and approval. All mortgages along with the mortgagee's consent and approval of the dedication shall be required on all plats where mortgages encumber the land to be platted. 
    The signature(s) of the mortgagee or mortgagees, as the case may be, must be witnessed and the execution must be acknowledged in the same manner as mortgages are required to be witnessed and acknowledged. In case the mortgagee is a corporation, the consent and approval shall be signed in behalf of the corporation by the president or a vice president and the secretary or an assistance secretary, respectively, by and with the authority of the board of directors. 
(3)  Certification of surveyor. The plat shall contain the signature, registration number and official seal of the land surveyor, certifying that the plat is a true and correct representative of the land surveyed under his responsible direction and supervision and that the survey data compiled and shown on the plat complies with all of the requirements of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended, and this chapter. The certification shall also state that permanent reference monuments, "PRM, " have been set in compliance with Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended, and this chapter, and the PCPs (permanent control points) will be set under the direction and supervision of the surveyor within one (1) year from the date the plat is recorded. When required improvements have been completed prior to the recording of a plat, the certification shall state that PCP's have been set in compliance with the laws of the state and ordinances of the town. When plats are recorded and improvements are to be accomplished under surety posted as provided for by this chapter, the required improvements and surety shall include PCP'S. 
(4)  Town council. The plat shall contain the approval and signature block for the town council and the acknowledgment and signature block of the town manager. Upon adoption of a resolution approving the plat, the mayor shall execute the plat and the plat shall be presented to the clerk of the circuit court for recording. 
(5)  Town engineer. The plat shall contain the approval and signature block of the town engineer. 
(6)  Certification of title. A title certification shall be contained on the face or first page of the plat. The title certification shall state: 
a.  That the lands as described and shown on the plat are in the name, and apparent record title is held by the person, persons or organization executing the dedication. 
b.  That all taxes have been paid on said lands as required by Chapter 197.051, Florida Statutes, as amended. 
c.  All mortgages on the land and indicate their official record book and page number. The title certification must be an option of an attorney at law licensed in Florida or a title insurance company licensed in Florida. 
(7)  Instrument prepared by. The name and address of the natural person who prepared the plat shall be contained on each page of the plat, as required by Chapter 695.24, Florida Statutes, as amended. The name and address shall be in statement form consisting of the words: 
"This instrument was prepared by _____ (name) 
_____ (address) 
(m)  Mobile home park subdivisions. Areas to be subdivided for the purpose of a mobile home subdivision shall be in the proper zone for such development and prior to the submittal of the final plat and supporting data, shall have the approval of the town council and shall meet all of the requirements of the zoning code. The dedication on the plat of a mobile home subdivision shall include the following additional provisions or wording equal thereto: "Said owner(s) hereby dedicate(s) the lots shown on the plat exclusively for mobile home or trailer parking and use incidental thereto, except as to the lots indicated for other purposes on the plat, and mobile home or trailer parking is prohibited elsewhere than on the indicated lots. Areas indicated as parks or playgrounds are dedicated for the use of the owners of the lots shown on this plat." 
    Mobile home subdivision plats shall conform to all the requirements of this chapter, the requirements of the zoning code and shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended. 
(n)  Existing or recorded streets. The plat shall show the name, location and width of all existing or recorded streets intersecting or contiguous to the boundary of the plat, accurately tied to the boundary of the plat by bearings and distances. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-26. - Surety. 
    In addition to the foregoing requirements and items to be shown on the face of the plat, the final plat, when submitted, shall be accompanied by a statement of the developer indicating whether the required improvements are to be constructed prior to the recording of the plat or after recording under guarantees posted with the town as provided for in this chapter. 
(a)  When the required improvements (see article VI) are to be completed prior to the recording of the plat, it shall be expressly understood that no building permits shall be issued for any structure other than temporary construction trailers or models on a lot wherein the final plat has not been approved and recorded in a manner prescribed in this chapter. The approval to construct required improvements shall not be construed as authority for the sale of lots in reference thereto. 
(b)  When the required improvements are to be completed after recording under guarantees as provided in this chapter, the final plat, upon submittal, shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  A certified cost estimate prepared by the developer's engineer which shall include the cost of all required improvements or the contract bid price for all work required to complete the required improvements (Appendix 7). 
(2)  A contract agreement between the town and the developer for the construction of the required improvements, in triplicate, in the form set forth in Appendix 7 to this chapter. 
(3)  A guarantee in the amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the sum of engineering and construction costs based on the developer's engineer's estimate or contract bid prices. The guarantee shall be in one (1) of the following forms: 
a.  Cash deposit. 
b.  Personal bond with letter of credit. 
c.  Surety bond (having a Best's rating of AAA). 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-27. - Submission of final plat. 
(a)  Upon completion of the foregoing requirements, the original drawing of the final plat and required supplementary material shall be presented to the town manager. 
(b)  The town engineer shall examine the final plat as to its compliance with the Constitution and Statutes of the State of Florida and the ordinances of the Town of Lantana and shall, in writing, within thirty (30) days, report his findings, recommendations, or approval to the town manager and the developer. Such action shall be specified in writing and a reference shall be made to the specific article or section with which the final plat does not comply. If deficiencies exist, they shall be corrected by the developer upon written notice. If the final plat meets the provision of this chapter, complies with the Constitution and statutes of this state and the ordinances of the town, the town manager shall approve the final plat. 
(c)  After approval has been given by the town manager as provided in this article, the developer shall submit four (4) sets of the construction plans containing all applicable approvals of requisite governmental agencies affected by the proposed subdivision, along with copies of all required permits. The town manager, upon receipt of the plans, shall inform the developer or his agent, as the case may be, that the plat has been given final approval and is ready to be presented to the town council for approval. 
(1)  In the event the developer exercises the right to construct and complete required improvements prior to recording of the final plat, the original plat shall be returned to the developer pending satisfactory completion of the required improvements and shall be resubmitted to the town manager after certification that the developer has complied with the requirements of this chapter. Upon resubmittal of the original drawing, the certification of title and certification and approvals contained on the plat shall be current and the plat shall be rechecked, as required by this article, prior to presentation to the town council for approval. 
(2)  In the event the developer elects to record the plat prior to completion of the required improvements under guarantees as provided for in this chapter, the final plat shall be presented to the town council by the town manager with a written report and, upon approval of the town council, shall be recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court of Palm Beach County. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-28. - Recording requirements. 
    The final plats for subdivisions within the town shall not be recorded until the developer has installed the required improvements or has guaranteed to the satisfaction of the town that such improvements will be installed. 
(a)  Completion of required improvements prior to final plat recording. In the event the developer exercises the right to construct and complete required improvements prior to recording of the final plat, the town shall have the right to enter upon the property to be platted for the purpose of reviewing the construction of the required improvements during the progress of such construction. The developer shall coordinate the construction with the town engineer. When the required improvements are complete, the final plat along with the records and data as herein prescribed shall be submitted by the developer to the town manager as provided for in this article. When all requirements of this chapter have been complied with, the plat and a report shall be presented to the town council by the town manager not later than thirty (30) days after receipt of the completion for their review and approval. Upon such approval, the plat shall be delivered to the clerk of the circuit court of Palm Beach County for recording. 
(b)  Completion of required improvements after plat recordation. When the developer desires to record the plat in lieu of prior construction of required improvements, the developer shall file with the town documents guaranteeing that such improvements will be installed. All guarantees shall be incorporated in a bonded agreement for the construction of the required improvements in the form prescribed in the Appendix 7 to this chapter. All agreements, guarantees and documents are subject to the approval of the town attorney. The guarantee shall be in one (1) of the following forms: 
(1)  Cash deposit. The developer shall deposit with the town or place in an account subject to the control of the town, cash in the full amount of one hundred ten (110)percent of engineering and construction costs for the installation and completion of the required improvements. The developer shall be entitled to secure draws from such deposits or accounts as installations progress at stages of construction but not more frequently than monthly. A draw from such cash deposit or account shall be made only when the cost of required improvements installed equal or exceed the amount of the draw requested, plus any previous draws made, and the town manager has reviewed the required improvements and authorized the draw. The town manager shall have the right to reduce the amount of any required draw to an amount justified, based on his review of the required improvements. The town manager shall also have the right to refuse to approve any requested draw, so long as the developer fails to be in compliance with any of the terms and conditions of the plat or plans and specifications for the required improvements. The developer shall be entitled to receive all interest earned on such deposit or account. The town, after sixty (60) days' written notice to the developer, shall have the right to use such cash deposit or account to secure satisfactory completion of the required improvements in the event of default by the developer or failure of the developer to complete such improvements within the time required by this chapter; 
(2)  Personal bond with letter of credit. The developer may furnish to the town his personal bond secured by an unconditional and irrevocable letter of credit, in an amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the total engineering and construction costs, for the installation and completion of the required improvements. The letter of credit shall be issued by a state or [a] United States banking institution to the town. Such letter of credit shall be in the form set forth in Appendix 10 to this chapter. During the process of construction, the town manager shall reduce, semi-annually, the dollar amount of the bond on the basis of work completed, provided, however, sufficient funds shall remain to complete the required improvements. The town, after sixty (60) days' written notice to the developer, shall have the right to use any funds resulting from drafts on the letter of credit to secure satisfactory completion of the required improvements in the event of default by the developer or failure of the developer to complete such improvements within the time required by this chapter; or 
(3)  Surety bond. The developer may furnish to the town a surety bond obtained from a company having a Best's rating of AAA, guaranteeing that within the time required by this chapter, all work required will be completed in full accordance with the plat and all conditions attached thereto, copies of which shall be attached to and constitute a part of the bonded agreement. Said bond shall be in the amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the sum of engineering and construction cost. During the process of construction, the town manager shall reduce, semi-annually, the dollar amount of the bond on the basis of work completed. The town, after sixty (60) days' written notice to the developer, shall call on the bond to insure satisfactory completion of the required improvements in the event of default by the developer or failure of the developer to complete such improvements within the time required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
ARTICLE VI. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 17.5-28.1. - Generally. 
    The following tangible improvements are required in conjunction with the development of a subdivision within the town. The required improvements shall be completed prior to recordation of the plat in the manner prescribed in this chapter or the developer shall file with the town a guarantee in one (1) of the forms prescribed by this chapter to assure the installation of the required improvements. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-29. - Alleys. 
    Alleys are required along rear lot lines of commercial and industrial subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-30. - Bridges and culverts. 
    Where a subdivision is traversed by or develops canals, watercourses, lakes, streams, waterways or channels, bridges or culverts shall be provided as necessary to facilitate the proposed street system. The requirements for bridges and/or culverts are subject to the agency having jurisdiction over above-enumerated facilities or as required by the proposed street layout of the development in conjunction with a proposed waterway. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-31. - Buffer areas (screening). 
    Subdivisions shall be buffered for the protection of residential properties with a four-and one-halfto six-foot high masonry wall or landscaped chain link fence, or some other equivalent buffer which shall also be at least four-and-one-half (4 1/2) to six (6) feet in height when necessary to separate residential developments from commercial and industrial developments, except where such developments are separated by a golf course or other equivalent barriers. Residential developments shall be buffered and protected from adjacent expressways, arterials, collectors and railroad rights-of-way with a five-foot limited access strip, which shall be shown and designated on the plat, except where access is provided by means of a marginal access road or where such expressway, arterial, collector or railroad right-of-way abuts a golf course. In the alternative, a four-and-one-halfto six-foot high decorative masonry wall or landscaped chain link fence or some other equivalent buffer which shall also be at least four-and-one-half (4 1/2) to six (6) feet high, may be provided in a limited access strip up to five (5) feet wide. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-32. - Clearing, grading and filling. 
    The subdivision shall be graded and, where necessary, filled to comply with the drainage design prescribed in the design requirements article of this chapter. Developers shall be required to clear all rights-of-way and to make all grades for streets, alleys, lots and other areas compatible for drainage as prescribed in the drainage design. The type of fill within the rights-of-way shall be satisfactory to and meet with the approval of the town engineer, who shall require soil tests of the backfill and the underlying material at the cost of the developer to certify the type of material and method of placement. In the interest of the preservation of existing trees and other natural beauty, the town manager may vary the requirements of this section where aesthetic and environmental conditions will be enhanced but will not affect proper drainage of the area. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-33. - Drainage. 
    An adequate drainage system, including necessary open ditches, storm sewers, drain inlets, manholes, headwalls, endwalls, culverts, bridges and other appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions for the positive drainage of storm and groundwater. The drainage system shall provide for surface waters affecting the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-34. - Fire hydrants. 
    Fire hydrants shall be provided in all residential, commercial and industrial subdivisions. Fire hydrants shall be provided in the manner prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-35. - Monuments. 
    Monuments shall be set as prescribed by Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-36. - Parks and recreational areas. 
    In a proposed subdivision, consideration shall be given to the adequate provision of recreation areas to accommodate the needs of the residents of the subdivision. The recreation areas shall be dedicated to the public and be adjacent to a public right-of-way, or shall be dedicated to a property owners' association and have convenient access for the residents of the subdivision, or shall be reserved for the use of the residents of a subdivision when the subdivision is developed as a condominium or cooperative development, as defined by Florida law. Such dedication or reservation shall be in one (1) of the following forms: 
(a)  An acreage amount based on a ratio of five (5) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) people population, based on two and six-tenths (2.6) people per unit. 
(b)  The equivalent of five (5) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) people population, based on two and six-tenths (2.6) people per unit, in dollar value of recreational facilities of a type suitable for general use of the residents of the subdivision. The value of such land shall be determined by either the purchase price paid by the developer or the Palm Beach County Tax Assessor's appraised value of the property, whichever is higher; and the value of the recreational facilities shall be determined by an estimate of the construction cost of such facilities, prepared by the developer's engineer or an architect, registered in the state, both to be provided by the developer at the time the master plan is submitted. The estimate requirements contained in this paragraph may be waived if adequate surety is provided by the developer equaling the dollar value of the land required of this section. 
(c)  Any combination of (a) and (b) above, which equals the dollar value of the land requirement and adequately provides for recreational facilities properly interspersed and conveniently located for the use of the residents of the subdivision. 
(d)  The developer may, at the option of the town, in lieu of (a), (b) or (c) above, contribute the dollar value of the acreage requirement of this section, for the whole or incremental plat of the subdivision, to the town, at the time the plat is submitted for recording. Such funds are to be held in a nonlapsing park and recreation fund for the acquisition and improvement of recreation sites for the use of the residents of the subdivision. 
    Where golf courses and golf-related supporting facilities are provided in conjunction with the subdivision, credit of one-half (1/2) of the acreage requirement for recreation areas may be applied where use of the golf course(s) and supporting facilities are available to the residents of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-37. - Permanent control points (PCP's). 
    Permanent control points, (PCP's) shall be provided in accordance with Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended. Where required improvements are constructed prior to the recordation of the plat, the permanent control points (PCP's) shall be set prior to submission of the final plat and certified buy the surveyor on the plat. Where required improvements are constructed after recordation, the guarantee for such improvements shall incorporate placement of permanent control points (PCP's) and the surveyor's certificate shall indicate that permanent control points will be set within one (1) year from the date of recordings of the plat under surety posted with the town for the required improvements. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-38. - Sanitary sewers. A complete sanitary sewage collection system, shall be provided for all subdivisions and shall be connected with the town sewage collection and transmission system in a manner approved by the town. In the event individual sewage facilities are allowed under state and county regulations, the developer shall be required to deposit in escrow with the town for the purpose of constructing a sewage collection system, the amount of cash or a guarantee acceptable to the town equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the sewage collection system's estimated construction and installation cost. The entire sewage collection system shall be engineered and coordinated with the town. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-39. - Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks shall be installed in conjunction with the development of adjoining lots on both sides of all local and collector streets and on one (1) side of marginal access streets in all areas. A required sidewalk may be recommended for waiver upon concurrence of the town council when adequate pedestrian circulation throughout the subdivision is provided by means of access paths with adequate lighting. The control, jurisdiction and maintenance obligation thereof shall be placed in a property owners' association, or a condominium or cooperative association as defined by Florida law. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-40. - Streets-Generally. 
    All streets and related facilities required to serve the proposed subdivision shall be constructed by the developer. The construction shall consist of, but not be limited to, street grading, base preparation and surface course, along with drainage facilities, flush header curbs, soddings, and concrete curbs and gutters, if required. All local roads in new subdivisions shall be dedicated to public use. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87; Ord. No. O-5-90, § 3, 5-29-90) 
Sec. 17.5-41. - Same-Markers. 
    Street markers shall be provided at each intersection in the type, size and location required by the current town standards. Street name signs shall carry the street name approved on the subdivision plat. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-42. - Same-Lighting. 
    Street lights shall be installed at each street intersection, at a maximum distance of two hundred (200) feet apart between intersections and at the end of each cul-de-sac. Such lights shall be required on interior streets, boundary streets and access paths. The street lights and mounting poles shall be a type approved by the town and shall be wired for underground service except where overhead service is permitted. Upon completion of the development, street lights shall be owned, operated and maintained by the town, or either jointly or separately by a property owners' association or a condominium or cooperative association as defined by Florida law, and by the public utility furnishing the electrical service. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-43. - Central water system. A complete water distribution system shall be provided for all subdivisions and shall be connected with the town water distribution system in a manner approved by the town. In the event individual facilities are allowed under state and county regulations, the developer shall be required to deposit in escrow with the town for the purpose of constructing a water distribution and treatment system an amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the system's estimated construction and installation costs in cash or a guarantee acceptable to the town. The entire system must be engineered and coordinated with the town. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-44. - Traffic-control devices. 
    Traffic-control devices, excluding traffic lights, shall be installed in all subdivisions by the town at the developer's expense. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-45. - Construction methods. 
    Construction methods shall be those prescribed in the current Palm Beach County Construction Standards and Details and those prescribed by the current Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-46. - Supervision. 
    After approval of the final plat and supplementary material, a developer may construct the required improvements subject to obtaining all required permits. The town manager and town engineer shall be notified in advance of the date of commencement of such construction. Construction shall be performed under the surveillance of, and shall at all times be subject to review by the town engineer; however, this in no way shall relieve the developer and his engineer of the responsibility for close field coordination and final compliance with the approved plans, specifications and the requirements of this chapter. The developer shall employ a Florida registered engineer for complete administration of the construction of the required improvements. The developer shall require progress reports and final certification of the construction of the required improvements from such engineer be filed with the town engineer. The town engineer or his duly authorized representative shall have the right to enter upon the property for the purpose of reviewing the construction of required improvements during the progress of such construction. The developer's engineer shall submit construction progress reports, at points of progress prescribed by the town engineer. The developer's engineer shall coordinate joint reviews of the construction with the town engineer. The town manager shall have the authority to stop the work upon failure of the developer or his engineer to coordinate the construction of the required improvements as prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-47. - Measurements and tests. 
    During construction, the developer's engineer shall make such measurements, field tests and laboratory tests, or cause them to be made, to certify that the work and materials conform with the approved development plans and the provisions of this chapter. The town engineer may require, at his discretion, tests and measurements which he deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-48. - Completion certificate. 
    The required improvements shall not be considered complete until a completion certificate along with the final project records have been furnished to, reviewed and approved by the town manager. The certificate shall be by the developer's engineer stating that the required improvements were installed under his responsible direction and that the improvements conform with the approved construction plans and this chapter. The developer's engineer shall also furnish a copy of each of the construction plans on a high quality, time stable reproducible material acceptable to the town manager, showing the original design in comparison to the actual finished work and a copy of the measurements, tests and reports made on the work and material during the progress of the construction. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-49. - Time extensions. 
    All required improvements shall be completed within one (1) year from the date of recording of the plat or, if construction of improvements is undertaken prior to recording the plat, within twelve (12) months from the date of approval of the final plat. Time extensions may be granted by the town manager at the request of the developer when, in the opinion of the town manager, undue hardships or conditioners exist beyond the control of the developer. No such time extensions shall exceed one (1) additional year. If improvements are not complete within the prescribed time period, the town manager shall recommend to the town council the use of the guarantee for completion. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-50. - Warranty. 
    The developer shall execute a warranty (Appendix 12) guaranteeing the required improvements against defect in workmanship and material for one year after acceptance of such improvements by the town council. Such agreement shall be submitted to the town manager, along with the completion certificate and project records. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-51. - Dedication and maintenance. 
    The dedication of public space, parks, rights-of-way, easements or the like on the plat shall not constitute an acceptance of the dedication by the town. The acceptance of the dedication shall be indicated by a resolution of the town council adopted at such time as all improvements meet or exceed the standards set forth by this chapter. The town manager, upon satisfactory completion and receipt of the warranty (Appendix 12), shall certify that the developer has complied with all of the provisions, of this chapter and shall recommend to the town council the acceptance of the dedications and, when applicable, the maintenance of the required improvements. Upon such recommendations the town council, by resolution, shall approve the subdivision, the dedications on the plat and the maintenance responsibilities of the required improvements. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-52. - Town completion. 
    When a plat has been recorded and the developer fails to complete the required improvements as required by this chapter, the town council shall direct the town manager to call upon the guarantees provided by the developer to secure satisfactory completion of the required improvements. Upon the completion of such action, the town manager shall report to the council and the town council shall accept by resolution the dedications and maintenance responsibility as indicated on the plat. In such cases, the remaining guarantees posted by the developer shall be retained for a period of one (1) year after completion in lieu of the warranty. Any defects occurring during this period shall be repaired using funds remaining in the guarantee. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-53. - Failure to complete unrecorded subdivisions. 
    Where a development has elected to install the required improvements prior to recordation of the plan and fails to complete such improvements within the time limitations of this chapter, all approvals of the subdivision shall be null and void and the land shall revert to its original state. No reference shall be made to the plat with respect to the sale of lots or issuance of building permits, unless and until the plat has been resubmitted with all of the supplementary material and approvals as herein prescribed have been granted. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
ARTICLE VII. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 17.5-53.1. - Generally. 
    The design of the subdivision required improvements shall be in accordance with acceptable engineering principles. Design data, such as calculations and analyses, shall be submitted along with the development plans covering important features affecting design and important features of construction. Such calculations and analyses shall include, but not be limited to, high water, drainage facilities of all kinds, subsurfaces soil data, alternate pavement and subgrade types, and radii at intersections when minimum standards of the American Association of State Highway Transportation Officials are inadequate. Should the developer elect to provide improvements in excess of the minimum requirements, such improvements shall be considered on an individual basis. The design of required improvements shall be accomplished in such a manner that they shall be equal to or exceed current Palm Beach County Construction Standards and Details and the following [requirements.] 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-54. - Access points. 
    Points of access to lots developed within a subdivision shall be located a minimum of thirty (30) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines on local streets and one hundred eighty (180) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines on all other streets of higher classification as defined in the chapter. The subdivision shall be designed to accomplish access to the lots by the use of local streets. Local street connections to collector streets shall be a minimum of six hundred sixty (660) feet apart and collector street connections to arterial streets shall be a minimum of one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet apart. Where double frontage lots are created adjacent to a collector or arterial street, they shall front on a local street and the rear of the lot shall be the side which abuts the collector or arterial street. In such cases the lots shall be buffered as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-55. - Alleys. 
    Alleys shall be paved eighteen (18) feet wide in a minimum twenty-foot right-of-way for commercial and industrial use, all having appropriate radii for the use intended. Alleys shall have inverted crowns with three-eighths-inch per foot traversed slope. The alley grade shall not exceed five (5) percent or be less than three-tenths of one (.30) percent unless approved by the town council. Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided and dead-end alleys are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-56. - Blocks. 
    The length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(a)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated. 
(b)  Zoning requirements as to lot size and dimensions. 
(c)  Need for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
(d)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(1)  Block lengths shall not exceed one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet between intersecting streets except where special topographical conditions exist. Greater lengths may be approved by the town council. 
(2)  In blocks nine hundred (900) feet in length or over, crosswalks between streets not less than eight (8) feet wide may be required where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other community facilities. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-57. - Bridges. 
    Bridges shall be designed in general accord with the current Department of Transportation practices and shall include planning for utility installation. They shall be reinforced concrete; however, other low maintenance materials may be used, upon request and approval of the town engineer, having a clear roadway width between curbs two (2) feet in excess of the pavement width in each direction and shall provide four-foot wide sidewalks on each side. All bridge structures shall be designed for H-20-S16-44 loading, incorporating adequate erosion protection. 
(Ord. No. O-12-87, § 1, 9-28-87) 
Sec. 17.5-58. - Drainage. 
    All subdivisions must have comprehensive storm drainage facilities which convey stormwaters through easements to a publicly dedicated and maintained drainage system and shall be submitted along with the construction plans in a report form prepared by the developer's engineer, indicating the method of control of storm and groundwater, including the method of drainage, existing water elevations, recurring high water elevations, proposed design water elevations, drainage structures, canals, ditches and any other pertinent information pertaining to the system. The drainage system shall be designed using acceptable engineering principles with consideration being given to the protection of all future building from a one-in-one-one-hundred-year storm. The storm sewers shall be designed for rainstorms of the maximum intensity predicted for Palm Beach County area at three-year intervals according to current Department of Transportation charts and data. The system shall provide for drainage of lots, streets, roads and other public areas including surface waters which drain into or through the property. The design for drainage of the subdivision must he adequate to provide for surface water drainage of adjacent contributory areas. Where additional ditches and canals are required to accommodate contributory surface waters, rights-of-way shall be provided for future needs; however, the developer may be permitted to excavate or open sufficient capacity to provide for existing drainage needs whenever the developed or undeveloped status of adjacent areas so warrant, as determined by the town engineer.
